description:
This place is soooooo dope! So much fun driving down. Rode down on my motorcycle as well. Enter in on Hyde st and zig zag down and off into the sunset lol

The houses on this strip must be sooooo costly and they are very well up-kept. 

There is a sidewalk as well on the side so you can walk down this strip. 

A must do for any tourist or local in SF. 

Wouldn't recommend walking down the zig zag bc vehicle traffic is always flowing.
author: Angel M.

description:
Seriously what's all the fuzz about this street, and it was really hard to see the turns with all the flower bushes around! Not to mention the millions of tourists everywhere, I feel bad for the residence here, it's even worse than Beverly Hills garden park! I remember I could see this street much better when I came here as a child, and I was even shorter then! So it must be less flower bushes and much less tourists. 

Anyways I think it's better to rent a car drive down the turned street now, that way you might see better, walking down the handrails were not helping anything really! I wasn't impressed with this tourist trap but sister and parents were happy to hang around. They did agree that they saw this street much better years ago though. 

Stop by if you like tourist trap, otherwise just skip it!
author: Mimi L.

description:
When I was just a wee Annette I was obsessed with the Real World. And the first San Francisco season was my favorite. Where did they live? Lombard Street. I remember it to this day. Now, early 90s San Francisco is much different than 2018 San Francisco but I still got a bit of a thrill whenever we walk by the street when I'm in town. 

These days, the designation "curviest street in the world" makes it a tourist destination, not the Real World. Folks come to check out the street and drive slowly down its steep, windy roads. It's a sight to see if you're in the area but perhaps not worth going out of your way to come to if you're in town. But at dusk, when the sky is hues of pink and purple, and you can see the rest of SF in the distance, you can definitely see the appeal of visiting and spending a bit of time here. It certainly makes a great photo op.
author: Annette J.

description:
curvy street? driving through peoples' driveways? almost running over dozens of pedestrians on the way down? driving in between people trying to take pictures of their families? Lombard street has everything!!

it's definitely worth going to. i found it pretty hard to take a good photo of this place because it's on an incline. you can't really get a good picture of it from the top or while you're on it. from the bottom i imagine there's this really cool rooftop or something where you can get a really good aerial shot but i do not know of this building. 

it doesn't take long to drive down the street even if you're going super slow. it's a really good add-on to your trip if you want to fit in an extra landmark or short activity!
author: Enoch C.

description: Good to see this once but no need to come back. Do not walk here because the streets are super steep. The flowers lining the street are pretty and a cool sight seeing cars struggling down it. You maybe need 10 mins max here; nothing more.
author: Lanha T.

description: Ah yes Lombard Street! One of the number one must-sees in San Francisco! It's free and the surrounding streets have some breathtaking views of the area. Walk up and down the stairs if you please but look out for all the cars driving down (stay on walkway). Respect the beautiful flowers that align the road and the neighbors that live there. :)
author: Zach H.

description: Definitely a stop you have to make it you're in San Francisco!! It's near the golden gate park/Haight-Ashbury so if you're in the area def go! It's awesome to see the beautiful homes that are located in this street, and most importantly how windy this road is! Nothing like it. Beware of the steep hill going up if you're driving/walking. Parking is kinda crazy up there because of all the tourists, but that view is amazing!
author: Lia A.

description:
Overly crowded. People blocking traffic by posing in the middle of the street. Don't come with your car as you won't find parking. Unless you double park like some. Neighbors must hate it:)

Flowers are beautiful and the street is gorgeous and nice to visit. The houses on the side also beautiful. The tourists are a disgrace.
author: Apple S.

description:
Here's what you do: close your eyes, now picture some pretty Victorian styles houses, some lush greenery, and a crooked street. Once you've got that vision imprinted into your mind, spin quickly around in a circle a few times. Now, open your eyes. There, you've just done Lombard Street, and it didn't take a 2 hour wait in line!! That's why I'm a Yelp Elite, I'm here to serve....

Lombard Street IS an iconic tourist destination for a first trip to the City. A crooked 600 foot long street with your typical San Francisco houses bordered on either side; some gardens that can range from lush and vibrant to blah and boring, depending on season; and a virtual cacophony of tourists that basically ruin the experience by being stupid. Not you, of course. (::::eye-roll::::)

If the flowers are in bloom it can be an adorable little walk or drive, but in reality, it's just a very short, crooked street. If you deign to skip this stop in lieu of the many, way cooler attractions San Francisco has to offer, you're really not missing much. If you feel an irresistible need to do it, try to arrive earlier in the day while all the other tourists are still trying to sleep off their hangovers.
author: Michael H.

description: This place had a nice view and it was nice to take picture here with your love ones. We had a great time .
author: Christian C.

description:
**** Review 104 ****

It was a good site to see and experience. Besides the actual street, the location has great views of San Francisco. Lots of tourists come to see it, so make sure you don't become an annoying tourist and block the streets around it. The houses around it are beautiful, and it's a short walk to Pier 39.
author: Luis S.

description:
Driving down Lombard Street never gets old. I loved it as a kid and still love it as an adult. 

It's such an excitement driving up a very steep hill to get to the top and then drive down the crooked street while trying to enjoy the view of the city. 

It's one of the best attractions in San Francisco and a must see while you are visiting.
author: Glenn A.

description:
Great touristy stuff! 
These streets and homes are so pretty! 
It's about a 1/2 mile up of you're walking the stairs 
Great vows of Lombard street once you get up there 
-driving the street 
Ekkkk I don't dare but for all of you that are brave kudos to you' 
-walking it was so enjoyable and fun! 
Views were amazing
-parking -- make sure you park correctly, parking enforcement doesn't play around
author: Koi S.

description:
Let's cut to the chase:

Is this a top-tourist place-Yes

Is it worth seeing-Yes

Is it "instagram worthy"-Yes

Are there a lot of people there-Yes


Jokes aside, super cute street that I just had to see on my trip and I'm glad I did. There are a ton of people trying to get that money shot just like you. If you have a car, I recommend driving down the street, seemed super cool.
author: Adelina M.

description:
I tried to see this when I first visited SF for a day in 2012 while on a vacation to Monterey.  We tried to get to it, but couldn't locate the street!

Fast forward to 2014 and I end up moving out to the Bay Area from NY.  I had to come back to see one of the most crooked streets!!  We were usually in SF 1-2x each month, so we did a little research and found it.  

I'm a little embarrassed to admit why I wanted to come here!  I was a HUGE fan of the 3rd season of the Real World that was filmed at a house on this street back in 1994!  This was the season with Pedro and Puck.  The house was located at 949 Lombard, but a fire did wreck most of it, but it has been rebuilt.

We parked not TOO far from Lombard and walked down it.  It was fun to take it all in.

We then DROVE down, which was crazy with all the traffic.  Still, it was fun to do it once.
author: Kara M.

description: Not sure why this is on yelp but this was the third time I've been here and it's fun to walk down and people watch here. I overheard someone say the road is as straight as most of the people who live here.
author: Ben T.

description: Fun viewpoint and a great place to take a couple photos. This is an iconic place, so don't be surprised if it is crowed.
author: Louis M.

description: TRUE STORY: Lookout for the Lombard Street GRINCH! She's a mean one. She will be trimming her bushes & pulling out her weeds. But if she sees you even take one step onto the red brick Lombard Street, she will scream at you, "GET OFF THE ROAD!! if you try & touch any of the plants, she will violently come over to you & yank at the same plant you touched & she will pull on it vigorously screaming at you, "DON'T TOUCH THE PLANTS" with a vicious look in her eyes making her look like the mean one. Has anyone else witnessed this? It was kinda of funny watching huff and puff her way up and down that curvy road screaming and yelling at everyone. She must live there. The picture shows the bushes she was trimming.
author: Jay R.

description:
Great tourist location. If you want to go when it's less crowded, go between the times of 2-5 on the winter or 3-7 in the summer. This spot overlooks the city and give you great views of downtown and the east bay, you can see Berkeley! 

Photos are great at the top of the street. Street parking is available so you can walk it. Driving down it is cool as well, but walking is better if the traffic becomes heavy.
author: Ami S.

description:
"I've never been up to where I've seen the others climb I have a feeling it must be nice"

So I actually went on a pilgrimage today to the North Beach Branch Library & adjacent to the library is the Joe DiMaggio Playground which is actually located on Lombard Street.

I know Lombard Street is famous as being the crookedest street in the world & stumbled upon it. I looked up to the top & looked interesting to say the least as well as quite the climb to the top.

As we enter further into December into the New Year of 2018 perhaps I will make it a point next year to return to Lombard Street & do the full ascension to the top yet for now appreciate being on the famous Lombard street vicariously appreciating the view above.
author: Shane S.

description: Really beautiful, but overly busy. We chose to walk, instead of drive, which meant we had more time to enjoy the scenery. Traffic police are at the intersections and they can be aggressive at times. There are also people who stand in the crosswalk and take pictures, which is kinda annoying.
author: Kristina H.

description: The "Crooked" Street!!"  So cool!  It's a must see and drive when you're in San Francisco.  How people live on this street is beyond me as there's always a vehicle going down it.  The traffic is so bad, there's a traffic cop at the top directing the traffic.  The views are to die for and it's actually pretty cool to drive down it.  I don't think there's another street in the world quite like this one.  Pretty cool and a must do and see!
author: Scott V.

description:
A must see for any tourist or part time Bay Area visitor. I go up to San Francisco 2-3 a year and always drive down Lombard Street, whether it be for myself, family, friends or out of towners. I always add to the local traffic but yet Lombard Street isn't too crowded or busy. Tourist come and go and don't clog up the streets. 

Just be careful of the pedestrians at the bottom of the street trying to take pictures and crossing the streets. 

Love Lombard Street! Start at the top and work your way down the most crooked street in the world!
author: Ticha B.

description:
Lombard Street and Garden is a must visit spot in San Francisco near Fisherman's Wharf. There are various bushes and shrubs along the narrow and curvy brick road. Cars may drive slowly down the hill, but drivers need to maneuver carefully among the congestion and tourists. On the sides of private residential buildings, you will see signs and steps to stroll up or down the garden. Don't be daunted by the steps as the climb is moderate and good for any age. We saw lots of cars and visitors crowding at the bottom for pictures, so expect to wait a little or take a photo ninja with you to take your favorite pose.

PRO Tip: 
1. walk from Hyde Street Pier ( starting point of Powell/Market Street Cable Car) to Leavenworth/Lombard street. The 10-15 min walk will be faster than waiting for the cable car which runs every 20 min
2. Standing on Lombard/Leavenworth corner gives uphill view of cars coming out 
3. Standing on Lombard/Hyde Street corner gives downhill view of SF and ocean
4. Hop on/off the cable car at Lombard/Hyde Street
author: Maggie C.

description: It's really underwhelming in person... honestly the view is better looking the opposite direction of the squiggly road, because it looks down on the downtown and the bay bridge. You also won't be able to get a good photo of yourself here because the photographer will have to stand below you. 1/10 would not recommend coming for a photo of your chins.
author: Steven E.

description:
Known as the "Crookedest Street in the World," Lombard Street is one of San Francisco's most popular landmarks. Surrounded by Russian Hill mansions and perfectly manicured landscaping and flowers, it is also one of the city's most scenic streets and its one of my favorites... I gotta drive it!!
Walking down was scary.... wear shoes with a lot of traction. Lol
author: Tijuanna D.

description:
We didn't really have a desire to go here, but we happened upon it walking somewhere else. We could've saved ourselves the five minutes. 

There are a lot of people and cars around, and honestly, I left just feeling a tiny bit bad about the homeowners. 

Two stars for the wonderful plants and a decent view, but not for the street itself. It's just an Instagrammable tourist trap. I did not take a picture here. To each their own, but there are about 100 cooler things to see and do in San Francisco.
author: Shane K.

description:
One of the most memorable stops in San Fran when I first visited as a little girl was to the world's most crooked street, Lombard! 

I knew when I brought my own daughters here for their first time (my eldest was the same age I was when I first visited this magical city!!) a drive down Lombard was definitely a trip we had to make! 

They loved it as much as I remember loving it! 
We actually went down twice!!

Sure it's touristy, but it's also super fun and the views not only from the top heading down of the bridge and bay, but the lush gardens as you're maneuvering your car around the bends are gorgeous! 

They ask that you don't walk to take photos actually ON the windy drive although many did.

Be careful taking photos below as it is a working street.
I did find it difficult to take photos without others in the background of yours. I hear first thing in the morning is key if that perfect shot is something you are looking for. 

If it's your first visit to San Fran, you can't miss this especially if you have kiddos!! 

So. Much. Fun!!
author: Sari Marissa G.

description:
Like many things in San Francisco, Lombard Street is a iconic sight that you've just gotta take the time to see!
In today's smart phone age it's easy to find.  You'll have the option to actually drive down it although on most days it will take you awhile.  In my opinion it's best experienced two ways.  Standing at the foot of the iconic winding street to take those selfies with the winding cars in the background, or to actually climb the steep street using the staircase that runs parallel to the street.  Either way it's a beautiful sight as the flowers and greenery make for a unique experience!
author: Michael S.

description: It's a great experience to drive around. You have to be really patience, since it's tourist attraction area there are too many cars and too much foot traffic. Other than that becautiful view
author: bilal s.

description: Fun to drive through. Easy to take nice pictures. Street parking is not metered. Strongly suggested!
author: Tommaso M.

description:
Iconic road in San Fran. Great views from the top but be ready to take a little hike up! It's a nice walk if you can make it but if not, there are tons of shuttles, Uber's or tours that you can take that will take you to the top without having to walk straight uphill. 

Very safe part of town so if you like views, it's great to walk up and have views of the city at night!
author: Bethany M.

description: Still a tourist favorite. If I have guests visiting SF for the first time, this is a must stop on the way to the GG bridge. I still enjoy walking up and down the street and taking photos along the way. It is a mini workout too. Parking is of course a major hassle, no special tip here...I also struggle to find a spot.
author: Sunil R.

description:
It's an iconic street in the entire country. If you show people a picture of it, they know what it is. 

That being said, it's kind of anti-climactic to see. There are pretty views up there at the top of the hill but it's just a road. Sure, it's a really curvy road, but it's still just a road. 

Don't get me wrong, you have to see it just because it's Lombard Street and if you're in the city, you can't not see it. But, don't think it's anything more than just seeing a super curvy, super famous road. It's just a road.
author: Matt M.

description:
Huge tourist attraction! 

Good luck finding street parking to take pictures! Or... be a dick and stop your car at the very bottom, get out of your car, and become a Lombard St Photographer and block everyone else! 

I made a bad choice by going at the very peak hour when everyone's awake and ready to become a tourist. 

I suggest the best time to go is late at night, when everyone's asleep. You get to see night lights and the Bay Bridge lit up! Wouldn't you want that beautiful night picture instead of that foggy day landscape pic?! 

Also, going down this thing takes FOREVER!!! There's so many people getting on the zig zag and everyone drives so slow! 

Who wouldn't want to experience a time when NO ONE drives down that thing?! ME ME ME! 

I would like to see how fast I can go down that thing.................with a bike! LOOOL 

Now that I think about it.. maybe I shouldn't have suggested this. Otherwise everyone will be doing it at night now.  jk have fun!
author: Katie L.

description:
Reviewer # 620

AS good as it gets! On the weekends plan to be in line for a few hours if you want to drive down the iconic street and get a very good view of the breathtaking city. I've driven down it a few times now and I would really like to walk up and down it next time, but the parking is quite terrible. Perhaps I will Uber there next time. 

I would hate to live on the street honestly. Only because of the people standing in your front yard constantly and it would take over an hour just to get into your garage-- no thank you. I would love to live in one of these homes if I had a helicopter or a back interest. The view is seriously amazing. Check out my photos for some amazing photos. 

This street has been on many films including The Love Bug.
author: Greg D.

description:
Dearest Lombard Street - 

You silly silly street, you got us!  Even though we knew you were a 'tourist trap' we totally fell for your zigzagginess.  You are just as special, and notorious and crooked as everyone says and I'm glad we took the time to visit you.  :-)

- AP
author: Alyssa R.

description:
You know you've found Lombard St when there are swarms of people and a huge line of traffic (from the top) waiting to drive down. The world's crookedest street offers wonderful views of the bay. It's a hectic place, with a lot of traffic (ahem, jams) and people walking everywhere. You really need to be aware of what's going on around you. People at the bottom of the street crowd the intersection for photo ops, and traffic in general around Lombard is impatient and doesn't always obey rules. 

If you walk up the left side, there's 253 steps, and 249 steps on the right. The street is lined with beautiful flowers and the houses themselves are lovely. I find it difficult to imagine living here though because the traffic is nonstop, the people noisy and always in front of your house.

Tourist or resident, you should definitely check this place out at least once, for the gorgeous scenery and energizing walk.
author: Nikita H.

description: Meh, it s a street with a bunch of Hydrangeas.  It's pretty but you couldn't pay me to live next to that daily chaos.  It has one nice view, looking down from the top.
author: Jim P.

description: One of the great places to see in San Francisco   go down specially at night you could take some really nice pictures of the city. If you go during the day expect a backup so it's better to go at night take your time take pictures take video Take your time walking  down or walking up driving down in the car.
author: Lizzie G.

description: This is the crookedest street in the world! I always take tourists here but I am always excited about it myself (despite going down this street over 5 times now). Make sure you know how to drive up extremely steep hills before attempting to drive down this street. Traffic getting up to the top of this hill is dense and you'll be stuck in extremely steep inclines while driving very slowly. Depending on what time of the year you go, the windy road might have flowers. If you don't want to drive down the windy road but instead park below it and take pictures, there are parking spots along the road that are free. Make sure to take photos as fast as you can because the roads are still open for regular traffic.
author: Brenda L.

description:
Lombard Street was quite an experience.  Thankfully we rented a car with an automatic transmission!!  This is one street I have always wanted to drive so I was excited to get to do it.  However, when I saw how steep the street was in person, I was anxious, kind of between terrified, nervous and excited.

Why are there street lights going up Lombard?  To make tourists think twice! JK.  It was actually pretty cool once I realized we weren't going to roll back down the hill.  Being so steep was very interesting.  When we got to the top, we were stopped as a cable car unloaded tourists to an already busy intersection.  Once it unloaded off we went!

Going down was really cool. The houses that line the street going down Lombard were beautiful and the road is lined with flowers.  What a cool drive!  I am so happy I did it!
author: Angela D.

description:
Dude this street is so dang cool. Yes I had to drive but it wa still amazing. I wasn't to thrilled with waiting in the line but after going down the street it was totally worth it. 

Be prepared to have to wait in line.
author: Jason Z.

description:
I came to San Fran for the second time, and I just wanted to experience something unique and local. 
My friend told me about this place, she said "when you go to San Francisco, you have to check out this street".
Despite the face that there are always.... so many cars 24/7, and the fact that you have to wait for quite a while, it's a lifetime experience that you need to try when you come in town. It really tests out how good your driving skills are :)
author: Helen L.

description: The street is narrow and crowded. One can see cars going down the lane continuously. There are plantations, flowers to enjoy the view of huge steep slope down the street. It is exactly the same as depicted in the GTA game.
author: Shail P.

description: So fun ! I suggest taking the cable car to Lombard Street getting down at the begging of the street. Taking some pictures at the top because it has a nice view of the city and the street going down. If you don't have difficulty walking, go down the stairs and get great pictures on the way down. When you get downstairs, you'll get the best photos of the whole street. Traffic is busy and lots of tourists, of course. Walk upstairs again & take the cable car to the very end of the cable car stop which is only 3 blocks down. Really cool experience.
author: Mia P.

description:
This is the famous San Francisco road that twist back and forth: Lombard Street!
I've driven down this road in my old z-series, and decided to drive down again. It's a fun drive, that cars of all sizes can do. People also go down this street in motorcycles, bicycles, scooters, mopeds, and even unicycles.
This is definitely a tourist trap, with folks from all over the place snapping photos and walking up and down the area. There are steps on either side of the road, which make for a good exercise.
I recommend this spot, it is a must see. If you have a convertible (like my old Z-3), then even better!
author: William G.

description:
A must see in San Francisco! One of the most popular things do in this city! I'm sure many people have seen this street on a movie or TV show which adds to it's popularity. It's both unusual to drive down this street and a lot of fun. There's always a ton of tourists and traffic around Lombard Street. 

If you can find parking near or around Lombard Street be sure to walk down or up. If you choose to walk up be prepared for a steep climb.. Foot traffic gets really busy as well. There are traffic officers there to keep the traffic flowing.

I honestly don't know how people live on this street with so many tourists constantly on this street at all hours of the day.Take tons of pictures and don't forget to record when you're driving down this street.
author: Karen C.

description:
Although I was born and raised in the bay, this was my very first time checking out Lombard Street! 

The boyfriend and I found parking nearby the residential areas and walked a block to Lombard Street. I was surprised to see traffic/crowd control officers, but greatly appreciate their presence as the traffic with both pedestrians and vehicles were extremely hectic here. Safety first!

As we walked up Lombard Street, I had a fun time observing other people, especially individuals in vehicles driving down the historic crooked street doing some illegal things. All part of the experience! The views are excellent and I loved the pretty flowers and greenery along the way. The homes are beautiful, too!

Definitely a great place to check out, especially if you are not from the area. However, personally one time is enough for me (at least for a while). Have fun!
author: Julia L.

description: Make no mistake about it, Lombard is actually quite a long and regular street. This one block is the iconic, windy road and it is incredibly cool. Our Uber driver (who was also amazing), made a quick pitt stop and we hopped out to take photos. There's a guard on duty there and he is incredibly personable and hilarious. His primary job is to ensure the safety of drivers and pedestrians such as myself who randomly hopped in the middle of the street to take photos. Be mindful that Lombard is an actual street with cars. Very cool. I've never seen anything quite like it. Worth the visit. Only takes a few minutes to view if you're on a crunch for time.
author: Kari C.

description: My favorite street ever!!!! If you can, drive down and then park and walk up to take the pictures that way you will get the best of both worlds :). Driving it and walking it are definitely not the same experiences. Great spot to catch the cable car too!!! This last time I visited SF I waited by ghirardelli square literally 1.30 hrs for the cable car, but when we passed by Lombard street people just hopped on without even waiting, who knew!?
author: Lucia B.

description: I remember driving down Lombard Street at least five times in a row when I was in San Francisco years ago. It is so fun with the turns and all. Yes, it is touristy, but the houses are nice along the sides of the street.
author: Matthew H.

description:
What a street! So different and beautiful!
It was great to see the city from the top, see the cars go down carefully and the people from all over the world take pictures. Defitenly a place to stop by as a tourist.
author: Christine B.

description:
I've always wanted to see "the most crooked street in the world". Not only was the mission completed, I did it in the funkiest tour bus to rock the west coast!

My wife & I took a tour with San Francisco Love Tours. We're zipping thru towns, everyone recognizes the VW vans. Its brightly painted bus with peace signs and groovy sayings. Everyone flashes a peace sign and snaps a picture as we boot skoot thru towns. Now picture cruising down Lombard Street in the van with me riding shotgun?? People were going out of their minds! Tourists snapping pictures, I'm smiling, posing and laughing, it was something I'll never forget.

Groovy baby
author: Bill S.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review for Lombard Street yet!

Walking to Lombard Street can test your fitness level because my oh my, the GIGANTIC hill that you climb up (depending on which direction you're facing to get up here) is a great test to see how much energy you have. For most it's probably fine, but for me, who walked a good 20km that day with a ridiculous amount of stairs, I was exhausted!

The swervy, curviness of Lombard Street is a trademark of San Francisco. There are many guards just standing at the intersection always yelling at tourists to get off the road for cars to past - I think I would hate to be a local in this neighbourhood. The most beautiful spot to take pictures is located at the bottom of Lombard Street where you can actually see the curvy roads!

Definitely a place to visit when you come to San Francisco!!
author: Kristy N.

description:
You know we've been coming up North since about 2006 for football games and every time we make a stop at Frisco. It wasn't until years later that we took a co-worker of mine and his friend for a game that we found out about Lombard Street. All because it was in all their damn video games and they just had to see the street before we headed back home LMAO.

So we've been coming here after that thanks to those weirdos. We also bring our friends here that have never been to Frisco and they just love it. They girls loved it too especially the little one, running down those stairs and leaving us behind lol.

Parking around here can be a hassle, thankfully since we were here early we got a good spot. You can also get a good view of the Bay. The drive through the street doesn't take long, unless of course their are alot tourist around which there always is. Mostly it's after 11 when it gets full. It is worth a stop to see maybe at least once.
author: Graciela P.

description: My boy friend and I had an adventurous time heading over to Lombard Street. Climbing up the hills of San Francisco just to take some touristy photos at the iconic crookedest street in the world. We took photos from the top, middle, and bottom. Tons of steps on both the left and right side. It's a great way to get your leg work out in! The flowerbeds were gorgeous with tons of blue and purple hydrangeas all year round. Such a sight to see! It's neat watching people walk up and down the street versus people driving through it. It would be neat to experience both ways! Overall, Lombard Street is super iconic and a must photo op place to go!
author: Natasha N.

description:
It is crowded and touristy af.  
It's SF AF.
Which is why you have to do it.  Especially when it's free.
It's probably the best free non-sea lion thing to do in SF.
I like to yell "No brakes!" as I go down.
author: Glen N.

description:
I'm giving this area 4 stars on account it was a quick tourist-sy run. It was easy to get here and there wasn't really much room for crowding around. It's more like take a picture and experience the ride -- once or twice. :)

When our group went here one evening, the view of the city was so nice. I feel bad for the folks living in this neighborhood as there was a good amount of cars wound it ways down this short but curvy street. 

And as for the length of the street... It takes 2 to 3 mins from top to bottom if you drive slowly. What you see in the pic of Lombard street is all that there is. 

I did see people walk down Lombard, but as they made their way down, they took pictures of the view (like the one I have posted).
author: Andrea M.

description: Very cool to see the  crookedest street in America. I recommend taking a trolley to a near drop off point then getting back on for your next destination. The tourist traffic was very heavy trying to driving down the road. The walk was just as satisfying.
author: Michael H.

description:
It's a windy freakin street, what's not to like?! 8 hair pin turns, narrow as all get out, apparently it was designed to reduce the hills intense gradient that makes it hard for cars to drive on. I love that this was the solution to that problem. 

We went at night and had no trouble driving through. You get a beautiful view of Coit Tower lit up in the distance.
author: Luci B.

description:
A free attraction deserves 5 stars!  

Be cautious of tourists who are making the wrong turn onto Lombard Street.

This place offers a great view of the city.

I'm sure homeowners are annoyed but what can you do. 

I suggest parking on top of Lombard and walking or if you're driving come from the opposite side as you'll be able to make a right turn into the street.

Be sure you have a friend with you to take pics and record video of this unique street.
author: Arnel D.

description: Almost everyone we came across in San Francisco told us we had to visit Lombard Street. We came, we saw, we conquered. The tourist turnout over Labor Day Weekend was intense as was the record breaking heat. I felt very bad for the neighbors who had to put up with all of us noisy tourists. Nonetheless, the zig zag street is worth a photo op or selfie if only for its spectacular views of the city. I don't recommend trying to drive down this street because it's such a quick dissent. Instead, walk down the sidewalk and marvel at the beauty of antiquity.
author: Vincent Artemio E.

description: The Lombard street is definitely crooked for car access, with 8 hairpin turns on the one way street going down the hill.  For pedestrians taking the stairs, its pretty much a straight shot going up and down.  The highlights of Lombard Street include the excellent views from both the top and bottom of the hill, and of course the many flower beds planted everywhere.  You'll see folks in cars, go carts, scooters, and motorcycles do weird things coming down the hill do, like driving while taking selfies.  They have traffic control folks busy at both the top and bottom of the hill.  Probably the funnest character is the traffic guy in the middle of the hill - he chats with customers and jokes around quite a bit with each car.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Very nice view. It's definitely the most special and signature interest in the whole city. Since it's on Russian Hill, you can easily get an open view of the entire city along with the coastlines. Beautiful. 

Do keep some things in mind. First, since this section of crooked garden street is on Russian Hill, you will need to do a lot of climbing if you do not use any transportation. Check out the cable car around the area if you're interested, but other means of public transportation is pretty limited -- the small number of bus lines, and surely no Bart. 

Also, if you want a few great looking pictures, please come by as early as possible. It's such a hot spot that people start to crowd up ever since 9 or 10 in the morning. Unless you think the tourist scene can enrich your photography, set your alarms!
author: Junyu Z.

description:
Driving whilst holding a GoPro out the window and watching the replay screen instead of the road? Don't be that kid. We took someone's advice and walked up to Lombard Street from the back way, then walked down the stairs alongside the famously crooked street. My little sister has lived in the Bay Area her entire life and had no recollection of ever coming to here, so it was a cool, touristy thing to do with her and DD. Walking allowed us to take our time and stop to smell the roses (or whatever the flowers were).  We enjoyed the different views and angles as we took countless selfies along the way.  Once we reached the bottom of that section, we joined in with the rest of the tourists in our surely illegal blocking of the roadway and impeding traffic. However, it appears that no locals were driving in this area, only other tourists, so the traffic was minimal.  I was pleasantly surprised to see a public safety employee present. He kept a careful watch from the sidelines, but he did have to yell at someone -advising them to get out of the street- who was sitting in the middle of the street, and wouldn't budge when a car was coming.  smh Don't be that kid either.

Beautiful area. Free thrills. Great gluteus work out.  That's what's up!
author: Tigra C.

description:
Known for being the crooked-est street in the world, Lombard St is always a fun place to visit! It's usually flooded with tourists, but it can be fun for locals as well. 

I like walking down more than driving because you have more time to take in the view and take as many pictures as you like. Although, driving down is fun to do at least once! The cars move slowly and are usually polite. You can get a cool view of SF from the top and spot Coit Tower in the distance as well. There were also lots of gorgeous flowers and greenery along the street which are great for photo ops. 

2 hour street parking is available around the area, but it can be hilly so be careful while parking on inclines and remember to turn your wheels!
author: Susan D.

description:
I confess, I stood in the middle of the crosswalk to take selfies with iconic Lombard Street in the background. But hey, everybody else was doing it.

Besides, there was a safety officer there making sure people don't get run over. So it looks like all the sightseeing here is sanctioned by the city.

Even drivers seem to come here for the experience. There was a line of cars on Hyde Street waiting to take a right to drive down the twisty road. I even saw a guy in a coupe driving down holding a GoPro with one hand. Maybe I and the other 100 sightseers there will show up on YouTube!
author: Anson W.

description:
It's a windy street.  Sounds like a waste of time, right?  Wrong.  Our visit to Lombard Street was a mix of humor and amazement.

First, I find it fascinating that the street is so windy and you can even get a car down there.

Second, watching the cars wind down at "Two Miles an hour, so everyone can see you" (credit DJ Jazzy Jeff and Fresh Prince) is hilarious.  My favorite was watching an old school convertible Caddie drive on down blasting AC/DC with an older guy who just didn't give a...

Third, it's incredible that people even live on the street AND have cars.  I can't imagine living here, but you get a sense of their daily commute.

It's a hike up to the top, so I wouldn't recommend this for anyone with walking issues.  Stay at the bottom and take a selfie.
author: Jeannine S.

description: The prettiest, most well groomed fun street ever! There's a billion people & cars at the end of it taking pictures so good luck getting a clear shot of it. We loved seeing the gorgeous flowers & scenery!
author: Alexis G.

description:
Came here during the night around 530-6pm. A lot of people and cars up and down this street. There was crossing guards/people in front guiding cars as they came down the street.

My son really enjoyed it. We walked up the stairs along the side and got into our car and drove down it as well. The houses were nice, everything was well kept. Beautiful.

As we were walking, we saw a van who would go pretty fast while hit the corners... it was pretty obnoxious of the driver. Other than that, the view of the city towards the bridge was nice as well.
author: Yee W.

description: Definitely the kids favorite they had us bring them here a few times they loved it!!  Neat street to drive down and take pics. You must come here.
author: Zuri P.

description:
San Francisco is built on several steep hills making both walking and driving a challenge. Lombard street counteracted its steepness by making its road twist and turn. 

The famous section of the street in the Russian Hill area has eight hairpin bends. It would be interesting to drive down. It is also interesting to watch others drive down. This section of the street has several lovely buildings and the road winds through gardens. These are filled with flowers in summer. On our visit they were not, but there was some lovely spring blossom.

One of the best things about Lombard Street is the fantastic view you get when you are standing at the top of it. You can see all the way to the Bay Bridge and the Coit Tower. The view is stunning by day and spectacular by night when it is all lit up.
author: Steve N.

description:
If you can climb up the huge slope to get to the bottom of the crooked street, GOOD FOR YOU. This place was sooooo crowded on a Saturday. Lots of tourists (guilty) but I was determined to relive my childhood. 

To be honest, you can't see the zig-zags clearly from anywhere. I even climbed up the mini-pole, and I still couldn't see much besides lots of green shrubs and cars driving through. I am glad that there is also patrol for pedestrians and cars...this place would be a mad house if they weren't there! 

There are two cable car stops nearby that will take you to Fisherman's Wharf and Pier 39. Part of the experience, if you haven't done it already!
author: Hurjane V.

description: Place is PACKED with people. It's a pretty sight but that hill...I feel bad for the residents that lives there. However, it is a really pretty place.
author: Nikki H.

description: What a great street! Not sure it ever would want to live on it but it's fun to drive down or walk down. Been there many times - once in a little yellow go carts that you could take around the city which are highly recommended and super Duper fun but my favorite was at night when no one else was there and I was able to see how fast I could go down Lombard Street. The next day I brought my sister back (who had never been) to show her where we were the night before, when I attempted to not have to break down the Windy road. Of course I did have to break and I was safe don't worry! But it was fun and she was pretty surprised how fast we were able to get down such a Windy road!  It's an absolute must see attractions and if you've never been to San Fran! You can get out at the bottom and take pictures or take them at the top both provide great photo ops!
author: Christy W.

description:
Welcome to the crookedest street in the world! This place is definitely worth checking out when you're in SF. But beware, there will be soOoOOOooO many tourists. 

What I did was I drove down the street and then found meter parking and checked it out by foot. At the bottom of the street, there were tons, and I mean TONS of tourists standing in the street trying to take pictures. People were just blocking and standing in the streets, thinking the world revolves around them, and cars had to honk to get thru. It was insane. 

I walked from the bottom to the top of the street, taking pictures here and there. There are lots of flowers on the side that will allow you to take artsy fartsy photos and such.

It's awesome that there are people actually living in the houses on the street, but I just wonder how they deal with the insane amount of traffic and tourists.  

I would recommend coming here early to avoid all the tourists and cars. It would allow you to get better photos with a ton of people and cars in it.
author: Michelle T.

description: The street is crooked. Great view of the city. Touristy things to do when visiting San Francisco. You can walk to North Beach (bars and food) when you get the bottom of the street.
author: Jon M.

description:
If you are in SF, you gotta drive down this infamous street lol but it's been years for us and we wanted to show our younger ones so we drove it. I don't remember the pretty flowers around it by that was nice. Yes didn't like the part where tourists littered the whole street down even to the point of camping out by these houses. How do they live knowing their backyard or front yard is constantly filled with tourist snapping pictures? 
 I guess we weren't any better driving down but at least we stayed in the car. Boy it's steep but a lot of fun snapping pics inside the car and driving down.
Pure nostalgia :)
author: Grace L.

description:
[ The hub suggested I take our 4 yr old on a mommy and me vacay, but where do you take a rambunctious 4 yr old little lady in training? SF, of course! With it being only an hours flight away, it was perfect! ]

I hadn't been to Lombard Street in well over a decade, but thought the little one might enjoy it. My friend picked us up from the airport and we proceeded here after having breakfast. After driving down the "zig zag" as my daughter called it, we parked the car and the little one lead us up all the way to the top of the street in a flash. I wish I had her energy. Anyone know how to bottle something like that?!

Even mid-day on a Friday there were plenty of tourists blocking the streets, I can't imagine how much worse it is on a weekend. I tried to take more pics than usual, but I'm more of a live in the moment type so I don't have much to show for our half hour or so here. 

There are stairs on either side of the street so take one side up and the other side down. Perfect! Plenty of flowers for you to "stop and smell the roses" if you'd like and I'm certain there are plenty of other tourists around (at any time) to take a pic for you. Stop with the selfies and let someone get a wide shot of you and the scenery! Trust me, one day, you'll want to remember MORE THAN JUST YOUR FACE ;p
author: Grace C.

description:
One of the things that makes San Fran unique and great.

Drive down it...even if you live here.

Walk up it ...even if you're out of shape

Marvel at the lovely views of the east bay and the lights.
author: David G.

description: Lots of traffic and people but worth it. Was fun to see and close to the wharf. Recommend parking a few away and then walking.
author: Kimberly G.

description:
If you're a tourist, definitely make it a point to visit and take a photo op. Take the cable car and start at the bottom of the crooked street and be sure to walk up the steps to the top.
The woman worker maintaining the plants/landscape was nice enough to remind a tourist not to leave her phone/selfie stick on the ground because it can easily be taken.
Beautiful scenery, get some cardio in and it's Free!
author: Mary E.

description:
I spent one minute and 47 seconds of my life driving down this street. I think I can die happy now.

Check.

One more thing off the bucket list.

But seriously growing up near New York City and being there several times, to drive the streets of San Francisco and walk them is really a trip. There are barely any hills to climb in New York City and I get on some of the streets in San Francisco and understand how they filmed those car jumping scenes back in the 70s and crazy cop chases. Notably Dirty Harry and the Bullitt. If you go really fast down the hills and get to a level cross street, you feel like you are just going to drop off fast. That reminds me, Notable mention: "The Rock" when The humvee jumps.

Lombard is very unique with some beautiful landscaping, definitely worth checking out.
author: Bryan F.

description:
Every single time that I visit SF, this is one of my stops. I remember running up and down the stairs on the side as a 5 year old kid. Whenever we park, I managed to run up and down the stairs again (as if I was 5 again). 

Be careful driving down the road as you can get into a traffic jam with the car in front of you, or people blocking the streets while trying to get a good picture - sometimes even with a long selfie stick!

This place is definitely a tourist spot. But you can't blame them, you never really see a road like this on an everyday basis.
author: Michelle S.

description: I didn't want to drive down the street as there were many people watching the cars that were. Some see it as a thrill, speeding down with their music blasting. I started at the top and walked down the stairs to see the view from the bottom as well. The red brick street has 8 hairpin turns with flower gardens on the side. It's a free attraction, so it doesn't hurt to check it out.
author: Helen H.

description: It's a street. It's crooked. It's one hell of a hike to the top! The best view is from the bottom, so don't waste your time walking to the top. The street wasn't all that busy when we went by, so I'm sure you could drive it if you really wanted to. It's your run of the mill residential street. I'd probably be unhappy if I owned one of those multi-million dollar homes and people were constantly crowding my street. Neat that it's one of the crookedests street in north America, though.
author: Brandi K.

description:
This street is crazy!
For sure something that has to be seen, there is really no street like it.
Actually I don't know any city quite as hilly as San Francisco and there are a ton of crazy steep streets, but this is really something else.
Very busy and overloaded with tourists this might be better to walk that drive through, we did both and it was a fun short stop during our vacation here.
author: Nijole T.

description: It's a cool street to visit in San Fran. My suggestion is to walk vs driving because you get to enjoy it more.  I was visiting during thanksgiving and it was EMPTY only 5 -8 people which is great !!! Go early morning to get good shots
author: Suzy V.

description: To drive down there was a wait but it was worth it because it was really cool! Then when we got down we took pictures and it was really fun. I know it's a typical touristy place but it's pretty awesome. Specially since they have opened it up again for people to drive down it.
author: Bianca M.

description:
For me, this was a must, I've seen Lombard Street in so many movies.  The best view is on foot at the bottom of the street looking up, but we also drove the hill.  Strewn throughout the curvy hill is well pedicured flowers, mainly hydrangea, which were in full bloom on our visit. 

It's not often you get to see curvy streets like these, especially when it's on a down hill, mind you, it's a one way street.  The area here is pretty nice, but exercise some patience, it can get crowded at times, especially when people block your way and don't know how to move.  When we drove the hill there was so much traffic over Memorial Day that the city posted traffic officers at the top and bottom of the hill. 

If you're visiting, be sure to check this street out. If you plan on driving on this street, drive SLOW and assume it will take about 30+ minutes.
author: Chris G.

description:
It's a short winding road.  Just not impressed.  It is not the big deal it's made out to be but it's clear by the volume of tourists there that great marketing, good pictures by professional photographers have done their job.

It was more fun to walk it than drive it. I did both.
author: Thomas B.

description:
Yes, it's touristy. Yes, there are always a bunch of people. Yes, it's just a road. But c'mon, you have to come and see it once right: the "most crooked street in America." I took tons of pictures, it's close to the piers and the Embarcadero!

Be warned, it is on the top of a very steep hill. I highly recommend getting the Uber to drop you off at the top and walk down rather than up.
author: Judy S.

description:
Beautiful views from the top of this super popular street.  If you have a car visit at night when there is nobody around and drive down the winding road!  
Definitely a must visit if you are in San Francisco!
author: Jennifer D.

description:
It was a nice quick experience to come see it and take pictures. This place is packed with tourists so be prepared to wait in line if you want to drive through it. We opted out and just settled with pictures.

I would check it out if your in the area.
author: Keniff K.

description:
A free tourist stop in SF! YES! You have to go. Where will you find any other zig zag street in the world? While it is crazy busy, you can still get beautiful shots of the street with a beautiful view of the city. 

I recommend parking at the top. Get out of your car to take a couple pictures of the street and enjoy the view. Once you capture the beauty, get back in your car, drive down the street, and wave to the residents on the road.
author: Izzy C.

description:
We didn't drive it (who would do this on purpose?) but we did stop at the bottom for photos. There's no easy way to get here except by walking, taxi or other car. Though the Powell-Hyde streetcar stops at the top of Lombard Street, the better pictures are at the bottom.

Major tourist attraction. Be on the lookout for out-of-control selfie sticks.
author: Bruce K.

description:
She's Got Curves And She Knows How To Use Them ...

I've walked, and drove down this street many times through the years. 

It's definitely a tourist destination with hordes of people.

Once you reach the bottom, if you continue forward a block more to Jones St., there's an apartment building on the corner, left hand side, that was used in Alfred Hitchcock's film, Vertigo, 1958.
The main protagonist in the film, Scottie, played by Jimmy Stewart, lived in the bottom apartment. (900 Lombard St.) 

In recent years the new owners built a wall in front of the building, and painted over the brick fireplace to keep out tourists. It looks very different then it did in the film. They ruined it for film buffs and fans of 50's 
Architecture.

Anyways... there's a dispute over which is crookedest street in San Francisco. We have the famous Lombard St. In Russian Hill, V  Vermont St.  in Potrero Hill. 
Vermont, while steeper than Lombard, has fewer turns.
Lombard is the more famous, prettier sister to Vermont.

I've been to both and I think Vermont is the winner ! 

You should visit both and decide for yourself.
author: Brian D.

description:
Yes Lombard Street is a huge tourist trap. But that doesn't mean you should totally avoid this place at all costs. Lombard Street is basically this windy, zig zaggy road that goes down a hill with some nice views of San Francisco. It's easily accessible by car or on foot. 

When I was a kid, I thought Lombard Street was this giant hill that you had to climb in SF. Many years later when I revisited this attraction, I realized you can come here and soak in all there is to see on Lombard Street and leave within about 10-15 minutes. 

I've only come here during the night time and even though you can't see the city and streets as clearly, this place is still very beautiful. You can drive your car up and down Lombard Street or just take a stroll around it. There's stairs on both sides so you don't have to actually walk along the street itself. If you prefer to walk, there's parking all around on the streets; just follow the parking rules. 

Is this the best attraction in SF? Definitely not. But is it worth checking out and showing your friends? Of course! You may even just be walking around the city and perhaps come across this gem. It's not imposing on the city at all; it's just one of those cool things that are wedged into the beautiful city.

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description: We had a memorable blast driving down the mist crooked street in America. Beautiful views going down if you're not the one driving lol. Kids enjoyed it,
author: Casey B.

description:
Lombard Street is the most famous one way street in San Francisco due to its incredibly crooked path. There are eight sharp and narrow turns that are said to make it the most crooked street in the world! The street is closed to public transportation, so the only way to drive crooked is to do it yourself (or an Uber.....but let's keep that one on the down low, lol). If you do not have access to a car you can easily visit because there is a Cable Car stop at the top of the street, making it easy for visitors to access the street. You can easily walk down some of the stairs that follow the same crazy path as the road. For those driving be advised that there are private driveways and garages at each turn, so please be respectful of those that live this crooked life daily.

Overall I recommend making a stop to take in the most crooked street in the world, it's an interesting experience and the view from the top is actually quite nice, almost as good as the view looking up at the crazy turns!
author: Brian M.

description:
Been here more than 3 times already and it's still fun and fascinating every single time haha! 

Tip for those who's never been here and is thinking of driving. DO NOT go up the hill from Lombart St. Open the map and find another way around because I will be an easier ride and trust me you don't want your car getting in traffic while it's heading uphill.

Have fun guys!
author: Ngan C.

description: I have been wanting to come see this famous crooked street. It is between Hyde and Jone Street. The exact address to start is 1070 Lombard Street, San Francisco,Ca 94109. You can get there by City bus, Cable Car, your own vehicle or a tour bus. We drove our  car there.  It was interesting to drive down this hilly and steepest street and the sharp curves to go down was kinda scary for me. Parking was kinda of bad. It was shorter than I thought it was going to take, but the scenary was to die for. I can see beautiful mansions, North beach, Chinatown and Fisherman's Wharf from top of the street. One check off my bucket list. What a visual treat
author: Julie P.

description: Fun fun fun, ride, walk, or run.!!  Don't go if your afraid of heights, I came here back in 1978?  Sister in town from NYC so had to go again!!!! Do it!!
author: Saqqara K.

description: Lombard Street is a quick but unique stop to make in San Francisco. The T stop right at the head of the street. It is interesting to see all the cars try to make their way down the street (very, very slowly). There is a pedestrian sidewalk with stairs and a railing that can guide you down the street. It took me no longer than 15 minutes to walk down and back up.
author: Priya S.

description: Drove down Lombard as a tourist would lol its a nice detour that doesn't take too long.
author: Diana R.

description:
Aside from the Golden Gate Bridge, Lombard Street with a view of Coit Tower is yet another iconic view of San Francisco! From the top of the flower-adorned hairpin turns, you can see a whole stretch of eastern SF with the Coit Tower towering over the landscape. This is simply a cool sight to stop by a see, so either park a few blocks away to continue on foot...or brave through a series of hairpin turns!

But please, don't be an obnoxious tourist by standing in the middle of the road :P
author: Jay Y.

description: A must when you have people visiting from out of town. Its easy and free. Park at the start of Lombard street and walk down the steps. During the winter the flowers are not as nice but still great views and fun thing to do. Driving it down makes me dizzy. Tourists love it here. Come during the week because on the weekends the crookedest street in world get crazy. Be mindful of the residents.
author: Theresa G.

description: Best experience.. I have been to this place multiple time s and become my stop every time . This time, parked my vehicle and went by walk. This is the must stop every one who is visiting sfo.
author: Ak N.

description: Lombard street is a  San Francisco classic tourist attraction known as the most crooked street in the world. People will line up for blocks and wait for a long time to spend a few minutes to drive down it. I think that is hardly worth it. However, walking it is ok in my opinion. You can go either way uphill or downhill, there are steps on either side but for my money I say there are enough hills in SF so why not do a little advanced planning and go downhill? Enter Lombard from the Hyde street side and walk down to the Leavenworth side. There will be tons of people taking pictures and such, but at least you can take your time and let it soak in unlike the motorists who blow through it. Also, the cable car up Hyde Street and get off on Lombard to kill two tourist birds with one stone!
author: Desmond F.

description:
Too much of a tourist trap in San Francisco, and especially to the point where it puts people's lives in danger. There are actual residents who live in the houses along this "crooked street", and I sometimes wonder how they manage to put up with this traffic every single day. No question that this is a really beautiful street along with its gardens, which are very well maintained. But if you are driving on the street, please go extremely slowly and watch out for people who may be wandering on the pavement trying to get selfies and photos of each other while putting themselves in danger. Seriously, there is no reason to rush downhill as if there is no tomorrow!

There are too many people that gather at the base of the hill and essentially block cars from getting through. I understand it's a very scenic view, but people have to learn to get out of the way when a vehicle is about to pass through. Lombard Street gets crowded in a hurry by early morning and stays that way all day. There needs to be some kind of traffic enforcement or crowd control before someone gets hurt (if it hasn't happened already!).
author: Paul N.

description:
Also known as the  crooked street in San Francisco. Everyone should experience this famous crazy, steep, eight hairpin turns over a  one-block section. You can walk it but you really need to drive down it to get the full effect!
Take a look at the very small driveways and entrances to the garages of the few people that live on this street. 
 
Cool tip , if you don't have a car to drive down this street, then ride a famous cable car and experience both. *** The Powell-Hyde cable car stops at the top of the block on Hyde Street. ***

I loved the drive down, each turn more exciting then the last. Definitely a must if your here!
author: Kelly S.

description:
First time driving down: I was with some friends showing them the city - now normally at the time my brakes squeaked for the smallest fraction of a second as I just started to brake... but here my brakes responded differently. I had to ride them all the way down and at this odd late night hour I'm sure I woke up the whole neighborhood. It was embarrassing. I look back now and perhaps its part of the reason I attend to possible brake issues sooner rather than later. 

This is a real tourist attraction. During the days - especially now when people from all over the world are traveling - this place is packed. Don't dare stop near the top to snap a photo out the window or drop your friends off while momentarily blocking traffic... Traffic enforcement will yell at you. 

A beautiful place for a photo opportunity. Beautiful and well recognized street combined with a view of the city. Take a little extra time to go out this way but make sure your brakes can handle being ridden all the way down without having your presence announced to the whole neighborhood.
author: Stefan T.

description:
Crooked & cool! Actually Lombard Street is the most crooked street in the world with its 8 sharp hair pin turns. This is cool to walk but an adventure to drive! 

It is not accessible to public transportation or shuttles so don't expect to get through this maze on a tour, cable car or bus. 

Do it the old fashioned way...throw the kiddos in the car, let the windows down, and slow roll through this beautifully landscaped puzzle of a street. 

Thank me later.
~Christy
author: Christy A.

description:
A recent write up in my local newspaper prompted me to check Yelp and see if I had written a review of this infamous brick street, and I had not!  The last time I visited SF was back in 2005 or so, just as little baby Yelp was born, so I have a lot of catching up to do as far as reviewing this magical city.

I've been down Lombard Street twice, once via a passenger in car years ago when traffic wasn't an issue (on that day, anyway) and most recently on foot where we traversed the steps, passing by quaint gardens and homes.  While the steps don't follow the exact zig zag of the street, it's still something to experience and say you've been there.  You can also get better pics of the street while on foot.

I was appalled to read some negative experiences that residents on the street have endured, from urination on door stoops, to idiots climbing on  residential rooftops to snap "better" pictures, to personal bodily attacks from the people blocking driveways and getting honked at by homeowners to move out of the way.  As the world turns, a few a-holes ruin it for the rest of us, well-behaved travelers who enjoy the area while abiding by laws and showing respect for its residents.

FACTS:
Built in 1922.  Specifically designed because the cars of the time could not make it up/down its 27-degree grade.  Gardens were added by residents in the 1950's.

OVERALL:
Definitely check it out as it's part of the city's charm.  Great views of the city can be had.  Lastly, use common sense and courtesy!
author: Vince N.

description: Fun to drive down and seems like a must do for tourists.  There was a cop at the top directing traffic and telling people to keep moving.  You can't really stop at all and try to take cool pics.   I mean you are going really slow - but they keep you moving so as to not hold up traffic.  It was cool to see and fun to drive down.
author: Becky K.

description: I was entertained by watching people drive down this street; driving it myself would create stress from all of those hairpin turns. Go early, as there are TONS of tourists come here; I went at 9:30am and it was already very crowded.
author: Lon G.

description: Fun scenic street to drive though! Not too crowded and there were people to direct traffic so we didn't have to compete to make it onto or away from the street. Good little detour as you're driving out of the city!
author: Jake A.

description: What a beautiful place to see. It's so crazy to see how whiny the roads are the the top of the hill to the bottom where the car exits. There are houses on this roads as well and it's so cool to see the cars come down this road. On this road , it not only have beautiful houses but large bushes of flowers that travel down. Very cool sight to see. When it gets busy there are traffic officers that help guide the cars to go or let pedestrian walk because it gets pretty pack on a sunny day .
author: Sally L.

description:
Couldn't help but feel a little embarrassed that I was annoyingly tresspassing into a charming street of this magical city. 

Please be pleasant and and courteous with resident and the tens of tourists that are lingering around forgetting this is where people come home to.
author: Lesley M. C.

description:
Lombard Street is a must see spoint in San Francisco. It's near Fisherman's Warf so it will probably fit your tight travel schedule.

Also, be ready for a mini hike cuz you will be going up hill (if you are walking). We got so sweety after getting there, which makes me feel like kind of an accoplishment.
author: Susanne S.

description: Walked all the way there and all the way down. Phew. Wonderful tourist spot, have to see and the flowers and houses are beautiful.
author: Nicole O.

description:
Lombard Street and Gardens are a true landmark in San Francisco that you can't miss.

We walked up from Fisherman's Wharf and it's somewhat of a feat just getting there.  Obviously many people love driving down this crooked pathway.  Just a tip~ if you're driving there is somewhat of a backup to go down.  The cable car stops directly in the center creating a road block for traffic.  Obviously it's worth the wait or walk for a beautiful view to experience Lombard.  

There are sidewalks down each side as it is a residential area.  The 'Gardens' are absolutely gorgeous.  Garden wedges creating the winding curve are filled with blooming flowers.  Make this a stop you won't regret.
author: Bethany E.

description: A must see but there are lots of people.   We actually drove it which was better than just walking.
author: Sheila D.

description:
Did the touristy thing even though we are local.  Went 2 times in 3 days.  
Lots of pedestrians!  
Make sure to drive very carefully so you don't hit anyone.  
Be very aware of your surroundings.
Plan on a long wait to drive down the street.
I recommend that if you want to avoid all the above things go at night.  
Less people at night, plus you get a great view of the Bay Bridge all lit up.
author: Deanna L.

description: From Little Italy it's a bit of a steep climb up, but my friend and I had a very fun time walking around Lombard street.  Not only were people watching the cars zig and zag their way down, the houses and flowers nearby were incredibly beautiful.  It's hard to believe this street has been here since 1850, but it's definitely a quirky feature unique to SF.
author: Emily Y.

description:
You will encounter 8 sharp turns as you make your way down with your car on Lombard St. It is known as the world's most "crooked" street!! The brick road along with all the beautiful million $$$ homes to the sides make it all worth it. The view as you come down over looking Coit Tower and San Francisco Bay is breathtaking. Definitely a must visit for every tourist to see this landmark. Make sure to take lots of photos!! Once you are down, I suggest you head to North Beach for awesome outdoor cafe and enjoy the feeling of being a San Franciscan local!

Until then, Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description:
While others think that "The Most Crooked Street in the World" is the main attraction here, I personally think it's the people who come and literally sit in the middle of the road--yes, the road where cars drive through--to get a picture.

This place is tourist central, which isn't a bad thing--it means it's worth seeing! You get tons of people taking pictures--I recently saw a girl totally get all model status with her serious expressions and fashionable wardrobe thrust against San Francisco's iconic hills and houses--as well as the funny visual of cars weaving through the narrow street that is Lombard.

You have to take a walk up and down the stairs of Lombard to really check out the cool gardens and flowers the homes have as well as get a true sense of how windy the street is. People like to gaze at the city from the top, but I personally think the view is better from below. I also think that this isn't the best place in the city to have a great view; instead, check out Twin Peaks, Billy Goat Hill, or even the 16th Avenue Tiled Steps.

As far as parking goes, I've usually found parking in the adjacent streets and just walked over; usually, it's free, but make sure that you adhere to the signs posted to avoid any fines.

A true San Francisco classic, this is a no-brainer if you don't get to come to San Francisco very often (and even if you do like me, it's still pretty awesome).
author: Tremaine E.

description: It is free to drive and/or walk through this very unique street. There are areas where tourists can stand, take pictures and not be in the way of cars driving down the street. The higher up the more beautiful the view. At the very top where its not zigzag anymore, people can catch the Powell/Hyde Cable Car and head down to the ocean where Pier 39 is located.
author: Sam N.

description:
Lombard Street in San Francisco is known as "the crookedest street in the world." It is an iconic landmark in the city that I have been looking forward to visit ever since I watched Princess Diaries in middle school. Luckily my friend's apartment was only a 15 minute walk away so this was one of the first places I visited during my trip to San Francisco!

The street looks exactly how you see it in movies and in pictures. We started at the top of the hill, where you get an amazing view of the bay, and worked our way to the bottom, where you get a great view of the crooked street. The viewing at the bottom on Leavenworth Street is perfect for getting pictures up the hill its unique zig zag lines.  The landscaping was beautiful, overflowing with beautiful flowers and colors. The houses were gorgeous, but I still can't believe that people actually live on this street - there are tourists all day every day and cars constantly coming through. 

I also discovered just how unfit I was walking up to this street, but it so worth the effort. The best photos are taken from the bottom, looking up the street. It's also entertaining to see the cars and segways trying to come down the crooked street.
author: Syyu C.

description:
I could never imagine living on Lombard Street. 

First of all, I'm pretty sure I would have to sell my soul to get a house that beautiful! Secondly, where would I park? Thirdly....all those tourists outside of my house - every. single. day. That would get tiring super fast. I used to live a block north of Hollywood Blvd, that alone drove me crazy! 

But Lombard Street really is truly incredibly beautiful. Even if it is a bit of a tourist trap. You can't visit San Francisco and not visit this street and take in the magnificent views - no way no how!

Thanks to my wonderful friend Flor I was able to visit Lombard St. on the day of my departure. She braved crazy traffic and parallel parking in order to facilitate my visit. We chose to walk down the street and stopped to take many pictures of the view along the way. There were people from all over the world and within a few minutes we had asked (and been asked) to take photos from families from several different continents.
author: Zoie H.

description:
You have to come here while in town! It's a steep & twisted road but so unique and picturesque!
Pro tip! Drive down then take photos at the bottom.
I really wished my uber driver wasn't a pain & wanted to avoid the traffic. He told me cars could not drive down, which is clearly a lie.
We were dropped off at the top and walked down. Walking down still gives you a cool perspective but driving would have been way better & faster. (Did I mention I was in heels, not a good idea)
Keep in mind this is a functioning street & intersection so be careful!
Photos at the bottom looking up the street are the best & if you turn around the views of the city are also amazing!
author: Phylicia K.

description:
Came here on my way to work because I saw the many positive reviews, it's really bad! After 8 am it's prob the busiest street in SF. It's one way so you can only go down, which makes you think it would go faster but no, it's so ridiculously crooked that you have to be really careful. Scratched my car several times running late to a business meeting (social meetings I wouldn't care so much). Ironically they put up signs "Keep off the walls" as if I try to hit the wall on purpose...
For cyclists it's also really hard, way too steep. 
On my way to work it's ok, but coming home, I'm always sweating like a mofo. 
Really can't explain its popularity, it's not even the most crooked (sic!) street in town. 
Would highly suggest to take the streets around it if you're in a hurry. Chestnut Street is totally fine, and offers plenty of parking lots.
author: Baxter S.

description: I love this street, it is so cute.  I love all the hydrangeas they look so lovely.  We had our uber driver take us around town.  He was so nice do indulge us in our little touristy outing.  This street is unique to San Francisco and a must see and ride.  I have not been back to this part of town for over 10 years and it still looks great.
author: Marisa S.

description:
Seeing beautiful postcards of San Francisco and the crooked street this was one of the first few places I wanted to go to as a kid. Now that I live in the Bay Area I take family and friends who are tourists to the city to this famous street.

Driving down this street admiring the beautiful homes on this street and wondering how they can stand living in a place where people are constantly driving and taking pictures. 

It's a fun drive on this  crooked road! Drive slowly and enjoy the pretty flowers that adorn this street. Also popular in the movie the Hulk with Eric Bana! Definitely someplace to visit as part of San Francisco!
author: Maria M.

description:
For tourists, there is some odd fascination with this winding road and somehow I've bought into it twice in my life. Shame on me.

We love things that just look ... unique. There are probably hundreds of winding roads in America, but this one apparently stands out from the rest. Well, for one thing, I guess it's extremely well kept. There are small gardens that surround the winding brick road and when there are hundreds of people standing around taking pictures of it, we feel the urge to do the same. Many people tend to drive down it, but for me, that wasn't worth the torture of waiting in line to do so on those oh so steep roads that make me feel like I'm going up a roller coaster at less than 1 mile per hour.

My recommendation ---- visit Lombard Street, but drive there and park on a nearby street. Don't waste your time driving down it. Get out of your vehicle, snap your photos from the top, sides and, preferably at the best angle, the bottom of the winding road, then leave because there isn't much else to see here. There will definitely be some detractors, but if you're a first timer in San Francisco, I think it's worth giving a 30 minute visit.
author: Chris E.

description:
A crooked street that resembles a playground slide for cars and lined with flowers? I am so there!!!  

I had a lot of fun on Lombard Street watching all of the vehicles struggle to travel from one end of the street to the other.  I was lucky enough to witness a procession of motorcycles trying to make their descent down Lombard Street.  Unfortunately, not all of the motorcycles were successful in riding down the street without tipping over.  

Not only was it an amusing sight to observe all of the cars driving down the street, it was also a great way to exercise for pedestrians like me! It was quite an incline, running up and down along Lombard street.  Highly recommend!
author: Vy N.

description: Great spot for a tourist photo full of people! It's not that easy for the photo at the top or bottom of the street to show the real curvature of the road. If you're up near Coit tower, walk to the top of Lombard Street from there and you'll see it in all it's glory. It's a fair distance away so make sure you have a good camera, the iphone camera didn't work very well.
author: Rowena B.

description: We joined one day tour in San Francisco and the tour guide told us to climb up if we could.  It required some cardio workout and it was worth it. The views were incredible and amazing but the traffic wasn't good especially on Saturday. The pedestrians constantly blocked the intersection in front of the garden so the drivers hardly moved around. It's hard to imagine for those who lived here because the traffic might be a nightmare.
author: Michelle G.

description:
