I went here on one of my trip to San Francisco for the obligatory Lombard Street visit. 
I don't know what made this place one of the "Must See's" of SF besides the fact it is a crooked street. But I guess without fail, I fell for it. So I must still promote and tell you to go here because of 2 TRUE facts that I believe:

1. You get to take some really awesome photos in front of a world famous street in San Francisco.

2. You can drive down this really awesome street. (Even though the drive is pretty short)

Questions anyone?
author: Michelle M.

description:
We were at Ghirardelli Square and knew Lombard was a few blocks away so decided to walk.  The walk is a few blocks uphill but it's not bad.  We saw the cable car and taxis around.  When we arrived, there was a long line to drive down.  There were lots of people around taking photos from the start of the street.  

We took a few photos and made our way down the path.  We stopped at a few places to take photos and it wasn't too crowded so we could get decent shots.  It's lovely with the flowers planted along the street.  Walking down the street, you can see the entrances to the homes and also the car parked in the driveways.  I would think it's a pain living here to wait a long time to get on the street to get home.

The bottom of the street was busier than the top with lots of people taking photos.  Good thing the streets around aren't very busy so people can stand in the middle and take photos.  Lombard Street is a place to see once but not somewhere I'll need to visit again next time.

After, we walked up and down the streets to our hotel on Sutter and it took close to half an hour.
author: Violet P.

description:
Walking is best to reach this spot!
Always overcrowded.
You can walk on the stairs adjacent to the crooked Street to get a feel of it.
The view is awesome from the top, you can see upto the ocean!
author: Zeba S.

description:
Another one of those well-known touristy SF landmarks that you just have see yourself! This iconic street is always bustling with high traffic from both cars and strong-willed travelers on foot! I say that because the journey to here via walking is steep, yet extremely rewarding for the beautiful and breathtaking (if you have any breath left) view! 

If you're not up for the hike through Russian Hill from Fisherman's Wharf, the Powell-Hyde cable car can easily take you straight to the top of the street on Hyde St. & Lombard St. for a mere $7.

Cars are constantly being fed down this weaving street and it's just fun to see everyone having a great time as they experience the drive. If you're driving, just remember to be courteous to the people living in the neighborhoods around it. 

As for the sidewalks, they aren't frustratingly crowded with tourists as other famous SF places are, so it's easy to obtain a perfect photo-op spot and just hang out. 

So come by, take a seat on the edge of the street's entrance, and just admire the amazing view, because it's your reward for making it all the way to this truly one-of-a-kind street!
author: Kyrie S.

description: Beautiful street full of pretty flowers and houses. Been here a few times before. Best time for pictures is early morning or afternoon but it can be really busy. Best time for less traffic is say is late evening. It's not as beautiful for pictures but still beautiful to see
author: Gracie N.

description:
We caught a number 45 bus along Union to Russian Hill at Hyde Street. A short walk along Hyde gave us excellent views until we got to the top of Lombard. Cable cars run in both directions on Hyde and how people are not hurt I will never know. If they aren't hanging off the cable car with one arm they are walking in front of traffic trying to take the perfect shot. The best shot of Lombard is at the bottom standing in the middle of the pedestrian crossing. You need to wait until there are no cars travelling down AND make sure you don't step out under the wheels of cars coming up the straight bit of Lombard.
Walking down Lombard is best done by the steps but if you are careful you can walk into the road for the odd shot.
author: Sue L.

description:
Must-see place when you're around SF!
Although parking can be pain in the ass, I think it's worth checking it.
It gets really windy, as well.
Hyde Street is the top of the crookedest street 
Leavenworth Street is the bottom of it.
I would suggest parking along Hyde Street then walk down the stairs to get to the bottom of it.
Great view of the city when you're on top!
Lots of tourist especially in Leavenworth St, taking selfie pics haha
Plus, you can even drive this street!
Great for photo opt!
author: Laramae E.

description:
We biked this! Awesome!!

No problem competing with the cars as they were happy for us to be infront!
We were slower so they had a chance to take photos!
author: Rain B.

description:
So, I've been visiting a lot of touristy places lately.  Why?  Well, when you've been meeting a lot of transplants and you tell them you haven't been to here and there in the city, their reaction makes you wonder why you've been stuck under a rock for so long.  I've been living here in the city for 20+ years and my only interaction with places like the crooked street is from news articles or postcards.  Like, yes friend from out of state, you should check out the crooked street...its crooked and like not straight and uhh... No, I haven't actually gone there but whatevs.  

There's a long line of cars waiting to drive down this street, crowds of people at the top and bottom snapping photos, and fools like me walking on the street even though there's a sign that clearly states, "Man Walking inside Red Circle with a Slash".  After I walked half way down the road and snapped my photo, I was over it.  It would be awesome if I could rent a bubble soccer ball and roll down this street.

Bucket list, check.
author: Linda N.

description:
If you like hills, stairs, cars, flowers, zigzagging lines, traffic cops and crowds, then Lombard Street is your place.

Seriously though, it's such an iconic part of San Fran that your basically need to see it just for the sake of saying that you were there.  Whether or not you feel into the whole ridiculous selfie category thing is another story but the location definitely provides some interesting views.

Weekends here get pretty crowded with people and cars and traffic cops direct both foot and vehicle traffic to help alleviate the pandemonium that would surely ensue.  They do a pretty good job too.

So if you aren't afraid of stairs and hills and a little trekking, and being a tourist, do yourself a favor and at least check out this iconic place once for some pretty nice views and to check it off your "been there, done that." list.
author: Jeff S.

description:
I've been on a lot of roads but this one just doesn't compare to most.  First, it's too curvy. I couldn't believe how challenging it was to crank the wheel to the right, and then immediately to the left. Even with the aid of modern technology like power steering I found it a chore to steer. Heck, the curves can't even turn one direction like NASCAR!

Second, it's too steep. I had to ride the brakes all the way down. There wasn't even a chance to get the tachometer over 1500 RPMs or get out of first gear.

Last, there are way too many people. They act like this is some sort of tourist attraction or something.


Avoid this road. With the millions of miles of roads in this country you should be able to find a straighter, flatter, and faster one.
author: Travis B.

description:
L-looks like you must visit this street
O- out of the car or walking up & down the street, this won't disappoint
M- many people from all ages, come and visit
B- because this is an iconic street after all 
A- are you ready to see this must-see attraction?
R- ready your cameras 
D- drive or walk- and lets go
author: Jordan L.

description:
On a recent visit to San Francisco, I found myself here at Lombard Street... once on purpose and once by accident.  Though the Powell-Hyde cable car drops passengers off at the crest of this Russian Hill area to partake in this tourist attraction, I relied on my own man-power to trek purposefully up the steep grade of this street for a few obligatory photos.  If you choose to walk, be sure to wear appropriate, non-skid footwear to safely gain access.

This one-block, eight-hairpin-turn section of Lombard Street, created in the 1920's to accommodate cars that could not maneuver the original 27% grade, is a picaresque sight for any tourist.  I particularly enjoyed the view from the bottom of the block, taking in views of the shrubbery and hydrangeas not yet in bloom (April) as well as sweeping views of East SF and Coit Tower.  Tourists were abound, standing in the middle of the street, selfie sticks and all, to gain their coveted photos.  Traffic police in the area did well to keep the cars moving down winding road as well as manage some of the more obstinate tourists who would not move for the cars trying to pass by.   

My second unintentional visit occurred while following a GPS to get back to my hotel.  Driving through the turns of this block was certainly an experience, but I am glad I had the opportunity to spend some time walking around and taking in the sights prior to.  The posted 5mph sign was strictly followed mostly due to the crowds that slow traffic.  I did marvel at the skill it must take for residents of this area to turn into their driveways from these curves.  

I'm glad I had the opportunity to check out this famed sight of San Francisco but having seen it now, would probably pass by on future visits to the city.  A perfect once-and-done kind of activity for the SF tourist.
author: Ashley P.

description: Tourist trap.  Total tourist trap; however, a fun one considering its uniqueness.  Have I ever driven on it? No. I get anxiety just going downhill or parking uphill.  Does it look fun? Yes, most definitely.  Maybe one day I will be brave it. For now, I enjoy just standing at the bottom marveling at the intensity.
author: Jaymie Lynn S.

description:
One of the must sees in the bay area! Lombard street is located just west of Fisherman's Wharf and up the hill from Ghirardelli Square. Our hotel was located a few blocks from the bottom of Lombard street, so we took a leisurely stroll to check it out after getting some lunch at the wharf. Views from both, the bottom and top were beautiful! I thought about taking our rental car through, but there were so many people and just didn't seem worth it since we had already walked up and down the area. We also took a cable car from the bay, up to the top of Lombard street and to downtown SF, so were able to get another few pics along the way. A gorgeous part of the city that resides in Russian Hill, can't wait to return again soon!

Best,
Charlie
author: Charlie K.

description: What a delusion! Obviously we wanted to visit Lombard street when we were on a vacation in San Francisco as everyone was raving about it everywhere. It is recommended to get there on foot as car traffic is enormous all around this area almost all the time. We marched up on the very steep streets to get to the top of this oh-so-famous street, and I have to tell you it was a gigantic delusion. Cars are coming down continuously and the street itself if extremely crowded by people so it is impossible to make a decent photo. But the main problem is that even if there was nobody you couldn't manage to make a nice photo of the street simply because there isn't a spot from which you can catch the curve. Simply nothing can be seen by standing on the street level. If you have a drone you  might be able to do nice shots otherwise forget it. Flowers are lovely there though - but you can find gorgeous flowers all over the city. All in all a waste of time!
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Man I love this iconic street. I've been here a few times and I can never seem to get annoyed of it. It's such a beautiful stretch of road, that it can't be beat. If you're visiting SF for the firs time, then you better find a way to come here and walk this sucker and even drive it if you can. I'd advise finding parking near the top, then walking to the bottom, then walking to the top and then driving down! Whew! 

There are are also some very beautiful homes on this road that probably cost a fortune and a half, but then again, even a one bedroom shack in SF can cost half a million. It's that crazy that this packed city has so many people wanting to live there! 

Still, this street is legendary and worth every second of your time. You'll have so much fun with the zig and the zag!
author: Benny H.

description: Lombard St., also known by its popular nickname, "The Crookedest Street in the World," is a fun attraction to visit, whether you drive, ride or walk down the block long street.  It's fun to watch cars approach, some with trepidation as they peak over the edge, basically at the point of no return, and take the plunge.  Walkers are full of laughs and giggles as they watch the cars and each other, snapping endless photos.  Maybe the most fun was watching a Segway tour traverse the curves.  You've got to go down Lombard St. at least once but more than once is even more fun.
author: Will T.

description: You've got to see this when in San Francisco! Quite a vertical climb. We parked on a side street nearby and hiked up to the top a block over, and then walked down Lombard Street. Amazing that this is an actual functional street with homes! A family actually backed out their car from their garage as we walked by. Tons of tourists, and I don't see how anyone living here can get any privacy. Fortunately, this is a public attraction...so best part... NO ENTRY FEE!!!! It's free!  :-)
author: Karen D.

description: A must see if you're in San Fran! Try taking your own car or an uber so you can drive down it! You can also take a cable car, but it was awesome being able to actually say we drove down it.
author: Ashley M.

description: A waste of time. We waited in traffic for almost an hour to see this. There are so many other amazing things to see in San Francisco. This place is flooded with tourists. Ugh!
author: Andrew M.

description: wait, we just stare at a street here? lmao have no idea why i came. there's nothing spectacular about this place, it's just a damn road. people hype up places like this and i cannot stand it, but oh well i'm the one that still ends up going to them and seeing what the hype is all about.
author: Anthony M.

description: This place is a nightmare. the street was never built for tourist and now the tourist have ruined it. It is horrible to see such destruction and rudeness from visitors who do not pay anting o drive down it and stand in the middle of the street for a selfie. Such a waste of time and so depressing to see the destruction of this once beautiful area.
author: Archers T.

description: Not that exciting . Flooded with tourist, one big traffic jam, and not that much to see. Don't waste your time, lots of better places in SF.
author: Ellie G.

description: Awesome street view. I guarantee you have never seen anything like it. I could either walk through or drive. Enjoy it
author: katarina p.

description: Very interesting driving experience on this street. Make turns, make turns......, and make turns.
author: Maruko X.

description:
Who didn't read about this in your history books and in the Guinness Book of World Records when you were a kid?  I sure did!

If you have the privilege of driving while in San Francisco, get a map, look for Lombard Street and go!  It's free, it's famous, it holds a great view of the city and is iconic San Francisco.  

Once I drove past this little park and then boom!  It hit me before I was ready.  There's no real warning. You drive across the tiny intersection and start your descent.  Who cares about the drivers behind you.  Drive slow, take in the experience, enjoy the view and feel the curves, just like you would the small of your girl's back and the side of her hips.   Enjoy the moment, because it passes fast. 

Once you get to the bottom, look for street parking in the area and you can go back and walk it.  There are straight steps on on both sides of Lombard street that you can walk up.  The the top and the top half of the curvy street have the better views of the skyline than the bottom half.  I went at night so the details weren't as visible, but the lights of the city... just breathtaking.  

If you're not driving in the city, take the cable car to get here. Walk a little into the curves to get better pictures.  There aren't any restrooms nearby and don't leave your trash. Don't be disruptive as people live here (as much as you might feel sorry for them and the foot traffic here, these houses are worth a pretty penny).  

Biking?  A little bumpy but doable.  Skateboards?  Not allowed.  If you're just driving it, then it only takes 2 minutes.  If you want to walk it and take some pictures, allow about 20-30 minutes.  

Visiting San Francisco on a budget?  Visiting San Francisco while not on a budget?  Put it on both must see lists.
author: Howie C.

description:
A very crooked street (which I'm honestly not sure what the purpose of it even was), and some well-maintained gardening along the way, but honestly, that's about it! This little street is way too hyped, and is kind of difficult to get to because it is surrounded by REALLY steep hills.

Best views are from the bottom, however, so in terms of logistics, you might be better off taking the Powell-Hyde cablecar to the top and getting off. There's a pedestrian staircase on the side of the street so you can walk to the bottom for photo ops, but not worth it in my opinion.
author: Tashnuva E.

description:
Look at you, with all those curves, and me with no brakes. 

Lombard Street is a must for anyone renting/owning a means of travel that has at least one wheel to it. It's a quick stop that typically doesn't have too much traffic beyond foot traffic and is something you can enjoy on your way around town. If you're able to find parking, you can walk up and down either side to get some different views. From above, you get a great shot of the north end of San Francisco, with Coit Tower standing prominently in the distance. From below, you get to see the rows of cars come down the winding road at about 3-20mph as they whip around the turns. It's fun, it's different, it's free, and it only takes about 15 minutes to experience it and you'll move along without regret.
author: Chris M.

description:
Amazing experience ! Lovely view in San Francisco ! It was a little difficult to find parking to I would just recommend driving down the street and take pictures while in the car  
Have fun !
author: Marilin S.

description:
Mongo watch cars go left. 
Mongo watch cars go right. 
Mongo watch cars go left. 
Mongo watch cars go right. 
Mongo watch cars go left.

I went there to take some photos to announce that I am in SF.
I think that is all the purpose of Lombard street,Taking photos.
The photos from downhill is much nicer.
Once you done with Lombard street,

author: Hani G.

description: Great landmark. My friend and I walked down Lombard St. There are too many cars heading down, it is best to walk down.
author: Christine G.

description:
The crookedest street in the world with eight-hairpin turns and a buttload of automobile/pedestrian traffic.  Huzzah!

I've been down Lombard Street millions of times as both a passenger in a vehicle and as one of the smarter ones that walk down the street.  It's all just gorgeous views and sweet-smelling flowers here.  Driving down this street is a real nail-biter since you're worrying about your brakes and running people over the whole time so it kind of takes away from the experience but if you walk it, it's actually nice.  San Francisco weather is always gorgeous and that crisp cool air makes the steps a walk in the park.  It's photobomb central at the bottom of the hill since everybody wants a selfie of them blocking traffic and such.  Good times.

The houses that actually line this one-block street are gorgeous as well.  I wonder how they deal with the traffic?
author: Joyce W.

description: Absolutely lovely. Best way to design an extremely sloped street is to make it curvy so it slows cars down and people get to enjoy a gorgeous view of the city. I recommend to drive down this street during the day and at sunset!
author: Ava R.

description:
OMG I LOVED driving down this crooked road in the car. It's short- takes like 5 min to drive in but it's SO crooked  I thought it was hilarious to drive down. The people in my car were scared of heights so it was 1000x funnier when they're screaming as we drive down. 

Tons of people taking pics from the bottom and you can see them as you drive them. One way street down. Super narrow and sharp turns. Never seen anything like this before. 

First time tourists in SF- Drive down at least once. It's crazy to me how crooked this street is. There's also a couple like 90 degree hills near it...seriously thought I was on a roller coaster ride.
author: Jessie H.

description:
So tourist but so fun!

I always try to drive Lombard Street when I am in SF. 

Takes a minute to zig and zag your way down but I always enjoy doing it. 

The wait can be long but it is worth a try if you never did it before.
author: Kevin W.

description:
It's more of a novelty - but, that doesn't make it any less awesome.

I'm proud (or maybe I shouldn't be proud) to say I drove down this street! After many years of honing my driving skills in the obstacle course that is Miami, I was pretty proud when I made it down this street with no incidents. Can you believe people actually LIVE on this street? That's gotta be the worst...

"Hey babe...there's 2000 tourists driving down the street again...it's going to be tough to go out and grab some milk - since it will take me 45 minutes to make it down the street in the car." -- OK, I know SF is walkable, so this convo likely doesn't happen.

So...it's free. It takes a few minutes to snap a photo from the bottom and a few more minutes if you decide to be one of the brave ones to drive down the street. It's totally worth it to stop by if you're visiting.
author: Blue A.

description: Pretty flower garden on zic zac driving way. But very heavy traffic around the street. If you want to take a picture of flowers then you should park block away. Its impossible to take a picture if you drive down there lol
author: Ji P.

description:
In a city where being straight is boring, Lombard stands out as the most famous street cause roads are like women ... the more curves, the more exciting they are. Anyone can drive a straight line, but it takes a tourist to handle curves. Here's the straight dope on the short and winding road that leads to your tour.

Cable Car - Recommended!
 * Take the Powell-Hyde Cable Car which stops at the top of the hill
 * Leisurely, walk down the sidewalk along the 8 switchbacks
 * Best photo spot is from Leavenworth St. at the bottom looking up
 * Bring some water for the walk back up Lombard Street

Driving - "Fun" at least once
 * Be prepared for up to an hour-long queue if you come from Van Ness
 * Instead take Union, turn onto Hyde and right onto Lombard ... wheee!
 * There are no left turns from Hyde onto Lombard (go around)
 * Best times: Before noon ... especially early before 10 am
 * Worst times: After 3 pm ... especially in the summer
 * Speed limit: 5 MPH
 * Some steep & busy parking on Lombard is below Leavenworth
 * Or find parking on Larkin, Hyde, or nearby streets
 * Pay attention to all parking rules cause there are hefty fines
 * Many nearby streets have very restricted parking in summer
 * IMPORTANT: SF will close Lombard from auto traffic 4 weekends in 2014
 * No cars on weekends between June 21 and July 13 (including July 4)

Walking - Wear comfy shoes
 * When driving/parking is too crazy (summer) try walking to Lombard
 * Park in a garage or lot at Fisherman's Wharf & walk up Hyde Street
 * It is 6 uphill blocks from Ghiradelli Square or Hyde Street Pier
 * It is about 12 blocks from Pier 39

Some quick facts:
 * Only 1 block of Lombard (between Hyde & Leavenworth) has curves
 * There are 8 sharp switchbacks down that 1 block
 * The switchbacks & brick-paved street were constructed in 1922 to deal with the 27-degree slope
 * Lombard had 2-way traffic until 1939
 * Sidewalks on both sides have about 250 steps
 * During peak hours, 350 cars per hour drive down Lombard
 * Tour buses were banned in 1980
 * At least 4 legal attempts have been made to close the street to traffic
 * Since 2001, eastbound traffic has been limited on holidays/summer
 * Real people live in the houses and condos along the curvy street
 * In 2008, a 1-bedroom condo (925 sq ft) listed at $1,150,000
 * Chrysanthemums in the flowerbeds bloom in Spring/Summer
 * The Lombard Hill Improvement Association maintains the gardens

Lombard Street is the most famous road in California's most beautiful city, so, when your vacation throws you a curve, celebrate every zig & zag and then stop to take a few pics.
author: Michael S.

description: Nicely landscaped. The walk up to Lambord Street is definitely a cardio workout, and it is highly recommended. It is worth the hike, because the view at the top its spectacular.
author: Greg I.

description:
I've been here a couple times - always taking my friends who had never been here before and it was always a good experience.

Parking was hard to find. There was parking both from the top of the street to the bottom. If you are parking, make sure to park correctly! If you're parking uphill, just remember to face your wheels and think up, up, and away (from the curb).

Overall, this place didn't get too crowded but it could. There was one time when I went and there was way too many people and just decided to pass by it. Driving on this street was fun in my opinion. Not everyone could say that they've driven on the steepest street in the USA!

I've always appreciated the architecture of San Francisco homes. There were some beautiful homes on this street. There was one particular one that I thought was beautiful with purple flowers growing on it. If you go here, I'm sure you'll know exactly what I was talking about.

This was definitely a landmark you have to experience!
author: Aj C.

description:
I'm glad I was able to witness the "crookedest street in the world."

We arrived from the top of Lombard Street to do all the touristy stuff. Like taking pictures of the view and taking selfies with the view. I wanted to take a picture of the whole street itself so me and my boyfriend and best friend decided to drive down it. They advise you to drive 5mph down the street because it is very steep and has 8 curves.

If you ever plan on visiting SF, make this onto your bucket list.
author: Sophia V.

description:
I'm gonna put this here

Do you REALLY need a review for Lombard Street?

And then I think... I'm writing a review for Lombard Street......but that's alright.

Lombard Street, the second crookediest street in the world (the other being Vermont Street in San Francisco) (ps bet you didn't know that, did you? ;) ), is iconic, as you have a beautiful view from the bottom, with some of the (remaining) flowers. You can also partake in actually driving on it, making sure you don't hit people, edges, other cars, etc.

But what is bad about Lombard Street? If you want to go straight, there are a lot of  tourists and asian people who don't know you don't stand in the middle of the street versus a car. And you're too ignorant to realize you're blocking a lot of people because the whole world revolves around you. I'm done :P

There's a lot of build up (traffic) on the hill leading up to Lombard Street. So San Franciscans usually get around this by any means necessary :P Be careful and enjoy your pictures!
author: Raymond L.

description: Worth a look at another one of San Francisco's iconic landmarks but aside from a few picture opportunities and a walk up/diwn the paths either side of the street it won't take up a huge chunk of your visit. Looking forward to driving down the street in morning to get a different perspective.
author: Mark L.

description:
First time here! Pretty awesome overall. VERY touristy and busy so prepare yourself for rude behavior, lots of foreigners and tourists, selfie sticks & GoPros in the eye, no or very little concept of patience and common courtesy and you should be all good.

Brick road and stairs are very well maintained it is super easy getting around. Parking officials are there at most times of the day to direct foot and car traffic properly and maintain order with a side of chaos.
author: Christine G.

description:
Googling famous attractions in SF will result in Lombard street for some of the top ten spots.

I thought it would be funny for my auntie Tracy (cute little Jewish lady who is very loud and vocal) to drive through Lombard street since she is known for her impeccable driving, as evidenced by my grandma who holds on to the handles on the roof of the car whenever Tracy is driving. You always wear your seatbelt when Tracy drives!

It was stop and go all along the path, not because of traffic, but because it was steep, winding, and narrow. We picked the perfect person to drive! The things that flew out her mouth, hilarious! Obscenities, curse words, dry humor and such! Including the fact that some gardener was trimming the bushes along the narrow winding path of Lombard street. Seriously?! Who does that?! Gardener, you cray!!!

There are tons of tourists on top of the hill and beneath it, marveling at its voluptuous curves. 

If we had more time, we would have taken turns driving down Lombard street. Who can get down the fastest?! Haha
author: Stacy W.

description:
People get off on a crooked street? Really? I was obligated to take my out of towners here, and even me as a local was shocked at the number of tourists here. The homes that line Lombard are probably hitting near $2 million, but I'm not sure you could pay me to live here. Traffic at all hours, noise, no privacy. And hey people, I know you're trying to take pics, but how about NOT blocking the intersections at the bottom of the hill? Thanks.

If you'all wanna see a special street, I recommend the intersection of Hyde and Turk in the Tenderloin. There are lovely characters lurking at the 4 corners there, and it's a real adventure and treat trying to sidestep the human waste the lines the poor concrete. You may even witness a real drug deal in progress.
author: Kris P.

description: Very packed just to go up the hill to Lombard Street. But had to see the crooked street is a must.
author: Andrea E.

description:
I guess. 

I mean yeah it's something to see to say you've seen it... But really it's just a very curvy street. There are sh*t tons of people there during the day doing the tourist thing and taking pictures. I actually feel (only slightly) bad for the rich folks that live here because, ya know, privacy! But then again.... you were probably well aware what you were getting yourself into when you bought a house on one of the the most famous streets in America. 
Here's a tip: there are better photo ops at the intersection below the curves.
author: Laurie A.

description:
I've driven down this street a few times there seems to be a lot of left and right turns involved :-). I wouldn't want to be one of the residents living along this street it must be kinda annoying at times. I've heard rumors that they were going to close it down to traffic so you can't drive down it unless you're an actually resident I don't know if that's true, but it would be a shame if they did since its such a popular attraction maybe they could charge a toll to offset the cost of the landscaping and street maintenance. 

Everyone should experience it once just to say they did.
author: Dave O.

description:
Lombard Street is cool; VERY COOL. Driving down this street was very interesting. You are pretty much parallel to the street and straight down; maybe 67 degrees down. WOW. If you are not careful you would certainly do some damage to your car. Going zig zag was fun and did I say COOL; VERY COOL.

Lombard Street was on my To Do List while in San Fran. I am glad I had this opportunity to experience this. I don't know if the streets leading to or around Lombard Street is where the car chase scene in "Bullitt" was filmed, but it was one hell of a ride going up and down the streets. Another cool thing to experience.

Overall, "do it"; "just do it". It is a fun ride. Remember be careful; the sides of the walls of the road had plenty of car markings. Also, this area is a residential area, so be nice and considerate.
author: Billy V.

description:
There are landmarks that you MUST go when you're visiting SF. For example, Golden Gate Bridge, Fisherman's Wharf, Twin Peaks, and HERE!

I recently took my visiting relatives here as part of a SF day tour. As the most crookedest street in the world, you can drive down the curves or walk down the sides. We took photos at the bottom of the hill with the street behind us, which looks really pretty. You can also see the Alcatraz Island down the left side of the street. There's also parking available on the streets. Usually you can find a spot available since most people park take photos then leave. Then we, as in I, drove down the street very slowly. The houses are gorgeous! Next we went to Fisherman's Wharf, it's reallllly close by.

Cable car also passes by the top of the hill.
author: Winnie T.

description: i actually have a question. where along the one of the stair cases going up to Coit tower is the small Arch way in the wall, it is now covered up by overgrowth, its along the path and i believe this is an electrical box in front of it... thank you
author: linda s.

description:
Most any travel guide will tell you this is a must do. And it was so fun to experience this street that over the course of one block you will encounter 8 hairpin turns and extremely windy turns down a sharp downhill. 
It was designed by Carl Henry and built in 1922. It's original intent was to reduce the hill's natural 27% grade which was too steep for most vehicles. It is a one-way street going downhill and is paved with red bricks.
If you have a car - drive it! Or take the cable car that stops at the top of the hill.
author: Kim K.

description: How fun was this!! My husband and I drove down Lombard street and it was so beautiful to see the houses and the pretty flowers. It does get very crowded because everyone wants to take pictures, drive down the street or video tape but I'm glad we got to experience it :)
author: Christina E.

description:
Came here to witness the crookedest streets in the world and it was awesome!

Design: Originally, the hill had a 27% grade, which was too steep for cars. So in 1922, Clyde Healy designed the street with eight tight hairpin turns and the grade was reduced to 16%.The two-way street eventually turned into one-way downhill only street in 1939.

Personally, one of the best parts about Lombard Street is the PROCESS of getting to the top of the block (intersection of Lombard St. / Hyde St.). I started from the intersection of Lombard St. / Columbus Ave and slowly walked my way up to the Leavenworth St. ... And once you are actually on the top (Hyde St.), the view was breathtaking.

Initial D in real life ... condensed in one block!
author: Luke L.

description:
I recently visited San Francisco for the fourth time and what can I say, you have to visit Lombard.  It's beautiful, fun to walk, and a great place to take pictures of the street itself and the city.  I know, it's touristy.  But it's touristy for a reason.  Always make it a "must see".

This time they had the street closed, so it was fun to walk down the street itself with worrying about being bumped by a car.  I've also driven down it and that's fun too.
author: Ron M.

description:
The ultimate reward of visiting Lombard Street comes when you start at the bottom and walk up. Aside from the awesome workout, the view from the top is amazing. It turns into a pretty intense workout, so the "reward" I mentioned is more about the feeling of accomplishment than anything else.

I can't imagine living on this street. The constant pedestrians would drive me crazy, but I guess you know what you're getting into when you write a check for seven figures (I assume) to buy one of these homes.

I've never seen anything like it and visiting once is one of those San Francisco things that you have to do when you're here.
author: David K.

description:
This is a very tourist-y spot but while in SF, why not?!

I would recommend walking there because there are so many tourists most of the time. If you're driving be careful of all of the pedestrians. But that's not your only worry going down. The slightly steep and curvy street plus the slow pace make it an experience. I mean, why else would so many people go through the trouble. 

The view from the top of Lombard street is beautiful. You can see the street and a variety of buildings that would make a great pic. At the bottom the view is just as lovely. The flowers through the whole street, as well as the cars going down. Usually you can get a pretty awesome picture of some nice cars going down. Definitely insta worthy if you get a good shot!
author: Christine N.

description:
My 14 year old brother sums it up perfectly: "there are more tourists here than flowers." 

Accurate assessment, young chap. 

#notworththewait
author: Diya L.

description:

After reaching the bottom, I started to calm down. It was very scenic with flowers and people snapping pictures left and right! I guess one of these days we can play crazy driver.... 10 points for running over pedestrians! I kiddding! Yeah, I know that was bad..... it's a fun experience though. Getting up to that street is a total different story. Don't really like driving up hills. Just make sure you have a well maintenance car, good tires and brakes!
author: John T.

description: This place is a tourist magnet. Tourist everywhere, all up in everyone's driveway. You feel a little bad for the people who live on the street, but then again I think they know what to expect. After the picnic at the presidio we decided to take a small detour and drive down the crooked street. My daughter got a kick out of how curvy it was. I am sure this was not the last trip down this road.

description:

There is a lot of people walking around with selfie sticks so I don't know if that works to get good pictures but I doubt it, as the only interesting pictures would be aerial shots. description:

author: Jannie M.

description:

author: Babar K.

description: It's was a cool experience to drive down Lombard St.  main point of interest in my opinion watch for all the idiots who can't read nor under stand the picture signs stating do not walk on the street.
author: Cory L.

description: Nice view from the top. Recommend driving down which you get the full crooked experience than just waking down the steps.
author: Hoku L.

I whined. I almost cried. I walked up the streets backwards. author: Kendra C.

description: So apparently every  single tourist was here at the exact same time we were lol.  It's  neat enough to do at least once in your life. Driving down it was worth the wait but pedestrians are everywhere and it was a little sketchy. Hiking up would be great cardio. The view from the top was interesting  but people and thier selfie sticks were pretty rude. Recommended for sure
author: Keith F.

description: So cool to drive down this road, a lot of tourist and if you do the walk down can get some great pictures. Would highly recommend as one of the touristy things to do, plus gives you a good view of how the streets of SF are setup, the up and down hills. Don't forget to take pictures when your at the bottom gives you a good perspective of Lombard Street.
author: N And N K.

description:
This is touristy.
I was touristy.
Match made in heaven.

My original plan was to take an Uber down the street.
My original ORIGINAL plan was to rent a car and drive it myself.
My original original ORIGINAL plan was to drive from NJ and take my own car down.
My original original original ORIGINAL plan was to scrap all of my original plans and walk the street like the other 477 other people there at any given time.

Whatever your plan may be, my advice is to follow my triple +1 original plan and get near the street (walk, bike, car) and walk it.  You can watch the traffic slowly crawl down like a mesmerizing lava flow of molasses and take a few pictures and/or videos along the way.

You will encounter a few selfie sticks with varying angles, and you will accidentally find yourself in the background of no fewer than two pictures taken be people you do not know.

Whatever method you use to get there and however you choose to commemorate your visit, it is worth the trip.  

Kudos to the people that have houses on this street...you have an awesome address, but I imagine departing from and returning to your house amongst thousands and thousands of tourists every day gets old at some point...
author: Tyler R.

description: A little touristy but always fun to drive down.  Took the kids down for the first time and they thought it was cool.
author: Jeff D.

description:
The best time to come here and drive the lombard street is early morning no traffic no long line of  cars waiting to try driving down the crookedest street in the usa??

author: Roland C.

description: Officers will direct traffic, and it can get quite busy or closed entirely. May want to check before heading over.
author: Kimberly H.

Holy Canoli! 
This place is a legit TOURIST TRAP!

author: Camille C.

description: Lombard Street: a famous tourist attractions in San Fran. and a must see once. We had beautiful weather so the views were amazing and believe it or not, not as crowded as I thought it would be. The flowers were still in bloom and the street was beautiful. The walk and steps are fine if you like exercising, which I do. We took the cable cars to Lombard, and then walked down through the street to the Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Melody K.

description:
It is a beautiful street with spectacular gardens.  But the traffic is impossible.  A constant stream of cars going down Lombard from Hyde Street.  Parking is even worse.  It would be a lot more fun to walk down and enjoy the street, but then you gotta walk back up to your car unless you took the bus or cab or Uber - and it's steep on the way back up. author: Doctor G.

description: READ THIS REVIEW: The hour wait is worth it to take amazing photos and to see a great view of the city and the tower on a hill. It's a really touristy place, so it's not best to just pass through. Walking past there is no line, as the line is only for cars with heavy traffic around the area.
author: Max T.

description: Cmon it's the smallest, most turned street block  in America.  Big time touristy place, surrounded by one way streets with no left or return turns depending on block.  Trust your GPS on how to get there, have your cameras ready and don't expect to park close by..
author: Paul F.

description:
Lombard Street is famous for being a crooked street. There are also a lot of beautiful flowers planted along the road. People actually live on the street. I cannot imagine how much it costs to own a home on that road. You need to walk up steep hills to get to it. description: I haven't been here for years and I must say its good being back. Yes, parking really is a bummer, but what can you expect, this place like others are very touristic.
author: Heather T.

description: A place where you don't have to pay to enjoy the beautiful scenery in San Francisco.! Lombard Street is pretty amazing
author: Stephanie R.

description:
Recommended to anyone who travels to SF. I was initially supposed to take a little Yellow Car (see prior review) down this, but didn't have time. We ended up visiting at another time.

It is very pretty and a neat place to visit. There were A LOT of tourists (myself included) as it was the weekend. If you have time while you're in SF though check it out.

We walked straight down to the pier after this, it's not to far of a walk at all.
author: Willard J.

description: A must see in San Francisco! Beautiful view, pretty landscape and you can drive the the windy street or walk parallel to it on the sidewalk.
author: Andrea H.

description:
Lombard Street stretches from the Presidio east into Telegraph Hill.  This review is for the zig-zaggy part of Lombard Street only, which is located between Hyde and Leavenworth Streets.  This stretch of Lombard Street is one of the crookedest streets in the world and one of San Francisco's major tourist attractions.

Go during a non-peak time (e.g. in the morning and not during the weekends) since the road and adjacent intersections will be less crowded and photographs will turn out better as well.  The zig-zaggy part of Lombard Street consists of eight extremely sharp turns.  It's only one-way: downhill (east).  The speed limit is 5 mph.  Any car is free to drive down it.  It's just like any other road in the neighborhood, except for the steep turns and all the tourists of course.

Lombard Street is lined with houses and is nicely decorated and landscaped.  On either side of the street are steps, so you can walk it.  Photos look good taken from the top, bottom, and on the street.  The street is still quite steep even after it crosses over Leavenworth St.  You can see down into North Beach, Telegraph Hill, and Coit Tower from the intersection of Lombard and Leavenworth.

A cable car line stops at the top of the hill at Hyde and Lombard.  Other than that, you can drive or walk right to it.  Free street parking spaces are all over the neighborhood if you can find an open one.
author: Daniel B.

description:
This is a very famous street,  In season it is definitely Postcard ready with its many curves and flowers filling the medians.  There are always cars winding their way down.  

If you just want to see it and are on foot.  The view is better from below.   You can see the whole thing better.   

The top can be reached by climbing or by cable car.  The top has nice views of north beach and Coit tower.  The street looks nice.  It's worth the climb but view of the street is better from bellow. 

Tip: come late spring through early fall when the flowers are blooming.     In winter it isn't very pretty.
author: Mark B.

description:
Of course there's a place to review Lombard Street! The most popular street in San Francisco, Lombard is famous for its crooked and narrow, winding street. Cars line up from all directions just to be able to drive down Lombard Street. It's a steep drive up, especially while you're waiting in line and slowly inching forward, so definitely be careful! 

I believe the first time I came across this street, I was completely charmed and enamored. It was different from anything I had ever seen! Now that I've seen it so many times, it's become more of a landmark and a must visit, especially if you're with relatives who have never been. I would suggest parking and walking down the street yourself because of traffic!
author: Tiffany C.

description: Hey, the view is magnificent, it wasn't overly crowded (by foot), and the cops stationed there to see the cars through were very kind and kept things moving smoothly. I can see why people love coming to this spot, and I'm glad that I finally made it myself.
author: Kristen T.

description: Walked here from my hotel which was about a mile away. Those hills really get you! It was more of a hike than a walk lol. When we finally made it was full of tourist which made it kinda hard to get good pictures but oh well it's a tourist attraction. Climbed all the way to the top it wasn't too difficult the stairs have rails and the steps are small. The gardens are absolutely gorgeous. My mom and I loved it. It was worth the hike!
author: Bri G.

description:
Growing up in San Francisco, you sometimes take local landmarks for granted.  I  have to say the view from the top of this street is breathtaking.  You can see coit tower, the bay bridge and the new bay bridge.  You get a really good view  of the streets and hills of San Francisco.   Walking down this street seems easy and it is.  Waling back up is an extreme challenge.  Yes i know i need to start working out again, but boy, was this a workout!  

I hope the make the street into Candyland again!  i remember they made it into Candyland a few years ago.  I would recommend coming here on a weekday because parking around there is much easier!
author: Belinda C.

description: This place was cool to go and visit but nothing spectacular! Lots of tourists getting in the way(me being 1 of them I assume) of pictures. You don't get a clear view of what is going on so you have to walk around to get a good picture. Not a must to do but go if you are trying to kill sometime.
author: J.C. F.

description: Yawn
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Touristy, but beautiful street that I could just imagine how difficult it must be to drive down it.  However, it is completely fascinating to visit in spite if the tourist crowds it draws.  Take the cable car to Lombard and Hyde and work your way to Leavenworth St.  If you don't get hit by a car, try your best to get a quick picture at the bottom looking up.
author: Anthony G.

description:
Touted as the "crookedest street in the world" this place is a tourist attraction and a tourist trap all rolled into one BUT its so cool that you have to make an attempt if not to DRI e down it then to walk on over to not only see the cars attempting to maneuver down Lombard but to also watch all the people watching the cars and taking pictures of themselves on various locations along the street.

I would suggest coming during a non peak hour but am not sure when that would be since on my several trips to the area it has always been busy.

I give the people whose houses line this street a lot of credit...the constant barrage of cars and people around would drive me nuts!
author: Anne C.

description: As most people that visit San Fransisco know, this is one of the most know roads in the area for its 8 tight hairpin turns. Its a beautiful sight, it truly is. From the top you can see the beautiful view of the Coit Tower and towards North Beach. The landscaping is beautiful around the roads. I couldn't imagine living in these houses on the road, it would very loud and packed. During the day, there are cars constantly driving down the road (just to do it) and the streets are filled with tourists taking pictures all day.. I rode down several times myself and unless you go at night, you barely move at all. At night, you can get a good ride down at a better speed than 1 mph.. Anyway, still a beautiful sight for anyone that would like to see it!
author: Steven P.

description:
Another must see for any tourist visitng SF. It is very cool and very unique. The only thing is it was a *%tch climbing uphill to get to this from Fishermans Wharf! Made me burn off some of those calories from the King of Thai Noodle! 

Once you get there it is all worth it. Beautiful views of the city landscape, including the Coit Tower.

4 stars....because I'm still bitter about the climb lol
author: Mike F.

description: It's worth the drive to come through here, but it's gonna suck if it's busy. We ended up waiting at the top of the hill so we didn't have to crawl down the hill on someone else's bumper. It's twisty and turny and fun. The view is cool. There's a tree that I am pretty sure is a baby whomping willow from Harry Potter. Yeah. It was awesome. Do it!
author: Lauren N.

description:
I came, I saw it.. its a curvy street... ehhh? I don't get it.

Why do people pay so much to live on a street full of tourist and always packed with traffic! I feel bad for the people on this street, you got tourist invading your driveway every day!

Alright, enough hating, it's cool to see (ONCE!)... but just not my thing.
author: Hansel B.

description:
Crowded , yup.

But our private driver
 knew how to go around
that mess.

In minutes we were on
our way down the crooked
street!

Definitely an awesome
view. Beautiful flowers
align the gorgeous houses.

It was so picturesque,almost

author: Chel R.

description:
Okay so I took the easy way out. We parked somewhere around the area and walked downhill.

As I was walking down the stairs, I was like, "Man there used to be more flowers." I couldn't stop saying that because I remember there were flowers all over these bushes. And I saw nothing but plain green. But then again I was on the backside.

When I finally got to the bottom, I turned around. Low and behold, I saw flowers on the bushes. They were on the frontside of the bushes. BUT it was nowhere near as populated as how I remembered it 4 years ago. Like 1/3rd of it just died off. It was still beautiful though.

The hardest part is probably taking pictures when you're at the bottom. EVERYONE is down there taking pictures specifically at the center. It was a big ass crowd.

Walking uphill back to the car wasn't that bad. It was super cold though.

I did have a great time! But I like my bushes flowery. Will probably be back here again when I'm in San Francisco.
author: Jane L.

description: I was in the backseat and forced to go on this hill. It took almost an hour coming up from the Golden Gate Bridge. Instead I recommend coming at it from a side street and turning right. The cable car gets preference so if you're in front or behind it you'll get in a lot faster. Sure it's fun, it's a tourist place, I've done it so many times now that I played on my phone and read my book and was entertained by a few car accidents along the way, if you don't know how to drive on big hills this isn't the place for you. If you drive a stick shift, think twice.  So glad when it was finished so I could eat lunch.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
This was so hilarious to see, but fun to visit at least once. I was told my uncle once drove down this(and I want to say my dad was along in the car, that day), and I only must say I'm slightly jealous of those who had either driven down this themselves, or knew someone with a car who went down. Alas since I didn't know anyone with a car while in SF, I didn't get to experience what it's like to drive down. Anyway, it was fun to get pics of, and I'm sure I annoyed at least a few drivers getting a fast pic at the top, looking towards the queue of drivers waiting to go down Lombard. Wonder if any skateboarders have ever attempted to skate down this street(as difficult as that would have to be), instead of a car driving down?

It's definitely a one and done thing to see, but it was amusing to see this. I have read the rumors that it might be closed to all cars except those of local residents, and that they begun doing occasional closures of Lombard during select days after my SF trip. So drive it while you still can, if you have a car and are interested in this.
author: Allan M.

description: Can't miss Lombard street. Our kids were amazed how cool the houses lined up & how the they could fit a car in the garages!
author: Dominica R.

description:
Think of it as a workout whilst you're making your way to Lombard Street. Not only do you get a beautiful view at the end, you're also working those glutes that you have been ignoring at the gym the last few years. Lombard is named after the Lombardia region of Italia. It's practically located on Little Italy of San Francisco. Once you're at the top you get nothing but such a spectacular view of all of San Francisco, wow! 

I suggest any visitor to add Lombard Street on their list of things to see in San Francisco. It can be touristy, and maybe a little windy, but nonetheless quite picture worthy x
author: Hannah Y.

description: Well, where do I start... It is almost December so it's not that wonderful as I saw on pictures you know. it had flowers and it was sunny, but missed the season to see its full glory I guess. Not that much to see to be honest, I mean street is funny and crooked, lots of flowers and houses are beautiful indeed. I'm giving 4 not 3, because I believe that with flowers blooming and warmer weather it has to be better than I liked it.
author: Filip C.

description:
I love the florals and the views from this street. It is such a cute street!! You can see beautiful architecture and the ocean from the top. Not to mention the fact that it's the curviest street in the world. 

I recommend first time visitors to see the street. It may be crowded but it is worth it! I drove down it once it was easy in the compact rental car!
author: Angela R.

description:
The crookedest street in the world! It has eight hairpin turns, not to mention TONS of people and TONS of cars making the area super-congested, at least when I was there.

The views are gorgeous and it was a lot of fun, sort of like a roller-coaster. Driving down this street can be a real nail-biter since you're worrying about running people over the whole time so it kind of takes away from the experience. I'm not sure how good it would be if you walked it. 

Warning: the bottom of the hill is even more annoying than the top - everybody wants a selfie of themselves and so they end up blocking traffic. 

Oh well, it's still worth it.

The houses that line this one-block street are gorgeous.  I couldn't help but wonder how they deal with the car and pedestrian traffic.

I came here with my two kids one afternoon, waited in a ton of traffic and finally made it down the hill. It was worth it, but I won't be returning anytime soon. Definitely a "check the box" sort of experience.
author: David S.

description: You must go! I enjoyed walking up and seeing the gardens. There's a cable car that drops off at the top so you can always get off and step down to the bottom.
author: Ashley S.

description:
One of the must-see landmarks of the city.  Yes, it's really just a street that happens to be steep and twisty.  I'm sure the residents just love the hordes of tourists doing cutesy Asian poses all the way down the block.

This stretch is cool to check out from both ends.  On the high side, you can see Coit Tower and the Bay Bridge.  From the low side, you can watch all the cars navigating the hill.

If you do drive this thing, make sure your driving skills are up for it.  Let's just say there are a lot of paint marks all over the concrete barriers on the side of the road.

There's also a plaque on the S side of the road, about halfway down.  See pic.  Tells you some cool trivia about the street.
author: Edward L.

description:
The iconic Lombard Street. By far one of the most famous streets in San Francisco. This street is completely crooked and filled with super narrow and sharp turns. You can walk this hill, or you can be brave and drive down this street in your cars. I've done both but driving down the street was definitely much more of an adrenaline rush-especially since it was done with my family in an Escalade. As you're going down this street, you're going to be on edge the whole time because there are people everywhere taking pictures and if you aren't careful, you just might hit someone. It's worth it though to say that you've done it. 

I do remember it being much prettier during Spring when all the flowers bloom and there's more green everywhere. It's still pretty neat during Fall and Winter but you really want to be here when the flowers are in full bloom. At the bottom of the hill, there's a ton of people there since that's a prime photo spot. Yes, they do block traffic so be a little patient. Also, remember that there are actual people living in the homes on this street so be respectful to them too! Enjoy! 4/5
author: Michelle L.

description: Its a crooked , winding street. Cool lol. Had to knock it off the list. Took the powell hyde line and then jumped off, walked down and its on the way to the palace of fine arts and golden gate bridge.
author: Angel R.

description: I went recently to visit Crook Street in San Francisco with my family and friend, is a beautiful place indeed located in a nice neighborhood. We parked on Hyde Street near Lombard for less than 5 minutes but in our way back to our car we noticed the back window got smashed!!!, we were shocked that happened and frustrated !!!, nothing was taken, we only had clothes and nothing of value but still the damage was done. A manager of a building who lives across the street told us that problem happens very often all that area an is nothing new, just gets worse, The police does very little or nothing about it and even if someone is caught won't be a major offense anyways so easily they will be 'back in business' . So please make sure to lock up you're car, don't leave any values inside or anything that looks "attractive" to thieves !!! maybe one person can stay in the car while others go to admire Crook St and then swap could be a recommendation.Only take a few seconds to thugs to grab and go, they keep an eye on tourists, cars with license plate out of state, they know they're business very well.Manager told us that problem happens at any day or any time and to any kind of car.
author: Dennis S.

description:
Lombard Street is definitely one of the tourist attractions to see in San Francisco. We wanted to get the view of the street both on foot and by car.  So while we waited in the line of cars, we found a parking spot as close as possible to the street, and headed down the stairs adjacent to the crooked street.  The stairs are flat and not steep so they were easy to climb and/or walk down.  It was helpful for me since I was working with a sprained ankle.  I was able to go up and down without too much pain.  The street is lined with beautiful flowers and the residents of this street preserve its beauty by adding their own plants/flowers in their front yard to match the landscape of the street.  At the top of hill where the crookedness starts, you get a great view of the city with Coit Tower in the background.

There is one particular street that you can drive on to make a right turn straight into the crooked street.  Otherwise, you'll have to wait in a really long line on Lombard street to go down the crooked Lombard street area.  I haven't driven on steep hills in a while so it took some getting used to to drive with both feet.  Hills are not my favorite to drive on but it was worth it for the views. These types of experiences make me miss my hometown!
author: Janet E.

description: I can only imagine how residents feel every time tourists come & take pictures here. Be courteous people, don't park in front of their driveways! I have actually seen people do that & residents get ticked off and start honking at you which is completely understandable. There is parking right in front of it. Keep in mind that Lombard Street is actually only a one way street for first timers or people that haven't visited yet. Its really beautiful in the morning & when it's sunny.
author: Anne L.

description: Lombard Street was an amazing sight to see and quite the experience to drive down! I did not drive of course, the hunny did! I took pictures and Videos the whole way down! Once down, we parked and walked up! We got VERY lucky to have someone pulling out right as we came down, and was able to pull in right at the bottom! We walked up along the path, which is lined with TONS of flowers and beautiful landscaping!! This street is beautiful, unique and definitely worth driving down... just don't hit someone taking a selfie! It's dangerous as it is FULL of tourists walking all around, taking pictures of everything and photographers lying in wait for the perfect time gap between cars to run in the middle of the street and begin taking pictures! So watch ALL your surroundings on the way down, other than that, enjoy!
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Stunningly Beautiful Views From the Top of This Unique and Curvy Street! Worth a Visit - Go Early in the AM to Beat the Crowds. 

My mother and I visited the famous Lombard Street during the early morning of July 31st. 

We were riding the Powell-Mason cable car and decided to hop off to check out Lombard Street. The Powell-Hyde cable car also stops here, but at the top of the street, while Powell-Mason stops at the bottom. The street is also easily accessible via MUNI bus (which is the cheaper and faster option, if you are not looking to experience the cable cars). 

Lombard Street is one of the most crooked streets in the world. From where the cable car dropped us off, we hiked uphill on Lombard Street until we arrived at the base of the curvy section. There were huge and gorgeous flowers blooming along with lush vegetation growing in between the curves of the street. The street was lined on both sides with beautiful houses. There was a sidewalk with steps on both sides of the street which made it easier for walking up this very steep hill! 

We arrived early in the morning to Lombard Street, at around 7 AM, which meant that there was nobody else there and we had the entire street to ourselves. It was lovely and the atmosphere was very peaceful, quiet, and relaxing, which I enjoyed (I very much dislike crowds of people). I highly recommend coming here early in the morning as well if you would like to avoid the throngs of people and crowds that would be there later in the morning and afternoon. 

After climbing to the top of Lombard, I was amazed at how high we were and we were rewarded with such incredible and beautiful views of the city! I could see Coit Tower, the downtown area, the bay and more. The photo opportunities from here were amazing. 

We enjoyed the views at the top of Lombard for a little while before catching the Powell-Hyde cable car from the top of the hill, going towards Fisherman's Wharf. 

Lombard Street may be popular but despite it being a huge tourist attraction, it was worth the visit for me!
author: Brittany T.

description:
It's Crooked

I know I'm in the minority here, but I was actually underwhelmed.  I thought it would be amazing, but it wasn't.  Don't get me wrong; it is cool.  It's just not near the top of the list for things I would recommend for visitors to SF.
author: Ted Q.

description:
It would probably REALLY suck to live on this street. I showed up with my gf on a weekday afternoon and it was still buzzing with dozens of tourists. Hell, we had to wait in a line to drive down. A line. To drive down a street. The things people do...

Funny thing is, this isn't even the crookedest street in SF. Not that anyone cares, though. They all want to check out this street. I will say it's a fun drive. Totally touristy, yes, but something you've got to do at least once if you're in town. Hot spots are usually hot for a reason, so indulge.
author: Anthony A.

description: Cool street. Fun and scary at the same time to drive down.  I'm glad I was able to experience it while in town.
author: Asenath N.

description:
The world famous Lambord Street with its crazy turns and beautiful flowers wrapped around every twist and turn. It has an enchanting view of the city from the top of the street before you begin your journey. 
So why was it just okay for me? Well I arrived mid-day and the traffic was horrific you have to drive past the street then get into a line that is not controlled. The wait to go down the street took about 30 minutes and we were starving so that didn't help our patience. You will notice huge crowds of people crossing every which way taking selfies, photos in the middle of the road, talking, jay walking, and many other annoying habits that made driving here frustrating. I noticed two traffic cops standing in the same spot that didn't make sense when one of them was needed towards the beginning of the line. Once you are allowed to go down the street in a car it goes really quickly and then it is over. Unlike Fisherman's Warf or China town there is nothing near this street that you can park and enjoy. It is a nice thing to see and experience and it will make movie watching a bit more personal but it is a lot of hype for such a short one way road. It's just okay for me and I have been there done that and will probably never go down that road again.
author: Gary M.

description:
Amazing it's a must visit, never seen something like this. Make sure bring camera
You may park your car and walk up/down the stairs as well. It was raining when I was there, couldn't walk but drove thru it.
author: Inderjeet D.

description: Took a late night ride on the cable cars and got to see this amazing view from Lombard street. Worth checking out.
author: Cristina A.

description:
ZIG-ZAG

If you're coming to San Francisco this should be on your list of touristy things to do. I consulted for a tech company in San Francisco for 20+ years and on one of my first trips my co-worker and now best friend, John M drove me down this hill. I am glad he was driving because there is no way I would want to do it by myself. There is just too much pressure with all the tourists staring at me. 

The name Lombard came from the street in Philadelphia. The curving back and forth design was first proposed by Carl Henry and in 1922 they built it. The design was created to reduce the hill's natural 27% grade, which is too steep for most cars. I am sure it was never intended to be a tourist attraction. It is funny how something that was created for a practical purpose becomes a tourist trap. 

I am just glad I had a local seasoned professional drive me down. You can do it yourself but beware of the other cars and tourists in your way. You also might want to get the full insurance on your rental car, just in case. Remember that this one block section of Lombard Street is steep with eight tight hairpin turns. Am I scaring you now?

San Francisco is an interesting place to drive and Lombard Street adds to that flavor. I've been freaked out in my rental car going over a hill and not being able to see the other side. How do they do those car chases in the movies? There is no way in real life a car could be going that fast over these hills. I must also say you haven't lived until you've parallel parked on a hill. It's not that hard but just weird. 

So add it to your list of things to do when you come to San Francisco. Just remember to be careful and safe if you decide to take
It on by yourself.
author: Anthony M.

description:
My dad was brave enough to make the drive up this historic landmark...all the while the rest of my family was freaking out in the backseat. But, the view from the top is definitely worth it, and I recommend taking pictures as much as you can. 
And like any tourist attraction, there were a lot of assholes who would not wait their turn and cut other cars off. Since we were, what felt like, straight up and down, it was a bit more unnerving than usual. If you can, I recommend getting out and walking to the top. But, prepare for an exhausting walk!
author: Katelyn R.

description:
After driving over 4000 miles from Massachusetts we made it to San Francisco and we had to go down the famous Lombard Street. 

When we showed up there was no traffic so we were able to enjoy the trip. The views from Lombard Street were gorgeous and looking at the beauty from the bottom of the street was great. 

In the end we loved coming to this historical landmark and this is definitely a once in a life time experience.

description: Beautiful street. But gets crowded really quickly for photos... Nonetheless great site to visit

walked up, saw the road, eh

description:
Great experience! ! A must do if visiting San Fran. Best experienced with a car

description: Great view. bring comfy shoes since it's a long walk.

description:

author: Nelson Q.

description:
Alright, it's a tourist trap in which you're suddenly considered cool amongst your friends if you conquer Lombard Street. I didn't drive down here as I took the cable car, but walking up and down the stairs to the side is enough of an exercise for me.

This place is great for views and great for photos...if you're under 65 or are relatively mobile. My grandma had a tough time staying upright here, because the wind from the bay kicks in hard around here, and it's magnified by the fact you're so high up. The wait for the cable car was also blustery and chilly (this was mid-June at around 6:30pm), to the point I had to give my oversized jacket to my grandma so she can stay warm.

Oh, and guys...please don't dish out your cameras if you're driving down Lombard, especially if you're the driver. First of all it's illegal, second you're holding everyone up, third it's unsafe since one misstep on the pedal and you could be victim of higher insurance rates. I saw no less than 5 cars that almost crashed from focusing too much on taking their photos instead of driving.
author: Calvin S.

description:
Great little tourist spot.  It's a nice view of the city and a neat street in and of itself.  We double parked at the top and hopped out for a quick pic.  Drove down, then illegal parked again for another quick pick.  This is the way to do it... also since it was the middle of the day on a Tuesday there wasn't a line and the tourist traffic wasn't too thick.  It's pretty neat, but it's not mind blowing or anything.  Check it out if you have time, but if you don't make it you didn't miss out on too much.

Too bad the guy we asked to take our picture was incompetent.  Guess we have to go back now...
author: Alan S.

description:
Life on Lombard Street must be really interesting.
I can't imagine standing in your room and thinking you're actually standing straight, when, really, you're on the verge of leaning over. 

That said, I'm making a note-to-self: bring a skateboard the next time you go to SF. I'm terrified on standing on a skateboard alone, but I'll make this my roller-coaster ride.

I took the hard way coming UP here: walked from Fisherman's Wharf, to Ghirardelli Square, circled Russian Hill Park, and hiked up Hyde St. Phew! Worked up a sweat. 

Was it worth it?

Well...

The altitude of this part of Lombard Street is just like any other deep hill you'd find in San Francisco--except there's a zig-zag in between, but no one really walks down on it because it is jammed with traffic. Trying to stand in the middle of the top, just to get a photo is scary, with a vehicle coming right at you. I get it: the appeal is the zig-zag and there's a joy in watching cars pass by in an unparalleled manner, but there's no joy if I can't go down that hill. But it was fun to finally trek down somewhere, after all that climbing. It's hard to get a great picture when you're up at the top of the hill because there's dozens of cars coming in, and it is filled with tourists who are possibly acrophobic to walk down. A friend of my mother's, who is a long-time SF resident, told us the street used to be filled with flowers, and now looks like one huge pile of grass. Probably would've made a difference since it is pretty unique. 
The only way I'd come back here again is if I were to go down the hill in some sort of transportation, whether it's a scooter, rollerblades, car, motorbike, whatever.
author: Sharon T.

description: Walked up to Lombard Street during a day of sightseeing and was not disappointed.  The street was as curvy as I imagined and it is also lined with stairs the entire length of the street, so my toddler and I hiked up the entire block.  We were certainly winded by the end, but it was really neat to see and you get a great view at the top.  Would love to drive it sometime if ever in the area, so perhaps will do that on our next visit.

description: The street is really neat looking. I got the best pictures from the top of the street. I wish I had a car to drive down it! Although, there are lots of people everywhere.

description: Must stop when in San Francisco! It is one of those see to believe things. Insanely curvy the whole way down but beautiful kept up gardens. Recommend if it is your first time going there drive down the Lombard Street.

description:
What a beautiful view you can see Alcatraz beautifully from the sidestreets. I mean if you're going to come to San Francisco and you don't walk down the crazy Lombard steps it's not worth coming for visit.

I would suggest starting at the top and walking down as it is a bit easier although we chose to walk up which took a little bit of excessive energy and the sun was a little bit warmer today maybe 75° but the exercise kicks in and you do start up a little sweat!

description:
We walked another steep hill to see Lombard Street and saw how steep going up Lombard Street would be.. so we just took pictures at the bottom, lol.

The street is totally crooked and zig zaggy. We went on a Saturday morning, and I thought it would be prettier in person but it looks better in pictures... maybe wrong time to visit, or it needed more flowers and greenery?

The cross street at the bottom was pretty empty so many visitors were able to take pictures of the middle of the street. I think it helped that it was a residential area, and also a weekend.

Overall, it was a nice landmark to visit. Took some quick pictures and on to the next!
author: Felicia L.

description: Hey, it's crooked for sure.  But Vermont St is crookeder.  Been there, done that on both streets.  But Lombard is far more scenic.  But OMG, the tourist hordes are hideous.  I made the mistake of going once on a weekend when two traffic cops were directing traffic due to the morons who forgot how to drive here.  Then I went back 1  1/2 weeks later on a weekday and there was no car traffic.  Just the moron tourists walking on the street despite the signs that say "no walking on street".  The idiots with strollers were icing on the cake for stupidity.  Go and enjoy but drive and/or walk safely and use the proper area (that means walk on the SIDEWALK).  I do pity the rich folks that live there for having to put up with all the tourists.
author: Tim L.

description:
Definitely visit this once in your life!  I was so fortunate to get to come here. Although, it's not THAT big of a deal but it is a tourist attraction - why not?  I gotta tell ya, I think I'm pretty good at directions and I thought it was difficult to find.  If I remember correctly, Lombard Street is actually not connected to the attraction "Lombard Street", confusing right?

Regardless, ask someone (which is what I did).  He was so laid-back, friendly.  No problem at all telling me where to go.  I'm pretty sure all Californians are that chill.

The signs on "Lombard Street" say do NOT WALK down the road.  Well of course you have people who do.  There are sidewalks you can walk down and take pictures.  Now I have people in all my photos of the street.  Annoying mostly.

I don't know how people live on that road, that would be too many tourists around my home for my likings.

I definitely recommend you stop here once while you're in San Fran!
author: Nina C.

description:
Not the crookedest street in SF, but definitely the prettiest crooked street. Miss the big wheel races here (moved to the other crooked street).  Everyone should visit this street.  It's fun at night when the lines of tourists aren't there.  I like to open the sunroof and pop out (as a passenger of course).  The line can back up during the day and on weekends.  The Zig Zag itself is fun even if you are going 5 or under.  Just remember people live here, so don't be obnoxious.  

Walk it, drive it and photograph from the bottom up for your iconic shot.
