author: Kristi G.

description: What a cool windy and twisting road in The City By The Bay. This is a fun drive to do. Or walk along the stairs on the side. The tourists love driving this road.
author: Peter J.

description: Sometimes it's closed. Decently one of the things to do when you are in San Francisco. The road is cool. Nice flower
author: Mara H.

description:
For a number of years I'd heard about the "Crookedest Street" in the world and decided to check it out on the way back from the Golden Gate Bridge. It's easy to see why it's an attraction with it's sharp, continuous, hair-pin curves down the steep decline. 

Adventurous drivers test out their maneuvering skills by chancing the ride down the hill, many of whom had passengers with Go-Pro cameras and cell phones perched outside their windows in order to capture the experience. Safely located on either side of the road, are designated sidewalks that allow pedestrians to navigate the street without facing the danger of the giddy drivers who maybe more focused on the joy-ride.

A gardner's dream. Beautiful gardens adorn and decorate the street with lush Hydrangeas, Rose Bushes and Boganvillia plants all over. 

This is a tourist trap. Crowds of selfie and groups photo takers liter the area. Many of them choosing to ignore the "stay out the street" and "stay off the wall" posted signs in order to "get that perfect picture". What many didn't (or chose not to) realize is that the pathways and street run though private homes and may tourist seemed not to care that they were infringing on the personal properties of others. Maybe with English not being their language they didn't realize the interpretation of the signs. I saw one young lady stick her cell phone in a garden bed, just to get a photo and didn't care that she was technically trespassing. They owners were either not home or didn't care.

Once and You're Done. You've go to check it out at least once while you visit the Bay Area. If you feel adventurous then take it for a ride. A cable car stop is conveniently located at the top of the street, but if you have your own vehicle you may find one or two parking spots. For the gardeners out there, it's definitely a treat to see the flowers in bloom so, sprint would be a great time to visit!

http://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g60713-d106232-r275292874-Lombard_Street-San_Francisco_California.html#
author: Philip T.

description: Make sure you are in here early so that you can drive on the street. It gets really crowded by 10 in the morning. It feels bad that you are disturbing the peaceful neighborhood but you cant stop admiring the street
author: Mohan S.

description:
Hyped! This isn't a bad destination at all, but the pictures that you may have seen, are most likely Photoshoped, as I have been here different times of the year, and only twice ever managed to capture the street with flowers in bloom. Over the years, this has gotten a lot more crowded so if you are planning to drive down, be watchful of the frequently changing one way signs, and the long and slow lines. 

Definitely worth a visit or two. Beyond that, well, SF has so much more to offer!
author: A K.

description: I had to come here during my visit, it's such a landmark of San Fran. Generally, driving in San Fran is such an interesting experience, and I enjoyed it quite a bit. Lombard st. doubles the fun with all the beauty. So jealous of people who live here lol.
author: Yue D.

description:
Lombard Street - known in the world as the most crookedest-road in the world with its 8 hairpin turns between Hyde and Levenworth Street. 

Heading West on Lombard, past Van Ness Ave is a steep climb towards the top of the 8-hairpin turns. It's probably about a 30-degree incline - quite a walk up (and eventually back down) the hill. Tip - wear appropriate footwear if you're walking here. 

But once at the apex of the hill - looking around is quite a view, great for long exposure night city photography, if you're into that kind of hobby. The hairpin turns itself; drivers are limited to 5mph going down the hill. Once you've seen this place - it's really nothing much else to see. Personally though, I like visiting this spot of San Francisco just for the walking aspect.
author: Franklin H.

description:
Imagine living on this street!! Ugh that would get so annoying haha, but as an attraction Lombard street is awesome.

While playing tourist in the city this past May, it was nice to experience this side of the city. Driving down the crooked road was fun and gorgeous while the flowers were in bloom.

Overall I had to knock a star off because the wait to drive down was ridiculous (usually is on the weekends). And to make matters worse there were city workers directly traffic that had literally no idea what they were doing. They led the wrong cars the wrong ways and made exceptions for certain people and not other... Super annoying when you are waiting on the steepest hill ever! I almost thought we were going to roll back into the rest of the cars!

But on a brighter note, one of the traffic directors was blowing bubbles which was weird at first.. But then kind of calming haha. I miss sf :)
author: Amanda L.

description:
Dear Tourists:

1. There is a very, very, very steep hill on the ascent to Lombard Street. If you drive stick, but suck at it, please do all of us a favor and take a cable car or have someone else drive. Your ineptitude messes up traffic for miles back.

2. Unless there are policemen on foot to direct traffic, don't assume traffic laws are temporarily suspended and it is now okay just to stand in the middle of the road to take pictures. 

3. THIS IS NOT THE CROOKEDEST STREET IN SAN FRANCISCO. Use the Internet, darlings!

4. Try not to disturb the people who live on the street. That's just rude.

Hugs and Kisses,

Tara H. (Resident of San Francisco)
author: Tara H.

description: We didn't get to see the Street from the bottom side, so we didn't really get to see much curve, except to see that the cars were winding as they drove down. It was a nice view of the city but it was a little crowded and there were cars trying to get down the street as people were trying to take pictures.
author: Margaret P.

description: We were lucky to have a fairly short line to drive down the street. View from the bottom is better though! Watch out for tourists lining the roads.
author: Trista A.

description:
Lombard Street: the crookedest street in the world!

Lombard Street is best known for it's winding block on Russian Hill between Leavenworth Street and Hyde Street.  This infamous one-way road has eight sharp winding turns.  The design of this roadway was created in 1922 to address the issue with the hill's steepness.  The gradual bends in the road make it easier for cars and pedestrians to navigate the hill.  Due to the popularity of this spot and the slow 5mph speed limit the hill is known to be a bit of a congested traffic jam.  

Watch out for ambitious photographers that may get too close to cars in search of the perfect photo!!!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Lombard Street is where Crookedest Street is located.  If you love your car, don't drive it down Crookedest Street.  If you don't know how to drive but still want to drive down, please get out of the car before attempting to do so and have someone else drive.  This is not a place for people to try and practice their driving skills.  And for the cars that are not well-maintained, it's really embarrassing for the hundreds of tourists in that main area to hear the grinding and gear-moaning coming out of your car.  It truly sounds like something is about to snap off...

You can take the cable car, which will stop at the top for you.  Other than car, bike, or walking, there is no other way to get up to Lombard Street.  This means no buses and no other forms of public transit other than cablecar.  It might be easier to go from the bottom of Crookedest Street and walk the stairs to get to the top.

However, ye be warned.  This is a tourist attraction.  Therefore, there will be many tourists.  They will block the streets to get a good picture, they will block all other pedestrians to get a good picture, they may push and shove to get good pictures.  And they're taking pictures with their baking-pan-called-iPads, which occupies even more space and walking room.

So, the actual landmark is very pretty, and fairly accessible if you plan ahead.  However, there are many inconsiderate tourists that may prevent you from enjoying the street fully.

Also, when going downhill on the other side of Crookedest Street, be careful.  I sprained my ankle when the bf and I were vacationing SF, and have been painfully hobbling around SF...  =(
author: Grace C.

description:
TRAFFIC TRAFFIC TRAFFIC. This place is great though for driving through if you've never experienced it and the view.....BREATHTAKING BEAUTIFUL! Only con is that there's some much traffic in this area and you have to be really alert because there's just so many people in one area trying to take photos and a lot of people don't pay attention to the traffic. Just a heads up, but breathtaking view..PICS DO NOT DO THE VIEW JUSTICE. Ya gotta see if for your own eyes :)

FOR PARKING: we ended up aprking 3 streets away for the free parking..it was just so packed!!!
author: K D.

description: The view is beautiful. Driving to the spot is cool but i think walking there tops it. Surrounding area is beatiful plus you dont have to wait for traffic. The only thing is the steep hills to get there depending where your coming from. Walking there definitely allows you to take it all in.
author: Joe V.

description: Lots of tourist, great leg workout. Definitely worth the walk - also, you definitely want to walk this street because you can stop as you please to take photos. The surrounding houses are beautiful to look at as well! Driving might be easier but walking was super enjoyable!
author: Laura K.

description:
The World Famous Lombard Street rocks more curves than a rap video model, but although it is probably a pain to actually drive down proves quite entertaining to watch others drive down. This short, but beloved section of street has the distinction of being the most crooked street in the world!

* Runs East to West
* Spans one block
* 8 Tight turns
* Named after Lombard Street in Philadelphia Pennsylvania
* Best known for this particular 1 way section between Hyde and Leavenworth
* The hill on this section has a 27% grade
* Paved with Red Bricks
* Speed limit is 5 mph

I'll admit that neither me nor the person I was with decided to try and drive down this world famous street, but we were quite happy to stop and pay her a visit. She sits proudly and majestically. There's been many types of discussions as to do with this section of the city as it is becoming so busy, but as of right now things still flow like they originally did since its inception.
author: Chad A.

description:
This is such a fun street. Super crooked and touristy. No other street is like this one, that's for sure. 

Great view of the city from the top. We got out and took pictures. There are a lot of pretty flowers here. Then, we actually drove down the street and that was so much fun! It was like a ride in Disneyland. Too bad it was so short. I can't imagine people living by this street; it must be so noisy from all the tourists stopping and taking pictures. Also, the Simpsons parodied this. Haha. 

A must see in SF.
author: Betty H.

description:
This is probably the most famous street in San Francisco. Only I can't help but to feel sorry for the people that live on either sides of the street. With constant people around taking pictures, buses, cars and buses it must get kind of annoying but after all they are choosing to live there. 

You get an amazing view of the city from this street. Just be careful driving here because of people paying attention 50% of the time.
author: Anne R.

description:
Amazing... Simply amazing.. Lombard Street - San Fran's crookedest street rules! It truly does. I wasn't going to do it but I ran into a guy who was visiting from Canada and he highly recommended I check it out so I did and it was totally worth it!

If you're in San Francisco, do yourself a favour - head to Powell and Market, take the cable car (beware of long, very long queues!) to Powell & Hyde not Powell & Mason! and you'll be there in about 15-20 mins. The ride on San Fran's famous cable car is a unique experience in itself and, as you make your way along the steep roads and you get a view of downtown; you'll realise.... Oh bagger it, just do it, you won't be disappointed! 

When you get there and you get off at Lombard Street, trust me, you are bound to be amazed! and taken in awe! At your 12 o'clock is a beautiful view of the Bay and Alcatraz and, at your 3; you have the zig zaggy/snakey street that is Lombard St with amazing views of Colt Tower - love it!

You know what you could do as well? Head east on Lombard and make your way to Fisherman's Wharf where the Powell/Mason cable car stops, get on it and get off at Chinatown - there you go, you've just knocked off 2 things off your list!
author: Kevin S.

description:
San Francisco's windiest, most zig zag, car sick inducing street, might as well be a fixture in the city's driver's test for how narrow it is. It is undoubtedly touristy and home to some of the most expensive real estate in the city (#1). Folks can walk the path that is Lombard Street, but most everyone will travel by car and at grandma speeds to ensure safety.

Try coming here during the day. The night is fun as well, but definitely not as easy to drive through for folks who haven't done it before. It is a one way street, so don't go driving up the hill anytime soon. If only San Francisco had a snowy winter, I can imagine this place would be an awesome spot to ride a sled / snowboard through. Wishful thinking yes, but zigzag lovers would have to agree.

The Lombard experience is worth a try at least once for all SF visitors. After a handful of times, it's just a time killer with a (steep) view.
________
(#1) The perks of living on a winding hill is ... what?
author: Jando S.

description:
Wow!!! This street is crazy! It was super crowded when visited with lots of people snapping photos! But it's a cool thing to see. The street has some beautiful buildings on it and great flowers up and down it. 
One thought if you drive be prepared to stop for all the people up top who block the street to get a photo.
author: Allison P.

description: This street is unique with all the zig zags.  There's tons of flowers and the landscaping is nice.  You can't walk the zig zags but you can walk some stairs.  The driveability looked pretty much looked like the line was too long.  It's unique so its better than most streets.  However it is a street.  It's cool to see once but you wouldn't make a habit if coming here.
author: Andy S.

description:
I'm fairly certain that myself and three other individuals that'll remain nameless are the only persons ever to drive *up* Lombard Street. If that's not the case, I'd love to meet the brave soul that accomplished the feat first. 

Important to note: I was not behind the wheel. Bill Cosby was.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
The brief story I am about to tell may or may not be the truth. It is up to you to decide...

The night was dark and the mood was tense with anticipation. A carload of misfits took this opportunity to look up rather than down and waited for an unlikely opportunity. A break in headlights took place and the throttle was pumped. It was all a blur, but what we believe this rental car of renegades just pulled off was nothing short of impossible much less unbelievable. I mean how could anyone ever make it up the zigs and zags of Lombard Street going the wrong way? Totally impossible, right?

Dream big, my friends.
author: Brad B.

description:
Great fun and windy place to show
You're friends. Obviously if you don't visit this street you haven't really visited San Francisco it's just a must go place other than the Golden Gate Bridge and the fisherman wharf. There is a lot to do in SF but you must stop here and take ride down the street.
author: Denise R.

description:
what a beautiful pain in the ass street to walk up if you're not in shape. Ok so be a smart ass and tell me no one told me to walk up it in the first place. Yeah yeah. No one said,  "Susan I am holding your life hostage if you don't walk up Lombard Street." 

To me it was a silly must do - like  strange accomplishment. I didn't drive down it - I walked up it. So there! Yes, I paid dearly for it the next day but I did it. 

Definitely a tourist attraction. If you drive in the area try not to run over the masses of people who seem to think the roads are for picture taking and not actual driving. I saw a few near misses because those with cameras felt they had the right of way to block the road.
author: Susan H.

description: It'll take you about a whole minute n a half to get to the end of this windy street, but it's a cute drive by while in San Francisco. During high tourist times, they'll close the street except for locals, otherwise it's usually open to experience. The "crooked street" isn't a difficult drive but prepared to avoid runners going up and down the street. Definitely an experience to mark off your list both at day and at night.
author: Philip And Dahlia A.

description:
What a goofy little street. We enjoyed walking up and down the sides of Lombard Street. We slowly walked up and down and took some pictures. You have a little view at the top of the street which is quite nice.

The line to drive down the street was quite long but I enjoyed walking. So I would recommend parking nearby and walking the street.
author: Jena D.

description: One trick pony. Come look at me, I've got switchbacks! Bleh. I can think of at least 4 better steep hills.
author: Loren G.

description: This was my first visit here. We rode the cable car to the top and walked down. The views were amazing, the flowers & landscaping were gorgeous and everyone else walking there were also happy and enjoying themselves. I cannot imagine actually living on this street! There were so many people and I'm sure its a lot of noise. You can look into a lot of peoples' houses which is kind of icky. Just saying. Privacy glass would be good. There were some folks walking up but why?!? The people driving down were all having fun with their music blaring. All in all, a very enjoyable walk, good times. Free entertainment (and shhhhhhhh don't tell anyone but you're getting some exercise too!!!)
author: Corina J.

description:
One of the more unique features of SF. Definitely a go-to spot when visiting because how many times will you see such a curvy path?! Have fun driving down! And take pictures at the base, you'll probably get your best pic there.

It does tend to get crowded because it's a tourist spot so you've been warned!
author: Olivia S.

description: A very beautiful zig-zag street and amazing views, I was happy to stop by this block to finally see it! If I had a car or bike I would of attempted to go down.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Once for yourself.  Many subsequent times for your tourist guests / friends.

First, if you are taking tourists, don't tell them where you're taking them.  Surprise them. Then, depending on when you go, you can roll up from the western approach without much hassle, or endure a line-up that backs up practically to Van Ness, the major north-south thoroughfare in SF.  Sometimes, it crawls so slowly, that both your patience and your car's temperature gauge are tested.  My least favorite uncle didn't know where we were headed and, in the midst of the traffic jam, started to swear.  I turned around and told him to shut up.  (You would too if you knew him).  The payoff:  everybody in the car LOVED the descent and insisted on stopping at its base to take photos.

The neighborhood twisty Lombard Street dumps into is Russian Hill, though it's hardly a dump.  Not even close.  However, the most roller coaster like drops, per my experiences, are found along the streets at the base of Lombard Street (Jones, Taylor, etc.) as they barrel downward to the Wharf.  Drive carefully.
author: Robert G.

description: Definitely a must visit spot when in sfo. Famous for having a steep, one-block section that consists of eight tight hairpin turns, it was really fun driving down Russian Hill neighborhood and onto the Telegraph Hill neighborhood. This spot is easily accesible through the cable car but I would definitely recommend driving on this street as it is one of kind experience.
author: Vineet S.

description: Nice place but hard to get to by car. Better to park somewhere and walk or try uber or public transport. Driving there will feel like a roller coaster
author: Katya N.

description:
Lombard street is an icon of the quirkiness of San Francisco.

As a sight for tourism, its a short stop and nothing to stick around long for. You see it, you drive it, you move on. I do like the interactive aspect in the steep and twisting drive. It makes me wonder if those living on this street are annoyed by the tourism.

When I think of San Francisco this squiggle always appears in my mind, that's Lombard street. The backdrop to this squiggle are deep views down the city. I like a lot of the houses along it. Lombard is a fun and simple sight to see for anyone who has never been here before, but once you've driven it, it loses some appeal as a repeat destination.
author: M D.

description: It lives up to the hype. A very steep walk down and up. Good exercise. Beautiful views of the city once your at that top. Awesome experience !  It is literally as windy as it looks in pictures
author: Vee W.

description: I've seen this place twice so far in my life. Great view! But literally a 3 to 20 minute drive down this winding rode (depending on traffic). Don't go at night! Enjoy this for the day!
author: Lin D.

description:
There's a cable stop at Lombard Street.  I've been to San Francisco a number of times, but never knew about this place until my bf mentioned it.

Lombard Street is a cool spot with hair pin turns surrounded by flowers.  My bf and I went through this by car.  It's a must see in San Francisco.
author: Keila N.

description: Everyone has heard of the Crookedest street in the world. This is so known that all the tourists visit, but that great thing about this tourist area, it is free and really cool! I highly suggest driving down the street and then parking and walking up it and then back down. It is one of those things that once you see it and drive it and walk it, you probably don't have to do it again in your lifetime, but it is worth it, the views are great too!
author: Tina S.

description: We got here super early and drove down the street. It was so cool and I just can't believe that people live on this street. It's so fun to drive down at 5 mph and see all the beautiful flowers and houses and the view is amazing!!! Seriously if you have the time check it out for reals yo!!! Hope to do it again walking. Just couldn't with the 5 month old baby lol
author: Timothy G.

description:
The line to even get in line to go down Lombard Street is soooooooooooooooooo long BUT it's still a fun tourist attraction.

So basically there was this big ass hill and the city planners of San Francisco decided instead of a street that went straight down, they would make it zig zag. Morons.

Lo and behold the zig zag pattern of Lombard Street!

I feel so bad for anyone who actually lives on the street and has a car... backing up without hitting anything seems near impossible.
author: Leslie D.

description:
Why three stars for such an icon? It has been ruined by the ill-mannered narcissists who treat the street like an amusement park.

If you're going to visit the crookedest street in the world:

- DO NOT BLOCK TRAFFIC. Yes, I'm talking to you...the one standing in the middle of Leavenworth with your selfie stick in hand.

- DO NOT BLOCK TRAFFIC ON LOMBARD ITSELF. Don't hold up traffic on the hill so that you and all of your passengers can get out of your rental and snap a selfie.

- DO NOT STAND IN THE MIDDLE OF LOMBARD AND BLOCK TRAFFIC. I don't know how much more dumbed down those NO PEDESTRIAN signs have to be.

- DO NOT BLOCK TRAFFIC. Did I forget to mention that?

Not surprisingly, Stanley Roberts was here.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=deX92UMLXdc

Traffic is an absolute nightmare around the hill...probably because of the aforementioned selfie brigade. Going east on Lombard the backup starts near Van Ness. And don't even think about cutting down Greenwich or Filbert to get to Larkin; you'll be waiting there too.

I only did it because it was my daughter's first time in the city, but if you care enough to see this street I would just capture a pic looking up from Leavenworth and move on. By the way, I'm implying the sidewalk, not the middle of the street...
author: JP A.

description: This was cool to drive down Lombard St. Police on top and bottom to help with traffic control. Heavy foot traffic as well.
author: Keala S.

description:
I debated even reviewing this but hey I went there so why not

We were in the area after visiting Coit Tower, saw the two birds, had a stone and decided lets get a picture at Lombard Street

With a thousand other people doing the same thing

I have been down the street before years ago, so I really didn't need to do that again. We were able to find parking, (somehow) and got out waiting for our moment to take shot

Lombard sign *click* check
Us next to street *click* check

Done and done

Love this street. Touristy? Yes of course it is...but it's a must when in the city.
author: Rachael C.

description: Can anyone really review a street? If it's as monumental and crazy as Lombard than yes, perhaps.  Be sure to drive down slowly while bumping SHM and have a friend record it with their smart phone.  The street begins on the top of a hill which winds down like a snake and ends with a bunch of random tourist at the bottom taking pictures of you.
author: Tim C.

description: My husband and I were in the area so we thought we'd cruise down Lombard.  The last time we had done it was 13 years ago and boy was it a different experience.  Now a days it seems like your better of walking. All the tourists stand in the street and block the cars so you spend more time sitting staring at rude tourists then you do actually getting to enjoy the ride or views.  It was so bad that at one point the whole intersection at the bottom was blocked by tourists.  There was even one man with a tripod set up in the road.  Unless you like tourist traps stay away.....
author: Laura P.

description:
It was the best of times, it was the worst of times. It was the dizziest of times, it was was the zigzagiest of times.

Rudy in the car seat and Vanessa whining about something. Four geniuses did the impossible, and you should toss us some respect. 

Editor's Note: I will never admit to this.

Evelyn Note: I WENT UP LOMBARD.
author: Evelyn A.

description: Eh. This is as touristy as it gets. Hearing about this site really made me hype up the street before seeing it. When actually coming here, thats exactly what it was, just a street. Yeah, the bloomed flowers was pretty cool, and the windy road is cool, but it definitely is not as great as it's hyped up to be. The best part about this street is the history and the view you get to enjoy when you are at the top. You can see the bay, Alcatraz, and if you're in the right spot with the right weather, you can catch a glimpse of the Golden Gate Bridge. You need to come here in August-September because that's when the flowers are bloomed and they are pretty nice to look at. Just remember, it isn't a gold-plated street like everyone hypes it up to be, and there are A LOT, and I mean a lot of tourists here so try and make it here early and try and get dropped off at the top and walk down, it's too steep to walk up and not get tired.
author: Melvin M.

description: Beautiful place to visit in San Francisco. Amazing architecture and great view of the bay. We took many pictures with loved ones. This was our fourth visit in 5 years. We loved it as always.
author: Dr. Kay S.

description: This place is packed with a lot of tourists. Parking is hard to find, and remember to bring your selfie stick.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Because I miss the bay...

When you visit San Francisco you have to stop by Lombard Street.  It's known as the most crooked street.  It winding back and forth and makes for an awesome picture.  If you turn the other way and look down the street it's also an awesome view of the city and Coit Tower.  

Tourist flock here to take pictures and locals are just trying to get out.  I've been here at least 5-6 times and on my most recent visit there was a uniformed woman directing traffic.  If you go on a good day there is little to no crowd.  It's definitely worth a visit to drive by and see it.  

It's also close to some other neat sightseeing things.  

Must try: check it out if you're in the neighborhood.  Don't forget to bring a friend so they can take a picture of you.

31 yelps - 5/31
author: Jasmine N.

description: The best way to appreciate Lombard Street is to approach it from the top. That is, if you walk along one of the nearby streets, e.g. Hyde Street, you will get your first glimpse of the unique 'slalom' street from that "looking down" point of view. There are pavers and beautiful manicured gardens at each tight bend, with a pedestrian path along the side of the steep street so you can make your way down the hill, while you watch drivers slowly negotiate their cars around the bends. It's a great way to showcase San Francisco's city hills and architectural ingenuity.
author: Ali H.

description:
We got out of the heat for the weekend and flew to San Francisco. We did the tourist traps since it was the first time we were taking the puppets to see the "City".  (We can check this site off the list!)  

Great views but the line to go down this street was crazy! More than a half hour and the worse part is you really couldn't appreciate it much going down. Lots of folks walking so maybe that was the funnest? I think the better view might have been in a crowded trolley? This will go on the list called, "Been there done that!"
author: Bunny G.

description: Well, at least I can say I did it. Getting to Lombard Street is a nightmare, especially with those steep streets. Going down wasn't that bad, but probably wouldn't do it again. The view also wasn't as good as anticipated, but I could feel the history of it.
author: Dirk N.

description:
Don't miss out on a drive or walk down Lombard street. It is unbelievable how curvy this road is. The pictures do not do it justice. Try driving down in neutral without hitting the brakes!!! 
The houses and street are landscaped with beautiful flowers. Drive from top to bottom then park and take some photos looking up this picturesque street. This is a top 10 site in SFO.
author: Scott M.

description: The officers who patrol the street for traffic are so funny and nice! make this touristy trap worth it!
author: Farwah N.

description:
Ever wonder where that crazy curvy road on top of the hill in San Francisco was called? It's called Lombard Street; it's brick paved and beautifully decorated with flowers. 

After we snapped our photos and drove down hill, we saw the crazy car pileup just to drive down Lombard Street! I would be afraid to be in the line because it's a steep incline for several blocks. 

It's worth seeing, but probably not worth waiting to drive down!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
This street, and view, are beautiful.  The grounds are well kept, and you quickly learn to feel sorry for the poor souls who live here and need to back out into the road.  We walked to take pictures, and then, because why not, drove down it!  It was a fun drive down, slow enough to enjoy.  Definitely different than the steep inclines/declines of neighboring streets.  

Beware the almighty tourist.  There are those, such as myself, who stick to sidewalks and cars (you know, where you should be).  Then there are those who stand in the middle of the road, laying to pose, throwing up peace signs like it's 1965, and making the almighty duckface.  They will pretend they can't hear you, that they speak no English (ok that may be true) and that the laws of the road don't apply.  But, unless you want to be charged with aggravated assault or vehicular manslaughter, alas they are crawling all over the place.  Driving or walking, expect to run into them!  

Absolutely breathtaking stretch of road, and a must-do!
author: Courtney L.

description:
One of the most beautiful streets in San Francisco.  Not only is it the most crooked, but it is also the most beautiful!  Pretty flowers line the street, and watching the cars drive down is pretty cool.  I always try to make a trip here when I'm visiting.  It's a free cool thing to do while in San Francisco.  

It's easy to get to either by car or by cable car.  There are always tons of tourists here.  

Lombard Street is one of my top favorite places in San Francisco!
author: Emily S.

description:
This was definitely an experience. I would highly suggest walking it instead of driving though. Our GPS took us to Lombard Street in a weird way to get to the top of the windy road in order to go down the curvy part we had to drive up this insanely steep hill I was so terrified I was holding onto the door handle the whole way up. I recorded a video of our drive down the curvy parts and I still crack up today watching and listening to our experience. I think my favourite part of this attraction is the conversation in the car - we were giggling most of the way down because the walking tourists were stopped on the sides taking photos of us in the cars going down. I actually felt like a celebrity it was so funny. 
The other downfall of driving down curvy Lombard is that because there is just so much tourist traffic you don't really get a good opportunity to pull over and get out to take pictures from the bottom. I wish I would have known this before we went (we were also following a tight timeline that day based on my itinerary LOL) but people who walked down on foot were able to stand around and had an opportunity to take as many photos as they like. 
I'd probably do this again the next time we're in San Francisco - no such thing as too many memories right!
author: Hannah H.

description:
Yes, it is a total tourist spot.  Yes, it is overpopulated with tons of people walking up and down, taking pictures, and watching the cars drive down.  However, Lombard Street is straight up awesome.

I visited Lombard both ways - walking and by car.  The first experience was walking.  We hoofed it from Embarcadero and it was an impressive sight even from as we approached from afar.  It was fun to walk up the stairs, look at the beautiful homes on either side (and envy the people who live there - that blue house with the pink/purple flowers will someday be mine, I swear), and watch the drivers attempt the twisty descent.  We took plenty of photos from the top and admired the great view - it was beautiful!

The second time we went was the next night, by car.  It was fairly late in the evening, so there weren't a ton of other cars around.  We followed the car in front of us down at a very slow pace.  No one was behind us, so my boyfriend quickly zoomed around the block to go down again - he wanted to take the turns MUCH faster.  We made it about halfway down, brakes squealing, but came across another car going VERY slow and had to halt our NASCAR-speed attempt.  One more time around the block to give it one last shot - but by then there were several cars very slowly taking the trip down.  My boyfriend and I were bummed we couldn't race our way down the hill, but alas....

Anyway, you have got to check this place out.  It's totally cool and definitely lives up to the hype!    Best of all, it's free!
author: Sonya L.

description: Pretty fun tourist spot. As a local Bay Area resident, I've been here a few times. It's not the funnest thing, and there are so many tourists, it's hard to get a really personal shot of the view. The VIEW is amazing! Coit Tower, the Bay Bridge and Treasure Island all in one shot. I'm sure there are other less touristy spots along that street to get a similar view.
author: Amy P.

description:
Lombard Street is a beautiful, windy road in SF. People drive the tiny yellow go-carts along the path, and it looks so fun! 

My boyfriend and I ran here,  and it was definitely worth the trip. 

Whether you're in the area or are visiting for the first time,  definitely check it out!
author: Vivian W.

description: Fun and exciting ride down the crooked street. Beautiful floral show.  Great view of the Bay!!
author: Dick F.

description:
I'd question why tourists flock to one location to see a street with some curves in it, but I've gone twice, both as a pedestrian and as a driver. 

Walking to the top of the zig-zag part is a pretty miserable. The only way to get there is obviously by going up a very steep hill. Cable cars run up and down the street, but on a weekend or time of day when tourists are around, the car will probably be full by the time it gets to you because a ton of dumb tourists have stood in a massive line at the starting point filling it up before it gets to any of the stops going up the street. You will just have to walk unless you specifically get a cab. Worse, the view when you get to the top isn't really that interesting. It will look better from the bottom looking up, so you'll have to walk down to really look at it anyway.

Driving is just as unpleasant. Again, a ton of tourists will be forming a parade of cars to drive down the crooked curves. The hills are steep and it's a little stressful -- your car will roll back anytime your foot is not on a pedal. It's a slow couple blocks up with the parade of cars. But worse, the drive down is pretty anti-climatic. Do it to say you did or to scratch a curious itch, but keep your expectations pretty low.
author: Charlie S.

description: I feel sorry for those who live in this iconic tourist attraction. I can't imagine having people walking 2 feet from my living room windows and not having an easy time getting out of my garage. Oh well. You are rich you will find a way :) #sorrynotsorry. Nice place to take family and friends when in town otherwise no reason to be in that area. Great pics for memories and social media. I heard it's less busy during the week rather than the weekend.
author: Ramla J.

description: This is quintessential San Francisco. You see this street in the movies and not to mention there is a trolley car right at the top. It doesn't get much more San Francisco than that lol. This is a must if your visiting. FYI it's hard to get a picture of the whole street, but it can be done.
author: Kirk M.

description:
Loved this landmark. Serio-- wonderful view of San Francisco and you can see the Coit Tower in the distance.

I think it would be best to walk down Lombard street. There were way too many cars trying to crawl down Lombard... You get the best photos if you park your car close by and then walk. And yes, obviously you would have to face off a bit of incline climbing but it's well worth it. :) 

Input the address: 1099 Lombard Street to get to the top of the incline going down the windy road. Do not try parking first, and then climb up to Lombard like I did... it was painful :( 

ps- take lots of photos! :) Nothing beats a photo with a nice view, flowers, and your awesome friend/lover/family member who is probably going to be with you.
author: Julie Y.

description: We drove down the hill, my wife recorded the whole ride. It was a blast and I'll be back, I love all the folks around watching. It's amazingly fun, and scary at the same-time.
author: Tom T.

description:
It's a curvy street.

Good view of the city but super crowded with tourists standing in the middle of the street taking selfies.  Whenever I come here I always wonder about the poor schmucks who actually live in the homes on that street.
author: Sean S.

description:
Lombard Street is an east-west street in San Francisco, California. It is famous for having a steep, one-block section that consists of eight tight hairpin turns.

It is a serious hazard to pedestrians, who are accustomed to a more reasonable 4.86° incline. In fact it's one of the most steepest roads in the US. Most are only accustomed to a certain inclination. 

I've been training for this prior at the gym before leaving for my trip by increasing my inclination on the treadmill. I have a heart condition and although I am fit, inclinations and hills like these have to be met with serious caution and consistent monitoring of the heart for me. Average beats at normal pace for me 95. 110 - 120 at athletic level. On the hill it came to around 160. 

To get to this hill my best friend and I walked other hills in San Fran surrounding it..a warm up given though those were challenging enough for me. 

I'm glad that I stuck with this 'cause when I made it to the top it was one of the hugest victories for me. This will make the Grouse Grind at home a cake walk. 

The top of the hill is where you will get the best view of San Fran.
author: Shila B.

description: A fun experience! Must see if you are ever in the SF....fun to take pics and try to manage to go down the hill looking cool lol
author: Nancy L.

description: Definitely a tourist attraction. It is a site to see at sunrise with the rest of the city in the background. It was fun, very crowded. I suggest to go early in the morning. If you can, take the trip down the road in a car, it's just fun! Be prepared to stop and take a lot of pictures
author: MaliaAdrian M.

description: Yes it's just a street but it's a must see when in San Francisco! It was hilarious watching people drive down it. It's not the easiest place to get photos at as there are always people everywhere and they will most likely be in your photos. The flowers weren't in full bloom which was a tad disappointing but it was still a fun experience!
author: Carla W.

description:
My experience:

Yes, Cool ! , Wait, What? Over? Let's Do It Again!

Wish it would be longer, it felt longer when I was young of age, now it goes by to quick, but worth the trip.

Make it a point to check this out when in SF or even if you live in the city, admire it.
author: Sal M.

description:
Wow, to Drive up, before coming down the winding road, is the scariest free fun We had in San Francisco.
This Street is very cool, and easy to find if you come right after the Golden Gate Bridge, since the 101 becomes Lombard St. 
You will love it, specially if you drive it!. The views are breathtaking!. 
Be aware that is full of tourists, who don't mind cars, 
You Must be aware, that every one there, looses their common sense, and will get in front of you for the best picture!. 
Definitely a must see with the family in San Francisco!.
I you want to walk it. That's good too. There is a couple parks around that have some parking spots.
author: Chaly B.

description:
As long as you don't get stuck behind the Hyde street car, this can be a fun little detour - my mom insisted on a trip down Lombard when she visited last December and these days - it's only at the request of an out of town guest that I go down Lombard.  I don't think I have even gone down on my motorcycle yet - I guess I'll have to fix that.

I think that the views from Lombard St are more impressive during the evening/night than during the day - all the lights are on and the city looks so pretty.  During the day - well, it doesn't really seem all that different from anywhere else in the area.  The houses aren't especially spectacular.  As everyone knows - it's not *the* most crooked street - but it is pretty and it's nice to visit every so often as a reminder.
author: Jenn C.

description:
An amazing spectacle, Lombard Street is one crooked phenomenon.

As fun as it is to play tourist and take lots of photos at the bottom of the street, it's even more fun to be able to drive your car through all the zig zags! 

A must see for anyone in the area!
author: Ann S.

description:
Tenzing Norgay. The unheralded heroic sherpa who guided Edmund Hilary up Mt. Everest. Have you ever stood at the base of the windiest street in the world, looked up with the hope that you could be the first to ever drive up it, and all it would take to push you over the edge was your own Tenzing Norgay? Well, I have, and I had my sherpas in a rental car, late on a Sunday night. 

I grew up loving Pike's Peak (the winding zig zag race up a mountain). I grew up in Indianapolis. And while my dad likely had doubts I would ever achieve his dreams behind the wheel, little does he know, that after almost a year, I am proud to admit: I drove up Lombard, uninterrupted in between streaming headlights coming down, without any damage, and in record time, a record I suppose because we haven't found anyone else who has ever done it. 

There were tire squeals, curbs jumped, roaring laughs and not one camera to capture the inevitably unbelievable feat. If you're unaware, it's the most visited street in the world, there are no turn offs, and the stream of cars going down doesn't stop through each day & night. 

I'll take Up Lombard as a nickname. Maybe it'll even grace a headstone some day. Once to the top, I could only look to my shotgun & rebels in the backseat, and be thankful I had my own Tenzing Norgays to sherpa our way Up Lombard.

Note: I do not condone, recommend or subbscribe to such acts as this.
author: Jon A.

description: Took us 35 minutes to get to the entrance and it was closed off to cars. The other day it was open. Disappointment.
author: Josh H.

description:
Finally saw the zig zag street!!

There were a ton of people here when I arrived at the top of Lombard, and it was kind of early on a Saturday morning. Guess that goes to show how popular this street is; and I can totally see why. It's such a cool road to look at and it's even more fun to stand at the bottom and watch the cars slowly wind their way back and forth as they drive down. I ended up walking down from the top, but most people start from the bottom and walk up so I was going against the flow of traffic. 

Definitely a must see when you visit SF!
author: Sam F.

description:
How can you not take a drive down this street when you visit San Francisco?  

First, the streets is closed on Saturdays during the peak tourist season so ask your hotel concierge to be sure before you head out.

We took Lombard East, turning South (right) onto Polk, then left on Filbert.  This takes you to a four-way stop with a left onto Lombard, one block south of the winding road.  This seemed like a better option than the long line along Lombard.  

Be careful of foreign tourists and idiots here....driving as a tourist in San Francisco is tricky enough but with the gawking and pedestrian traffic this is not relaxing for the driver.  Our first drive was on Friday in the afternoon the traffic was moderate.  Our video failed to turn out so we repeated the drive on Sunday......traffic was heavy and the cops were out to direct traffic.
author: James F.

description: Everytime I visit SF I have to come to Lombard street, such an amazing street,I LOVE IT! its fun driving through the street especially at night went during a monday to SF, but man was the street Still crowded I loved it though, and if you walk through the street they have a brief histroy about it, over all if you visit SF you have to come to this place :) and be careful taking pictures in front of the street there are a bunch of cars there ahha not too worried or fond about your picture taking moment haha
author: Maryam Q.

description:
Plz Do not visit this place with your luggage leaving in car 

We went there around 6 pm and parked car next street . We just walked away from car 15 min and saw that our cars rear window is broken and everything was stolen 

When called police they said its 53 incident  of the week  and they can't go directly to each incident spot so they asked us to drive to police station  

Folks .. Listen 

This street in evening is haunted . U will see people in hoodie .. No lights in any of the house 

Better don't visit in evening or don't park ur car . Just directly drive through that street
author: Arpit P.

description:
We had a small rental car and able to go down the street. Super cool. The neighbors are not (I dont blame them having strangers on your street constantly). 
But the view is awesome going down.
author: Prusha S.

description:
Its amazing how people walk up on hilly street just to check out the croockedest street in the world. Poor land mark signs around the place though. If you wanna go to this place try going using cable car(i think hyde and powell). This way you can enjoy riding the cable car too. Go to union square do shopping/eat and take the cable car from there. Cable car has stop right at top of croockedest street and then you can walk down on this street if you like. I felt this was an overrated attraction. Personally I think they made this street on purpose to attract tourist. They could have made similar street on the other side(you will see).
You can go there from Coit tower too. Not that far but be prepared to walk on slanted hilly roads. People just come here to drive/walk on this street. You also get the amazing city view from top of croockedest street.
author: Rasesh P.

description:
I wasn't that thrilled with this, actually.  I wish I'd gotten better pictures of it, to prove we were there, for one.  We went past this area of Lombard on our Segway tour, but it was night time and we were a few blocks away so really in the dark you couldn't tell that the street was crooked, and my picture that I hastily took sucked.

We returned in a car on a Saturday morning, around 10:30 or so, and it was okay.  The access point at Hyde street is easy enough to get to.  There were other cars descending, but they weren't a problem, they just moved on through.  The main issue was all the tourists on foot who were literally standing IN THE STREET trying to get pictures.

Get out of the way!  This is a road - people are trying to drive down it, mainly for fun, but still.  It was annoying.  Overall, it's cool but also maybe over-hyped.  I also would like to know why it is the way it is.
author: Johanna K.

description: This is another great place for sightseeing when you're in SF. You can take your car for a drive on the snakelike pathway and you can park somewhere down the street (for free!). I recommend coming early to beat the traffic and for photo opportunities!
author: Eva L.

description:
Lombard st. twisty turns will get you twisted.

Or at least feeling a little dizzy.

The cable car operator pointed out that this is the second most crooked street in SF and he is right.  (Vermont st. between 20th and 22nd st. is more crooked!)  

It is best to go down through these curves in a Porsche, preferably with your ex, just to up the fun factor   =P

Kidding aside, it is best to walk up and/or down this street.  You'll have more time to appreciate the vibrant colors of the Hydrangeas, charming homes and other intricacies such as this horse detail on a hand rail.  (see pic)  oh, don't forget views of Coit Tower and the Bay Bridge.

Once I got to the bottom, I even had my pic taken by an actual tourist! 

I love SF.
author: Janice C.

description: It was really cool to drive down this beautiful crooked street. It is a really cool experience
author: Madeleine S.

description: If you are in San Francisco you need to drive down Lombard Street. It's pretty cool and is a big hit with kids. I've always been too chicken to drive down it myself so I'm always in the passenger seat squealing the whole way down. There's always lots of traffic on the street so you won't be going fast, so don't worry. There are some decent views but the thrill of cruising down this super crooked street ranks in with a thrill factor of about 3 out of 5 stars.
author: Louisa M.

description:
Yes, it's predictable, but yes, it's super cool and pretty.  Amazing views!

The holder of the Guinness Book record for "crookedest street in the world," this street is always going to be busy with visitors and photographers.  But you're still going to love it, and I would encourage you to actually walk down it.  That's it's own fun.
author: Stephen H.

description:
Beautiful spot to visit if you are a tourist or a local who has never been!  We didn't drive down, but we did walk up one side and then down the other.

This is a MAJOR tourist attraction, so there are tons of people there at all times of the day.  You get a great view of San Fran and even Alcatraz once you get to the top of the hill.

I love when the trolleys are driving by on the top of the hill.  Feel sorry for the people who live there, but it's an amazing location.. just a beautiful scene to look at.
author: Mindy T.

description: I was a little underwhelmed but I am glad that I went. Walking down, yes down the steps to the side of the street was quite a workout I must say. There are great views from the top and bottom of the street, and it does look pretty cool when you are standing at the foot of the street. We only walked, didn't drive down it. It's a tourist trap, but I feel like you have to quickly see it while you are in town!
author: Vanessa M.

description: It's a landmark and a must see while in SF. However, its WAY better to walk it than drive it. Take the cable car, walk around, and hop back on. Or even better, walk down to the wharf after. Driving can take you hours waiting in line and there are much better things to do while in SF.
author: Leah B.

description:
Why would you want to go see a stupid street, I wondered, then I saw it.
cool cool cool cool cool

Its marketed as the worlds crookedest street and while I have not witnessed every street in the world, I would say is certainly very crooked.  I believe it has 8 very sharp turns and warns drivers of the 5mph speed limit, which even seems like it would be too fast.

I felt bad for the people that live on this particular street, there are tourists everywhere, a cable car stop right at the top (and I would imagine the bottom as well, but we took the Powell & Hyde to the top) ensures an endless barrage of people.  But the more I think about it, they did choose to live there, and if they can afford to live there they probably have too much bloody money, so I no longer feel bad for them.

Any way, amazing views of the city from the top of the hill.  The houses that line the street are very cool and they have done a wonderful job of keeping the turns fully in bloom with flowers and trees.  I think I even saw a grapefruit tree, although it may have been pomellos, I don't know my citrus well enough to determine the difference.

Walk up the stairs on one side, take pictures, walk down the stairs other side, take pictures, repeat as necessary.  Just be polite and remember people do live there, don't linger in their driveways.  A must see for the SF tourist and definitely makes for a great photo.
author: Jasmine B.

description: Honestly, just another touristy thing to do. It's a great view of SF and beautiful houses. All in all maybe a little overrated. It's a simple slow drive down a windy road. Enjoy it while it lasts because it doesn't last long!
author: Tina N.

description:
Must-see in SF :) Just make sure your brakes work and you aren't driving a HUGE car, driving a smaller car makes it a little easier to get down. It tends to get busy during high season, because a lot of tourists want to take pictures and whatnot. But it's still a nice detour to take, plus you get a nice view of the city from the top of the hill. Just make sure you're coming from the west side of Lombard to hit it.

It's pretty well maintained, and sometimes they have traffic people to help with all the cars. Definitely a quick must-see location :)
author: Amanda L.

description: Beautiful area beautiful homes and the view from the top of lombard street is amazing I had the chance to drive down this spiral street which was really cool. If your happening to take the cable car trolly up and down the hill like streets it stops on top of Lombard street.  So many tourists in the area I can imagine what the residents on lombard street are saying everyday?? But for the people that has not seen this place has to check it out.
author: Edwin R.

description:
You know that really wind-y street in San Francisco? You know the one that curves......? Yep.. The name is Lombard street. Im' gonna tell you why I personally think it's more of a tourist destination and an annoyance for those who actually live on the street than anything else. 

* If you're from Outta town and it's your first time visitin the 415.. More than likely someone local from Frisco might suggest you to head towards Lombard Street. 

***Seriously, it's just a really really windy curvy road. I've driven down this thing a few times and it's nothing special unless you like waiting for people to back down their drive-way. (Yes, there are people crazy enough to actually live on this street) It gets pretty backed up at times. 

*It's worth seein' once up in SF but like the 2 star suggests I've definitely experienced better streets. Hit up Olvera street the next time you're in LA and you'll see the flash of LA as opposed to the fluff of this SF street. 

Dueces
author: Justin Y.

description: It must suck for all the people who actually live on this famous, curvy little street. Tons of bad drivers in rental cars driving by your place all day, a bunch of confused no-English-speaking tourists no-English-speaking-it-up beside your house all day, cheap cameras going off nonstop. Lombard Street will have you thinking,"Wait, seriously, that's it??" within a minute or two.
author: Andy O.

description:
I came here twice on my visit to San Francisco, once as a drive down the street with my cousin driving and showing us around and the second time with a tour group.

It's a great experience, but be careful when you drive - other people be driving down this crooked and steep hill of a street while holding their video cameras out the window recording the damn thing! Then you got people actually going up and down the street to take pictures, when there are obviously signs that say "STAY OFF THE STREET!"

I feel bad for the people who live there...tour buses can't drive down the hill so they dropped us off at the top and we walked (safely) down the sidewalk right in front of these beautiful homes and this tourist couple comes out from a garage which wasn't closed! That is so rude! Just because it's open, doesn't mean you can go check it out!

Anyway, stop by if you have the chance, but please drive carefully, stay off the damn street, and respect the privacy of the residents who live there!!
author: Faye M.

description:
This is seriously one of those places you need to check out when you head out to SF. 

It's claimed to be the most crooked street in the world, I believe it. 
I wanted to drive through it but beware the line is rather long.
So instead I parked and walked down the street. From the bottom you get a better angle/view for your pictures. 

I seriously wonder how the poeple that live on that street do it? 
Constant traffic jam infront of their houses with a mob of tourists. 
Thanks for sharing your street!
author: Jackie R.

description: Heard about this when the cable car driver mentioned at the stop here. Came back later to drive it. There was a traffic cop directing traffic because it's very popular, apparently. Makes a fun side stop! Crookedist street in the city! Maybe anywhere, actually, although the road to Muir Woods is pretty crooked too.
author: Ken J.

description: This is the prettiest street ever! come in the summer where the flowers are in full bloom, you don't need to spend much time here, just come by and a snap a few pictures (it's free!).
author: Bebe B.

description:
I like seeing Lombard Street after hopping off the Cable Car, taking in the amazing Bay view, and then walking down. I'll admire the architecture and the flowers, and watch the tourists. Then I'll either continue onward or climb back up.

If I'm driving, you'll find me over at Vermont Street on Portrero Hill. That's the other crooked street and I have a great time scaring the crap out of my out-of-town guests as we go around the block a few times.
author: Eric B.

description:
One of the BEST iconic scenery of San Francisco.
This place cannot be missed when visiting San Francisco.

Dont come during a heavy fog because the view can hardly be seen. Make sure to plan your trip on a sunny and clear day. And ride the cable car going up here.
 
Have Fun!!!
author: Chexll M.

description:
Yeah, I was one of those annoying tourists who made Lombard Street my first stop after getting out of the airport. In my defense, it was not only my first trip to San Francisco, but my first trip to California... so I had to be one of those tourists :)

First of all, do what one of the other reviewers said and take Hyde instead of going up the ridiculously high hill. My friend's brakes were squealing and smelled like rubber after that trip. That, and we had a tourist who isn't familiar with the laws of gravity following way too closely behind us. Once we got to the crooked part, I wondered (like everyone else) how on earth people managed to live on this street. I'm willing to bet they don't drive much, because holy cow, I couldn't imagine getting in and out of this place easily.

Once we got to the bottom, we parked illegally (like everyone else) so I could take a quick picture. A local glared at us, although at least we didn't block traffic like some others... but c'mon, if you live by here, you have to know it comes with the territory.
author: Cherine A.

description: One of the most famous landmarks in SF.  It's iconic, beautiful to look at, and free.  I like free.  I would recommend either taking a taxi here or looking at it from afar instead of taking your beloved car.  Also going during the weekend is so much better.  I saw the line to go down here and it was ridiculously long.  Great place to sightsee.
author: Jackie N.

description: Terrifying drive up if you do the drive from the bottom and then through the street. Feel like you're on a roller coaster that's going to inevitably fall back down, but once you're on the top, it's really crazy how crooked this really is. No parking, so my gf waited near by idling while I snapped some photos at the bottom. Great views in the distance of SF too.
author: Dan M.

description:
Landmark windy street in SF.
For optimal viewing, drive it at 3 am. 
Make a few laps.
It's the best way to see it.
author: Sara P.

description:
It was cool. The end.

Being a dedicated yelper I couldn't just leave it at that but in all honesty that sums it up. Lombard street is the "crookedest" street in the world which is dictated by the crazy steepness of it (are those legit words?) We chose to walk it instead of drive and I think we made the right decision. We walked faster than most cars drove and we didn't piss anyone off when we stopped to take pictures. Photographic opportunities did abound. It truly is a beautiful view. An added bonus (yes I know I am showing my age) you can see the Real World San Francisco house while strolling down the street. 

I think it is definitely worth seeing but if you did happen to miss it just google it...it's not that much more impressive in person.
author: Tracie F.

description:
It's a local-flavor street like this that you can't miss taking your own-of-town guests too. Sure it's just a crooked-bricked-street lined with beautiful flowers tourist trap,  but the "Ohhhhs" and "Aaaahhhs" gasps of amazements make you appreciate what a local gem this street really is. Park at the bottom of Lombard (90 degrees, it's a picture-lean all in itself) and walk up to get the best bottom-of-the-street picture view. About face and you get a wonderful pic of Coit tower, right face and you get a great picture of Alcatraz.

Just don't forget it's a working 4-way street! Overzealous picture takers forget that cars actually need to get through. If you have a car and are willing to wait, the drive down is fun.. but the easily carsick will feel a bit pukey at the bottom.
author: Vivian A.

description: Another favorite memory of my trip to San Francisco with my son years ago.  Must have driven down this street at least 10 times and I couldn't get enough of it!  Great tourist attraction and I wouldn't miss it!  It was a lot of fun and I look forward to doing it again soon!
author: Violet R.

description:
Not worth a special trip, but if you happen upon it during your trip to SF, definitely stop to take some pictures!

There were so many people here today (Thanksgiving). It was rather annoying. I felt bad for the people who live on the street. Those who drove down were blasting music and being rude.

The road isn't so steep/curvy that I would consider it dangerous or difficult to drive down. In fact, I think any car can handle it! So go ahead and drive down :)
author: Annie W.

description:
A San Francisco legend and totally worth the hype!

This is a must-see on any SF trip, and as a local, I frequent it often too! It's a fun, quirky street! And, I live near by now! It's actually not the street with the most twists; that honor goes to another street in SF whose turns are not as sharp though. 

It's fun to:
- Drive Down
- Walk Down
- Snap Photos (came here after Senior Ball long ago and took our pictures here)
- Snap Photos of People Snapping Photos
- View the former, original Real World house
- Take in the Views

This street is a pleasure and it's lovely at night too (and far less crowded!).
author: Rebecca G.

description:
So pretty! Fun for the whole family. 

Long trek if you walk it up but well worth it! Be prepared for a long wait if you drive it down. Do it slowly and make sure you have good breaks LOL.
author: Jeanette H.

description:
Tourist Spot, look for the mini van with the three kids and crazy parents. I felt like a celebrity because of all the paparazzi, "tourist", taking pictures of everyone driving down the street. 

It was cool sticking my head out of the window while taking pictures of the street and other cars going down. It must suck to be a home owner living on this street with so many tourist and drivers in the area. They probably crave the attention. Why else would you have a house on a crazy, busy, winding road.
author: Alberto E.

description: Before you even consider visiting Lombard Street, know that you will be walking up extremely angled elevations- I'm talking like 30 degrees. After you catch your breath, the view from the top of Lombard will make you lose it again. Absolutely stunning! The city has also made sure to beautify the area by planting gorgeous flowers and vines throughout the street. The houses, the view, the plants...definitely recommend.
author: Zak C.

description:
I've lived in the bay area for over 10 years but never went to Lombard until yesterday LOL!!! No, we didn't drive through it.. we just passed by and managed to glance at many tourists trying to take photos of the famously crooked street. 

In the winter time.. it's not as colorful as the flowers were not blooming..but it was interesting... we did do the "steepest street" rollercoaster like ride (about a block away from lombard) afterward though.. it was really fun LOL.
author: Yun C.

description:
I've happened across Lombard Street on many occasions. Somehow, I'm just always nearby, whether to cross through it by car, or staring up the kinky road from below, Lombard Street almost seems impossible to miss.

It's wacky.
It's silly.
It's a squiggle on a map.
It's a totally kooky, unique, and quirky street.

It symbolizes all that is San Francisco.
author: Emily T.

description: So fun! Just be patient. It is usually crowded, but it's worth the wait when it's your turn, I promise. : )
author: Christy B.

description:
I have been here several times and I think the most ideal time to visit here would be during Spring and Summer times.

You can (fairly) easily walk up to the Lombard Street from Fisherman's Wharf within half an hour. You get a GREAT view of the city once you walk up to Lombard Street. Best time to visit would be during the early morning - perhaps around 8am or 9am when there are not too many tourists around - so you can actually get some good photos taken here.
author: Maria G.

description: Lombard Street is another one of those must see SF spots while you're touring the city. It's a sight to see with the cars driving down it. I suppose if I had a car and I drove it I might be more impressed with it, but as a pedestrian it was a great photo op and that's about it. You won't need more than a few minutes to see it, picture it and move along. As with anything in SF, be prepared to walk a small mountain to get to the top.
author: Joshua C.

description: Fun!  We parked way below, walked up and then walked down.  It is tough on your knees going down.  Must do experience.
author: Jasmine C.

description:
If you're in a hurry to slow down, perhaps to a standstill, this is the street more traveled. Happened upon the winding road whilst gallivanting about in SF and boy was it awesome. I think I saw more than half a dozen tourists come close to mowing over flower beds. It's a one-direction (not the band) street, but I've heard rumors of others driving "up" Lombard. Dig it. 

Much less exciting, but certainly more scenic, is walking up/down Lombard. On foot, you'll experience severe impact on your knees, but you get to experience a bit more in my opinion. 

Plus, if it ever rains enough, it would make a killer water slide. I'll volunteer.
author: Benjamin G.

description: This place is awesome but I hate that there are cars ruining good pictures. If you're in San Francisco you must come here, it's worth it.
author: Lilly M.

description:
I would love to know how people get a moving van near the houses on either side of Lombard Street. That's what always came to mind when I was with familly who wanted to see it on their visits out to California. 

Local Insider Tip: Don't bring anything larger than a Prius if you don't have an impeccable ability to drive (by other people's standards, not your own.) You don't want to be the one jerk that can't turn your car tight enough and you end up getting stuck.

Lombard Street is a completely illogical, manufactured, bizzare attraction. It's a one block brick street that winds down a hill, while all others just go straight down. I'm not too sure what the point is of it, but it's a curious sight to see.
author: Rachel S.

description:
This street is so weird yet interesting. Starts from the top and zigzags it's way down. There are a lot of people wanting to try to drive from the top to the bottom so it can get pretty slow and hectic here.

Not only that, but when you reach the bottom, expect to find TONS of people blocking the intersections just to stop by and take pictures.
author: Scott N.

description: Lombard Street and Gardens are a true landmark in San Francisco that you can't miss.
author: Gavin M.

description: Beautiful, great view of the street. Gorgeous flowers. Definitely hit it up. Wouldn't live there because of the hoards of people that come to check it out. The zig zag street is cool though. Got some brownie points of snapping a couple of great pics of the wife!
author: Allen C.

description:
"Big wheels keep on turnin'
Gen-Y'ers keep on burnin'
And they're rollin'...rollin'
Rollin' down Lombard"

I was convinced to come see the 7th Annual "Bring Your Own Big Wheel" Race today. It happens every Easter Sunday at 4PM...and yeah, I had never heard of it either until Jamie W. told me that crowds gather at the foot of the crookedest street in the world to see an army of thrill-seekers careening those sharp, brick-laden curves in their customized Big Wheels....yep, I mean those plastic, low-riding Mattel tricycles for ages 5-8.

I guess I knew I was part of the hip crowd when I saw Justin of Justin.tv carrying his own Big Wheel up the hill to compete. Actually "compete" is not the right word since it is really more similar to the running of the bulls in Pamplona. However, instead of a potential goring by an aggressive Spanish bison, I imagine a skinned knee and long-term podiatry issues are the most one could endure in this sport.

As a spectator, I endured a suffocating atmosphere of carbon monoxide as autos were stuck in their tracks among the throngs of onlookers on the street. The actual race happens so quickly that you would barely notice it were it not for the roar of the crowd. But it is a typically eccentric event among many in San Francisco, and you sure can't beat the price. See the pictures I posted if you don't believe me because...

"They're gonna take the beginning of this race up on Hyde
And do it nice n' easy
Then they're gonna do the finish down on Leavenworth nice n' rough
That's the way they do BYOBW
'Cause they're rollin'...rollin'...rollin' down Lombard."
author: Ed U.

description: There's not much to see here except for the quirky, winding street and the nice houses on either side. Still worth a visit if you can integrate it into your trip.
author: M B.

description:
Lombard Street is like a ride at Disneywold... But better, because it's free! No tickets needed, and no overpriced gift shops!
Seriously, though, "the crookedest street in the world" is a must-see for any visitor to San Francisco. It' easy to get to with a quick trip on Van Ness St. either by car or bus, straight to Lombard. You'll be amazed by the slope of the hill leading up to it and if you're on foot, you might be quite winded by the time you get to the top. But, what a thrill to see the gorgeous view of the North Beach area of the city leading right down to Coit Tower, across the sparkling Bay and the Oakland Hills off in the distance.
If you have access to a car, you absolutely must drive down the street. Have a friend hold a camera out the window to shoot a video of the drive down. Too fun!
One slight disappointment is that, because of the angle of the street, you won't get a really super great picture of the street - not like the ones you see in postcards. You'd honestly have to be standing at the top of Coit Tower with a super zoom to really see the curves.
No matter. The street is packed with beautiful hydrangeas and other lovely flowers, so your pictures will look great. Plus, the experience alone is worth a million bucks!
author: Jen N.

description:
It was my first time here and I love it! I love being that "new kid on block" feel where I have to whip out my camera to camera-whore, check-in to places with my phones, and ask people what's there to do for fun in the area. To cut it short, I love being a tourist. 

There should be a shirt that says "I survived SF hills". Holy crap, my 1998 Honda accord will never be able to go these hills. Well, not that it can't make, but I don't think it can handle all the screeching as it accelerate up. Apparently, all these cars that are waiting to drive down the zig zag street don't care about the burnt tire smell or that possible chance of rolling back and hitting a car. 

Man, as I arrived, I feel as if these people with cameras were for me. There were so many snap noises and countings of one two three cheese! The street was so busy that cars had trouble going through. So if you do go, please be considerate and step to the side. I know pedestrians have the right of way most of the time, but don't abuse this power, be considerate.

Tips: don't bother taking pictures from the top of the hill.. Go down and take it down there. You will get the whole view of the zig zag hill. Just be careful for oncoming cars.

Oh yeah, sucks for those people who live on that hill. Errr sf in general. Kiddos to your driving skills. :)
author: Tammy L.

description:
Lombard Street does have it's charm. A steep winding road paved with bricks and surrounded by plants. It has an awesome view too. You should definitely try it out. 

While you're in the neighborhood you can drive up or down some of the other steep roads nearby like Filbert St between Leavenworth and Hyde.
author: Yoni D.

description:
Jack and Jill hit Lombard Street
To take their car for a drive.
Speeding down the cobblestone,
Oh, how did they stay alive?

Tourists waved, in fear, I think,
As Jack motored down the hill.
Jill laughed and waved back, then cried
"These curves are a real thrill".

Snapping pictures as they drove,
They threw safety overboard.
Only when they reached the end
Was their common sense restored.

So, Lombard made them silly,
Will it do the same to you?
Bring your lover, you'll agree.
Thank you, Lombard Street.  Adieu.
author: Paul L.

description:
The girlfriend's father flew in from San Diego, so we were off & running on a frenetic weekend NorCal sightseeing spree.

Driving into the City, our 1st stop where we actually parked the car & got out was Lombard Street. Super tourist-y for sure, but a must for out-of-towners. No other city in the world has a street like this with the kind of views that are around it.

Just remember to go slow & be patient. There's no shortage of folks standing in the middle of streets trying to get a good picture. Just like us. After obstructing traffic long enough to get the shots we wanted, we piled back into the car & were off to the next spot.
author: John M.

description: God just get up 45 min before dusk and catch the sunrise here. There's no one up at that hour and it will take you 15 mins to drive down it. Otherwise just drive by it. (Uber driver 9 months)
author: Nick B.

description: Definitely worth the view & if you really must drive down in your car I'd suggest going down in a low gear, even in an automatic car. Otherwise find parking on one of the adjacent streets & take a few pics from the top & then walk down the left side (which seemed easier) & take a few more half way down.
author: Riz B.

description:
The short: It's the curviest road in the world..........and it is full of people

The long: WHY GOD? WHYYYYYYYYYYY?!?!?!?!?! I guess everyone should go see this once in their life. I'm just over it having to take every visitor that has ever come to visit to see this thing. To add insult to injury they never fully understand that SF is a walking city so you have to get out of the car. So inevitably I end up at the top of Lombard street waiting on someone to get up the 1500 stairs to the top. Hey at least I have the entertainment of watching people run out into the middle of the street to take pictures and not get hit by cars. I'm pretty sure I would be a serial killer if I lived on this street though. Between the cars burning rubber of the people who just don't know how to handle a car on the steep streets to the people mindlessly wandering into the street I would loose my mind. Seriously though it was cool the first time when it was cool and there were not a ton of tourists up at the point, but after that no thanks. I know a little dramatic, but after having to deal with this street probably 15 times in the past 6 months for visitors even you would be over it. Add to that SF has SO much more to offer that isn't so crowded.

What works: Something neat to see once and then never again
