What to improve: Maybe a stop light at the top to manage traffic flow or someone shooing the photo happy visitors out of the flow of traffic?
author: Patrick M.

description:
Holy crap, this street is gorgeous. It was a quick 5 second drive-by, but still a sight to see. 

The most exciting part is the drive to see the bottom of Lombard. We had a 12-person van and decided best to NOT drive down the zigged zagged street. Instead, we drove parallel to the zig zag and oh my god, it was scary! The crescent down felt like it was a 90 degree incline. Even the passersby stopped to watch us and probably secretly hoping to see a 12-person van flip over. 

Maybe next time, we'll stick to the smaller cars and make the zigged zagged drive.
author: Lily C.

description: I love San Francisco and the Bay Area in general. I always visit my family every other summer and am sure to come by Lombard street. It's always fun to drive down the twisty road and take some cool scenic pictures.
author: Zack A.

description: I lived in the Bay Area almost all my life but I've never been here until tonight!  Driving down the street you get a great view of the Coit tower ahead, gorgeous expensive homes on both sides, and just great SF views.  I"m sure this place is packed during the day time with 10000% more tourists, but I'm glad I got to see this spot regardless.
author: Katie N.

description: Almost every street in SFO looks like Lombard, but its really fun to drive around the snake like road. Almost feel the adrenaline rushing like that of a roller coaster. Excellent view of San Fran and the route is awesome with tons of flowers enchanting the path. It was a hassle to wait perpendicular  to enter the street, we were slightly frightened that the car would roll down and its crowded always. I can't imagine how people living here parallel park everyday, freaks the hell out of me. All in all a wonderful experience.
author: Geetha K.

description:
People who go 5mph or stop at every twist on their way down bother me just a touch. That's why we avoid going on weekends.. it's always more fun to go when you're (as the passenger) slightly intoxicated, and either have the window or the top down. The breeze, the turns, the colors, the view. Fun!

I wonder what it's like to live in one of those houses off the crooked street. It's a great spot... but I'd bet we (and by we I mean people who drive down there for kicks) get annoying.

I've only walked down it thrice... fun as each time was, I still prefer the lazy thing + the cool breeze.
author: Asha S.

description:
Yes, it's a beautiful site when you get to the top and as you're heading down the ziggity-zag street.  

However, the getting there from the ascending steep hill is monstrous when there is a line-up of cars screeching every time it moves a car up!  Very scary... I don't even know how people could park their cars in their garage every day!


My son and mother were with my fiance and I... the relief we got when we reached the top was when my son blurted out that he almost had a heart attack!!  we all just started laughing, especially my mother whom I never saw her crack up that much before.  There was a great irony in that moment!


Also, for some reason, I don't think that is the steepest street as I recall a taxi driver going through other streets just to give us a "ride" through SF.
author: Art E.

description:
Rent a car. Drive it down this road...slowly

This is one of my favorite things to do in San Francisco.  At the end of the road you will see tons of tourists taking pictures of this incredibly steep and beautifully gardened road....but the cooler option is to drive or walk down it.  You will most likely have to drive at 3 miles per hour, but you will have a load of laughs driving down the crooked street.  You'll also find out how squeaky your breaks are :)  A wonderful free activity in a rather expensive city.
author: Mary L.

description: Aw how adorable is this? there really isn't much to say but do prepare for pedestrians and a bit of traffic ... also make sure that your car brakes are working fine ... aaaannndd prepare yourself to be photographed since there is a quite a crowd at the bottom of the street that are taking pictures. Anyways, it is not death defying anything as you slowly crawl down the hill in this ziggy zaggy winding street, but it was fun and exciting nonetheless. If you are a tourist, come check it out. It is a sight to see and may even earn you some bragging points.
author: Queenie D.

description:
If in San Fran. must stop and see.  Curvy yes!  Beautiful yes!  Most curvy, probably not but close...street one or two blocks over was just as curvy.

Lots of tourists.  One tourist was getting out of the car and filming, and everyone in the car took a turn so they all were in the car driving it.  lol

Took the cable car to get to the top.
author: DJ J.

description: I think it's a little overrated. It's an attraction that you should see if you're in the area. The street is nicer during the day. Please don't be too loud as people do live on this street.
author: Jenifer T.

description: Beautifull street with a view. Tip: go early in the morning. Sunrise and great view over the city and harbours.
author: Stephan Z.

description:
Eh. I wasn't really impressed by the windy roads of Lombard Street. Why are people so impressed by a street that has turns and is a pain in the arse to go up and down. And what's with all the tourists? 

It's nothing new to me because I live in Denver and there are plenty of windy roads just as good if not better than Lombard Street. I would recommend Googling pictures. It saves you a lot of energy and money too. The ones in Denver are covered in snow too which is a lot prettier than flowers that many people are allergic to. 

I saw someone selling lemonade near the street. She obviously didn't have a business permit to sell it. Sam Francisco is a city where they don't enforce the law. I don't feel very safe here tbh.
author: Bob H.

description: Being a historical landmark in San Fran had to come here of course. It's actually very beautiful if you take the time to enjoy looking at the gorgeous flowers growing around it & the windy sharp zig zag street. the entire time we were there, there were actual people driving on that insane zig zag hill coming down. Me in a million years would not attempt that. It looks deathly frightening to drive down this incredible steep looking street. Its definitely an experience I can say that. It wasn't so crowded when we went. You have a gorgeous view of the bay & some of the city if you make it up to the top & look down. A lot of ppl taking selfies & standing in the middle of the street trying to take pics & eventual get killed or run over lol.
author: Mary A.

description: I've lived in the bay area my whole life and had never visited this popular tourist spot. We went yesterday with my friend's family from out of town and it was pretty cool. We didn't have to wait in line that long and driving down the road was unique. You get a great view of Alcatraz while you're driving down. There's also tons of people walking it. Some dudes got in to a shouting match and one punched the other's car with his fist but that was the random event that happened before we drove down. If someone has never been to SF, this is worth checking out, "crookedest street in the world."
author: Marty J.

description:
It's always lovely to come here and play tourist here.  I enjoy the hill-walking exercise going up and down this Lombard Street hill, and then also including some of the steep hills on nearby blocks (especially the two-block-long Hyde Street hill running from Bay to Chestnut).  Going up that long hill is a true butt-kicker. :)  Great bay views looking out towards the east and the north on the top of this Lombard Street hill.

As a trivia note, however, even though this block of Lombard is called "the crookedest street in the world", technically it's not even the crookedest one in SF.  That honor goes to a section of Vermont Street in Potrero Hill.  However, I prefer coming here to Lombard Street anyday myself. :)
author: H K.

description:
Driving down here is lame-whatever, who cares-especially if you are the one driving (which I often am, taking family from the east coast here.) Ahh, but walking up and down this stretch-now that's a different story.
I've been wanting to do this for some time and yesterday on a beautiful sunny day, I had my chance. 
After a city hike through the various areas of Russian Hill, I wound up here and went down on one side, back up the other. Seeing the actual houses close up was pretty cool as well as getting to see the views, which my often dirty car windows has always obstructed. 

Afterwards, kept heading up Lombard to Sterling Park and took a quick spin through there-met 3 friendly dogs and their owner as well as more fabulous city views.

Do yourself a favor if you're in town-walk up and down Lombard and then head over to Polk Street for some Fro Yo at the Loving Cup to reward yourself for the effort.
author: Jennifer N.

description: The drive down didn't take as long as I thought. People were driving at a good pace. And my boyfriend and I parked at the bottom of Lombard St. and walked up so I could get some pictures and it seriously felt like I just got done with leg day. It was such an epic walk. But its definitely worth seeing so that you can say that you've been there!
author: Jenelle G.

description:
At the top of Russian Hill, the decline is too steep for a normal vehicle and the curviest street in the world was made.  Ok, I guess you have to see it when visiting SF, and I don't blame you for driving down it.  it's an interesting site of architecture and urban planning.  However I can't help but feel bad for the people who live there.

There are houses that line the road.  Each curve leads to a driveway on the curvy road.  There is a constant stream of cars going to down the road all the time.  At the bottom is aways a flock of tourists taking pictures.  I would hate to live on this road.  I feel bad for the owners on the street or the people who actually live there.

I can't blame people for going down it though because it's unlike any other road in the world.
author: Ryan L.

description: SF historical place. Geeeezze. How much are these houses on this street. You need to be disgustingly filty dirty rich to live on this street. Big tourist place but still great for the locals. If you have not been here then take your right hand and slap your self now. Then go to Lombard street!!
author: Brandon M.

description: I prefer Vermont between 20th and 21st, but that's just me. I mostly enjoy going for a spin down Lombard on my motorbike. Driving down in a car is a buzzkill.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
This place is fun & funny. If you are driving, have a little patience getting there as traffic can be difficult and quite congested. The street is short, but the kids will love the experience.

A must do if you are in the area!
author: J T.

description: A must-see for visitors. Beautiful views and will put your guests in awe. I've never driven down it, but the wait is usually long. Still, it's worth checking out.
author: Ryan S.

description:
There is nothing worse than being stuck in traffic on a hill.  That is precisely what will happen if you try and do the touristy thing and drive down Lombard Street.  Of course, that's exactly what we did.  The only thing worse would be to be behind a complete retard who attempts this feat with a stick shift.

All and all, I am glad we went.  The whole time I wondered "who would want to live on this street" and "who cares for all these lovely flowers?  Are they suicidal?"

I got some pictures, but I totally should have just walked my fat ass down the to the bottom of the hill and taken some photos looking upward.  Oh well.  Such is life.

This is one of those things you really only need to do once in your life.  Therefore, I probably wont be back
author: Allison H.

description:
Great place for tourists. 

I live in the area but my little niece was visiting from up north a ways and had never driven down Lombard so I took her on this little adventure. We went around 3:00pm on a Saturday, it was positively beautiful out , sunny and slightly warm with a breeze. 

We got lucky because the wait was only seconds.

Worth checking out if you have never been.
author: Meghan L.

description: One of the more fun things to do in SF if you never have and recent rumors of the street's closure made this a must see since the BF had never been down the most crooked street in the world :) glad we fought the tourist crowds to do it.
author: Livi E.

description:
It's bad enough that the hills are hella steep in San Francisco. Lombard Street takes the cake for being steep, crooked, and crowded with tourists.

Going back home to visit, I felt the pressure to take classic "SF" photos for my new friends in NYC. So off I went with Jess M to cruise around the city on the one way streets and hills. 

The crooked road was uneventful. First of all, you gotta find your way to the top, wait in line, and then drive down slowwwwly. I was the driver so I couldn't really enjoy it. I was just trying to keep control of the big heavy SUV I was driving. I swear sometimes you wonder if gravity is really on your side driving on these hills. Once you get to the bottom of the crooked road, its like dodging tourists. They are oblivious to oncoming traffic! It's just a crooked brick road, people! It's not yellow and it's not in Kansas.

Going down the crooked road was a lot more fun when I was a kid. It was actually a highlight every time we drove into the city. It was like being on a mini roller coaster.

Now, its just a tourist trap. The view is pretty but you end up wishing all the other tourists are out of your picture.

If you visit, I hope you at least get to see the tour guide who has a microphone connected to her speaker fanny pack. Yes, her fanny pack was a speaker. And she was loud.
author: Rachel A.

description:
One crazy attraction!!!

Never gets old every time I come to SF.  Just funny that there are a bunch of people now taking photos on the street blocking traffic on the way down.  I always thought that wasn't allowed.  Someone is going to get rundown one of these days.

Coming from Van Ness, it's like a roller coaster, driving up lombard is like a super steep hill and approaching the crooked street.  Then going down the crooked street.
author: Japen G.

description: as you come to visit Lombard Street, be aware that there is a lot of movement either cars or people running around taking pictures and driving up and down this famous crooked street. I had the advantage of parking by and just wailing up the famous steps and taking pictures like all tourists.
author: Zochi F.

description: I like to walk the steps up and down Lombard st not so much driving it. The street is very short and great for bikes to go down. The houses on the street use this as their driveway, with the amount of traffic it doesn't make driving convenient. During the spring flowers are blooming in all of the landscaped beds. It is a beautiful street.
author: Dove N.

description: Cool place to drive down once but that is about it.  Nothing really that memorable driving about 5 MPH "weaving" through the curves while trying not to take your eyes of the road to enjoy colorful flowers and lush landscape that line the street.  Don't drink and drive!
author: Ken L.

description:
It's a novelty, and a favorite with the tourists and postcard printers. 

Check out Vermont Street, between 20th and 22nd, if you really want to drive the crookedest street in San Francisco without having to nearly run over tourists more focused on their cameras than safety.
author: Christine A.

description:
This is a crazy place, flooded by tourists, who are hiking up and down the street on the side and the cars slowly making their way down. We felt it is a bit overhyped, but still fun to see.

If you're already driving on Lombard St a few blocks on the western side it will take you some time until you reach the zigzag part, but there are some shortcuts from the North & South.
author: Julie M.

description:
Definitely one of the most majestic view of San Francisco. Definitely just a roll by and observe, take a quick picture and roll down the street is a necessity. I cannot see myself spending more than 15 minutes here to get pictures taken and driving down this street. 

If you want a great view of this, you're better of visiting during the spring time or at least near summer since the flowers and landscaping will be blooming and vibrant. The classic cable cars do pass by at the top of this Lombard street so if you get a chance to ride the CCC, then I suggest taking a quick gander as you whisk by to the next stop!

If you want to feel adventurous, drive down this street during the night; no one there and a beautiful view of the city lights ahead.
author: Viet T.

description:
It's a squiggly street. Though not the squiggliest street in the city, it sits between what certain children refer to as "a lot of up and down streets."

If you're into these sorts of things (or just enjoy seeing children- or other people- get excited about these sorts of things) this little stretch of Lombard Street might just rock your world.

Beware of wayward pedestrians in the road.
author: Loli L.

description:
Awesome place!

Well, it's just a street. A very unusual and appealing street.

It has a great view of the city + the Koit tower. 

Parking can be very difficult, however, because of all the tourists wanting to stop by and take photos.
author: Christian R.

description:
Since this was on our way from where were staying to Alcatraz, we had to stop by... ok I kind wanted to too.

I heard about this attraction, and my first thought was that it was completely ridiculous this became an attraction at all. It is ridiculous... but still cool. The city has done a lot of work putting in really beautiful plants between the switchbacks. There is a nice set of stairs to get you off the very congested street. And it is fun to see all the tourists taking photos, and the creative ways they pose... and dodge traffic...
My favorite part is the sign in front of the school on Lombard street that had to put up "Absolutely no photographing children on the playground".
author: David M.

description: What a fun little spot to stop off at while visiting San Fran. Take a cable car there, I think it's the Powell line that runs right along the top or drive and park somewhere near by, or drive down it :) that's always fun too. We visit Lombard every time we are in town because... it's just a fun little stop, get in a quick climb up and down the street, snap a few pics, take in the views and be on your merry little way. We love it!
author: Candace L.

description: As someone not familiar with driving hills, it was already stressful for me just to get here. I can't imagine driving down the zigzag. Park somewhere near Leavenworth St. and Greenwich or Chestnut. Walk to Lombard and Leavenworth, then take as many pictures to fill your tourist heart. I think coming here earlier in the morning, maybe even on a weekday would be best.
author: Stephie D.

description:
As touristy stuff goes, you could do worse. But I would not suggest doing this one with a car. The lines get long and the experience isn't as good anyway.

Take the cable car to Hyde and Lombard. Get off. You're now at the top of the hill. Take a few pictures. Walk down. Take some more pictures. Get to the bottom, turn around, take more pictures.

Now you have stuff to post on Facebook. You'll probably get at least 10 "Likes", and you'll have at least two clueless friends who have never heard of Lombard St that post inane comments about your pics. Mission Accomplished.
author: TJ P.

description:
This is iconic SF.
Along with Fisherman's Wharf and the GG bridge, this is probably one of the most recognizable streets in SF and even the world.

Driving down it comes with the challenge of dodging crazy Asian tourists dotted around.

At the top you get a nice view to Coit Tower and the water on 2 sides.
Worth a visit at least once if you are in SF.
author: Nick L.

description: I had a very romantic stroll with my boyfriend while in SF. Such a nice view :)
author: Cris C.

description:
The street is really impressive.
And beautiful with all the flowers.

It is always funny to watch all the cars driving down this crazy street.

The view by the way is very pretty too.
author: Kevin G.

description:
There's nothing like playing tourist in your own city! I've been here once when they had to block it off because they were filming a scene for a movie. I was never able to figure out what movie it was...

Late last night my friends and I decided we wanted to drive down lombard street. You feel like a kid at the top of a roller coaster! The anticipation builds up until you're actually on it and by the bottom of the street you feel that it passed by all too quickly. It's a very short route. Even so, It's a special SF landmark that I'll always love.

I'm jealous of the people living in the houses along this "crooked" downhill street. Beautiful homes. But imagine if you were late for work and had to somehow squeeze your car out into the long line of cars waiting to take a drive down the street hah!
author: Samantha L.

description:
It's not the crookedest street in San Francisco.  That would be Vermont Street (at 20th Street).  Plus, it wasn't always curvy.

It's definitely fun to visit when you don't live here, but when you do live here, it's kind of a headache.  So I might go with a very Fisherman's Wharfesque one star, but I'll add a star because of the amazing interview in the extras of the DVD for The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill.  The woman reminds me of my cousin in many ways, and she lived on Lombard Street (the woman, not my cousin).  So I guess the street played a part in the birds' story, and that's meaningful.
author: John S.

description: It's pretty awesome to visit the most steep curvy street in the world. It's a must see with beautiful homes surrounding. The architecture is amazing
author: Angel H.

description:
I thought it was funnier... Man, what a traffic jam in that street! Even the Cable cars were stopped!
I couldn't even find any good spot to take a great picture of the place.
author: Oleg K.

description: I visited the Lombard Street once in winter and once in autumn. The traffic was terrible in both visits. We had to park long away from the spot and walked there. To drive through the street would be very slowly and less flexible cuz you couldn't stop and take pictures. The curling street was interesting, but less attractive without the flowers.
author: Tian Q.

description: Beautiful street, wonderful view at night time i bet its even nicer in day light. It is a must visit place if you are in San Francisco.
author: Ny N.

description: Beautiful view. Windy road.  It would be a lot nicer w/o the gazillion tourists hogging up your photo opp or cars trying to run you over. :-)
author: Michelle H.

description: the architecture is beautiful and the colors of the buildings go so well with the hydrangeas in The center.  Beautiful to look at and the crooked streets are pretty cool to drive through with the kids!
author: Laila R.

description: It's the crookedest street in the world, why wouldn't you go? It's fun, quirky, historic, unique and beautiful...very San Francisco :)
author: Tracy C.

description: Lombard is one of those tourist traps that people have got to go to if they can.  My first experience here was probably over 20 years ago sitting in a car and driving down this famous street.  As a passenger, I remember it being fun, but slow going.  The second time was passing by while on a cable car.  This was really fun, too, but I kind of wished I had more time to enjoy the view before the car moved on.  Then, I was finally able to walk up the steps along the street.  It was a great way to 1) get a great workout - yes, the street is steep! 2) admire the amazing scenery, architecture, and beautiful hydrangeas (especially beautiful on a clear day!!!), and 3) people watch :). However you decide to visit, it's worth coming at least once if you can!
author: Christine L.

description: Surprisingly *not* the most daunting street to drive on in the city but definitely a must-see
author: Jenna T.

description: Kinda cute, it's fun to drive down atleast once.
author: Anthony A.

description:
It's an interesting site to see, that's for sure, and I wouldn't miss taking a look from the street car - but is it really that amazing? I don't think so.  

Tons of tourists come here, and the views from this hilltop are great. I'm not saying you shouldn't stop by, especially during a first visit to SF, I just think it's overrated.

A friend said driving down this street was so much fun he had to do it twice.  Well, having plenty of time on our rental car left, we made the trip up and thought the drive down was just about as exciting as driving round the Macy's parking garage.  You decide what that means!

I would say driving the hilly streets of SF is way more interesting - you'll never see anything like that anywhere! I guess I was under the wrong impression that the "crookedest street" was actually a fully zig-zagging long street, not a small curvy driveway-like lane.
author: Joan H.

description:
I do not understand why this is not one of the seven wonders of the world, I keep wondering why somebody would have a one way street in a very curvey downhill ride. 

I do not make it to San Francisco often, as I am not a huge fan of traffic and crowds, but when I bring people to the City, I make sure this is one of the locations I bring them too.  Everybody knows this street, but it is funny how very few people actually know how to get to this location.  I have a few secrets to this location that everybody that is bring people here should know.....

1. If you have the time, do not come here during the weekend, as the traffic up Lombard Street from Van Ness is crazy, and with a nice incline you will have to drive up, will freak most drivers out.
2. If you are bring visitors from out of town, and you can only come here during the weekends, I would recommend come here early in the morning, as most people will hit this location after they visit the Golden Gate Bridge, so the earlier the better to visit.
3. Now my last secret, here is a great one even if you are not away of anything else, this one should be followed, if you are coming here during the weekends, and in the afternoon...then find Hyde Street from the North or South of Lombard Street, at least a few miles away, then come in that way instead of just trying to come from Van Ness Ave to Lombard Street, this way has a short wait, plus you are not waiting and trying to drive my a very steep incline.

Enjoy the visit and drive down this great street.
author: Michael N.

description:
When showing friends and family around San Franciso, this is a must see place!!  It's supposed to be the most crooked street, but I think I read somewhere that there is actually a street in SF that is more crooked than Lombard.

There is always plenty of people here everytime we visit.  The street is lined with beautiful flowers, and the views of the city are good from Lombard street.
author: PatrickJ T.

description: Of course Lombard is 5 stars awesome!!! I took one of my friends and photo clients down the zag of a street and she was having a blast!
author: Rebecca P.

description: One of the most unique streets with stunning views of the most beautiful city. Not to be missed.
author: Gopi V.

description:
'The Crookedest Street in the World!'

...or so it's known as. You definitely have to drive down it if you're visiting San Francisco. I'm a native and like to drive down with friends every once in a while, keep driving, and head up to Coit Tower for a nice walk and view of the Bay.
author: Sade R.

description: This is the street Leah and I lived on. Worth seeing. We are kind of a big deal.
author: Danny B.

description: What a beautiful street! Definitely a tourist attraction! I just love how it's so well maintained, and so busy all of the time. The walk down the street wasn't a problem and the sight was breathtaking. It really is crooked! The walk up though, wasn't that bad, but it required more energy out of you. There are cable cars available the top of street once you're done looking at the street. I recommend visiting this street. It's pretty cool.
author: Cathy M.

description:
"We're tourists, dammit.  This is what we do."  And with that, we continued up the 45 degree incline known as Lombard Street.  What my passenger didn't know is that once we reached the top of the hill and drove around the tourists that were on foot, we would go down the very famous and very ridiculous part of Lombard Street known as the crookedest street in the world.  It's in all the pictures here.  My passenger (a big wuss) was on his first trip down Lombard street and I was determined to get him back because the day before, he sang the Rice-a-Roni theme song on the cable car as loud as he could.

So we crept up the hill along with all the other  tourists in all the other rental cars.  The incline was so severe that we couldn't lean forward in the seats.  We couldn't touch the dashboard.  He was getting nauseous and I was enjoying every minute of it.  Then we reached the top, the front of the car crested the hill and pointed down, and he could see what was next.  He screamed like a little girl all the way down.

Thank you Lombard Street for the best memory I have of the worst co-worker I ever dealt with.
author: Don W.

description:
Wow.. I cant believe I havent wrote a review of Lombard St as well.

If you go during the day, it is very busy. A line to go down the hill, parking is minimal, a ton of people at the top and bottom of the street taking pictures.

I have always wondered how the people that live on that street feel about having so many people on their driveway! But you live on one of the most famous streets in the US!

If you go at night time, obviously there is no waiting. On top of that, the view is great for pictures looking out at the Bay or towards the city.
author: Roger A.

description:
Welcome to Sam's Signature route and you are driving along Lombard Street which is the most "Crookedest Street" in the World. This is my avorite street in SF because you get the tourist excited each time you drive down Lombard street. It make me happy to see my friends/family in the passenger seat with the camera clicking non-stop when we are driving down Lombard street.

Suggestion: It is fun driving up Lombard street from Van Ness since it is going upward and everyone is leaning back on the seat looking at the sky but it can ruin your brake pad/shoes and transmission gear. This can be really bad if you have to stop and move many times. My suggestion is to take Hyde street and turn into Lombard. You don't have to stay in line with all the tourist. 

If you are driving from 101 South (Van ness), make a turn to Broadway and then left on Hyde. Hyde street is mostly 1 way street but near Lombard it is 2 way street. You can also drive thru the first Swenson Ice Cream shop while on Hyde Street. Hyde Street is where the cable car run so sometimes you have to be patience when driving behind them. 

Also from the intersection of Hyde and Lombard, you can see both Coit Tower and Alcatraz on a clear day. A good photo opp is to take the photo of the cable car going up Hyde Street with Alcatraz on the background. I will post a photo one day. Have fun and drive safe
author: Sam M.

description: It's a little difficult to think of what to say about Lombard Street because well, it's a street. But, Lombard street isn't just any street, that's why it so many reviews - and is one of San Francisco's most popular tourist destinations. The best part about seeing Lombard Street when you're on vacation compared to anything else is that you can be at Lombard Street for 20 minutes or less and be completely satisfied. The curvy part of Lombard Street is one block and can easily be walked in about five or less minutes. I recommend starting at the bottom or top - does matter which is first and then walking up or down. Make sure to check out the view from different angles as you go up or down because you can see in the distance you can see both Coit Tower (which is only about a twenty minute away walk) and the San Francisco - Oakland Bay Bridge. You definitely could drive down Lombard Street (one way only) which is a fun experience but walking it is much better because you can stop to take pictures at the top, bottom and all the beautiful landscaping along both sides.
author: Michael G.

description: I would hate to live here.  tourists are mean!!  I was shoo'd by an old asian man because I was behind him when he was trying to take a picture.  It's crazy busy but it is a landmark.  Very beautiful street.  Another photo op place while you are in the bay.
author: Chrissie O.

description:
Minus one star for the constant stream of tourists who flock to this curvy street like bees to honey...,  Or maybe they're more like a rumbling herd of Wildebeest mindlessly chasing a Zebra... ...:)  The herd cannot be stopped!
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildebeest

 I lived a block down from here for a few years and it was always somewhat surreal wading through waves of tourists from all over the world who were hanging out in this little hood.

The folks who live on this beautiful voluptuous block must constantly go insane trying to run errands, while dealing with the slew of rental cars driven by glassy wide eyed people from Des Moines to Tokyo, and beyond.

So, I must take a moment to apologize for that one night I drove through here..  Let's just say it was approximately 2:45am and I didn't take the regular route..  But damn, it was fun cranking some music and ripping up this hill on rails...in the ole' audi quattro.

Check the general vantage:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zTIN_rpW3koEcoEmGN3DwA?select=DbXrpmDQNiZcE_v_oCaRlA
author: Georgio N.

description: It's a very funny and unique street, chances are you'll probably never see any such street elsewhere in the US. It is very crowded and I think it's more fun to drive in the car than walk. Of course, for photography it would be better to get a good view at the bottom.
author: Venkata M.

description: Super tourist hotspot! Be aware of traffic slowdown cause of the tourist in the intersection taking pictures. It is a ridic hill to get up to see it.
author: Angela L.

description:
When I was a child my family came to San Francisco and we drove down Lombard St as part of our comprehensive coverage of all tourist attractions in the area.  At the time I believed it was an amusement park ride.

I do not have any real need to come here unless with a guest from out of town, but  inexplicably it really is a favorite among non locals.  As a local I like this excursion because I can do it from the car, ie I don't have to get out and actually interact with the hordes of tourists the way I would at Fisherman's Wharf.

The line to drive down can get surprisingly long (ie back to like Larkin or Polk) but it moves quickly.  That said, since you do end up waiting on an incline often, I would not recommend to do this in a manual transmission car.  The hill also provides some very nice views of the city if you do choose to walk in this area.  

If you would like to take friends for a drive down Lombard but you don't have a car and are debating whether or not this block alone is worth the rental, I would recommend combining this with a drive through Golden Gate Park, the Presidio, or across the bridge into Sausalito / Marin.
author: Molly B.

description: The famous winding Lombard Street is must see for visitors.  Great picture opp at the bottom!  Can get pretty crowded on the weekends.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Must do when family is visiting from out of town. I prefer driving down it - I think you get more of a traditional tourist vibe. But I've also walked down it plenty of times. Just have a plan in place so you don't have to walk up - it's steep. 

Since it's right by Pier 39 we tend to head over there with out-of-towners right afterwards.
author: Jennifer F.

description: A must see for any tourist! If you get the chance to drive down- DO IT! This spot is usually FLOCKED with tourists so be prepared for that, but it's worth the time and tourist dodging to see as it's a local landmark!
author: Kate N.

description:
We were walking around the city and were excited to happen past it. I recommend walking down on the sides. You get the best pictures and can take your time while watching the crazy line of cars going down super slowly trying to get their pictures. There are going to be some pushy people, but you can probably get one of them to take your picture like we did.

I also liked that as you go through the rest of the city you can catch glimpses of it, aided by the blue house with purple flowers (super distinctive and eye-catching).
author: Aly M.

description: Well taken care of with lots of beautiful flowers and people driving down really slowly.  A nice short walk from the wharf.
author: John K.

description: You got to try it , it's better if you medicate before you start your journey. The driver should try to keep his foot off the gas pedal. .....
author: Jeff B.

description: Big tourist attraction, but definitely a sight to see. I kinda feel bad for the people who live on this block and have to deal with everyone taking pictures of their street all the time, haha.
author: Katherine D.

description: Uh, this is amazing. I don't care if it's full of tourists. Had the time of my life. My one complaint? All the cars going down the road. I wanted to see it without.
author: Stefanie S.

description: I remember seeing pictures of this zig zag road in my sisters Guinness book of world records book way before the internet age. I finally got to see it and actually drive down it.  I was a little nervous because I was driving a mini van but I made it.
author: Kazuo O.

description:
You know you're in San Francisco when you know you see the crookedest street in the world, Lombard St. This is something very unique the SF only has. Also it's beautiful when the cable car passes by on top. I've been here like 3 times I climbed it twice and went down like once and seen it from a distance many times. 
Yes, it is manmade but it's something else to add on your checklist of San Francisco.
author: Nadav M.

description: The locals must hate living on the 2nd most crooked street in SF.  But if you got to see what everyone has heard of, plan on wearing some good shoes and walk, plus it's a good hike to the tower  the other item on the list.
author: G C.

description:
Truly an American landmark. A must see when visiting this beautiful city!

You can take the cable car to the Lombard stop then walk up it. A venture to mark off your bucket list!

Make sure you do not attempt it on a full belly.... Looked like someone did when we got to the top.
author: Jennifer C.

description: What a view; what a view!  The most crookedest street known to man.  What an amazing view.
author: S T O.

description:
What a curvy street! If you google map this street it looks like a snake hahahaha! 

My boyfriend and I drove to the top part of street first. We parked and walked to the street. BEWARE when you are parked, especially if you're 90degrees to the steep streets, opening the car door is hard and can be dangerous. Be careful not to smash another car with your door or smash your fingers, depending on which side of the car you're on.... 

There were soooooo many tourists around taking photos and enjoying their time. We snapped a couple of shots and walked a few steps up and down the stairs. 

We then went back to the car and actually drove down Lombard Street. There were so many other drivers driving with their go pros sticking out. Fun times. Fun times. 

We of course had to park again at the bottom of Lombard Street. THIS IS A MUST. The views from the bottom and top of Lombard Street are so different. You have to experience both if you can. If not, I would choose to see it from the bottom because the pictures capture the essence of the street very well. From the bottom, you can see the cars actually spiraling down. They look like toy cars. It's so cute! 

Again, be careful when coming out of your parked cars! And take lots of pics!!!!
author: Jennifer K.

description:
This is a total tourist trap!  But the experience is all there!  Every time I've visted San Fran, I've always only driven down the street.  However, this time we parked our car and took pictures on the top and the bottom of the street!  (We were actually lucky that we found parking.)

Lombard wasn't really crowded, but it had a good amount of people taking pictures in the middle of the intersection.  It was a challenge to get your best picture taken, with Alcatraz in the backdrop, when all the cars wanted to pass by on Hyde St.  But once that cable car stopped for a pick up/drop off at the intersection, it was a great photo opp!

I love the experience of driving down and taking a look at all the homes on Lombard.  It's a thrill to look up from the bottom and see the curves of the street and the beautifully landscaped paths.

It's actually my dream to "stay" (not live) at one of these houses for a while.  Must be a hassle for residents who live there.  But it's the price you pay for living on Lombard!
author: JME C.

description: Definitely a must see. Or shall I say, must drive. Gives you great views of the city from above. I always feel like the car is going to roll backwards so I get a little white knuckled driving up, but so worth it!
author: Lindsay A.

description: Visited the end of March 2014. We went at night when there was no one there. It was quite fun and interesting. I hadn't known about this street when we went, but someone mentioned it and I knew we had to go! I wonder how the people living right there feel about five billion cars driving by their homes everyday?
author: Reneesha R.

description:
i love this quirky street.
i dont know how many time I have been down this zig zag street but it never stop impressing me.
we have drove down it.
we have walked down it.
we have taken so many pictures.
we have video'd every turn we make in the car.
always enjoy the view from it.

will probably do a quick drive by whenever we are in the area. :)
author: Ann N.

description:
I thought that they were kidding about the hills? Really. Well, when I got to San Fran, my butt hurt like never before. I bet all the ladies in this city have a nice posterior or at least a strong one. 

Lombard Street is out in the middle of nowhere, at least to me. It is basically a very, very steep hill that drivers must circumnavigate by driving through a maze, outlined by pods of flowers. Pedestrians can climb the small steps to the top or down to the bottom. It is definitely a touristy thing to do, but it is something to see. 

I think the best time to go is at night. One of the good things about the hilly city is that you can pretty much get a good view of the city from anywhere in the city. Lombard offers a pretty romantic view when you reach the top under the gaze of a starry night.
author: Stacy T.

description:
This street is very wiggly
From afar it looks quite jiggly!

I drove past this place one day
At once my head snapped and I said HEY!

Circling all about, I found my way to the top
And weaved my way downwards, my head in a bop

My friends shouted Wheee!!! With their hands in the air
I still can't believe that I've actually been there!
author: Grace Y.

description:
Ahh Lombard st.  how I love thee.  
Beautiful roses at your sides, so inviting.
Your sexy curves make my heart race.
The Arch of your back is all I long for.
Stay there my love, I'll come to you.
author: ARTURO H.

description:
It has curves in all the right places and pretty flowers too.  Plus it's free to see if you can walk the hills in San Francisco.  I cheated and took The Powell-Hyde cable car line there, which stops right at the top where the curves begin, see I'm useful. 

I needed to know where the crookedest part was so I looked it up and also learned that Lombard St, also known as US Route 101, starts at Presidio Blvd and runs east from there with the crookedest part being on Russian Hill between Hyde and Leavenworth St.  Somehow the street ends up down at The Embarcadero but I just walked as far down as the next cable car line, I had already seen The Embarcadero.
author: Me H.

description: Love driving down this street.  Kind of confusing because you have to enter a certain way to go down.  I am sure the residents hate it but it is very interesting.  Once you get to the bottom, we parked and then took pictures on the corner with the street in the background.
author: Mooki x.

description: Very cool attraction! We walked here from the Hyde Street Pier and walked down (we didn't rent a car on our trip) the sides of this famous street. Definitely worth a look!
author: Krissy M.

description:
This is such a fun road to drive down on.  It's also very pretty.
Once you're down, look up and see all the people walking, all the beautiful flowers, and parents strolling with their kids - beautiful scene.

It's a great spot for photos, and again, just fun.
author: Greshka P.

description:
A fun (touristy) side trip best seen early on a weekday.

Lombard Street is quite popular and gets crazy busy, with wait times of more than an hour for cars. Go early in the day, and you can have it mostly to yourself. When it's busy the going is slow, as people stop their cars for pictures and video. The view from the top is excellent, but watch for the hordes of tourists taking pictures of Alcatraz in the middle of the street.

Please be respectful of the neighborhood and the people living there.
author: Monarch B.

description:
It's in Russian Hill and is noted for the crooked block between Hyde and Leavenworth. Known as the most crookedest street in the world.  Real World San Francisco was filmed at 949 Lombard St.

While, I don't LIVE in the city, I think it's a great place to take people that have never seen it.  But, once you've done it, it's a tad over rated.  Especially when it's busy as **** and cars are waiting and I mean rolling back on each other waiting to climb up for the 8 seconds it takes to navigate the curves and drive down.  It's best to do this on an off peak night/day and not the weekends when every tourist in town is there trying to do the same thing.  

I kinda feel sorry for the folks that actually LIVE on Lombard.  That's cray.  All in all, great photo opportunity and something to check of the travel bucket list!  And it's FREE!!
author: Charmayne Y.

description:
Tourist spot! The famous crooked street! 

Its fun to take the cable car up there and walk down the street to take pictures! We came on a weekday afternoon around 3PM and it wasn't crazy busy so we were able to get pictures without all these cars in the background. =)
author: Leanne D.

description:
Yeah, I know it's just a street.  BUT IT'S SUPER CURVY!  ^____^
We didn't drive down.  We walked down and, like the crazy tourists we are,  waved at the people who were driving down in convertibles and whatnot.

It offers some great views, and of course, some great photo ops.  I just couldn't imagine living on this street, though.  The houses are unbelievably beautiful, but you have to put up with a constant stream of yahoos like us tramping all up and down your neighborhood.
author: Christine G.

description:
crazy ass street

description: Very exciting considering we were going less than 5mph!  It's just one of those things you have to do if you're a tourist.  It's very unique and you get a great view of the city.  It's fun watching all the people watching YOU trying to make your way down such a twisty turvy road.
author: Jina R.

description: This is a must-stop for all of my visiting friends, but I honestly don't understand the appeal. Maybe I'm not impressed because I grew up in the city. Maybe I'm not impressed because I went to elementary school literally down the block. Maybe I just realize how useless of a street it is...a tourist attraction built for the sake of being a tourist attraction...and that's it. Well, it was actually built so cars could park on a steep hill, but why this was the only street to get the luxury, I don't know. The neighborhood is beautiful and I can find many good reasons to visit the area, but this street alone...I just don't get it. Yes, it is beautiful when in bloom. Yes, it's curvy. What else?! Oh yeah, when driving down the crooked street (you can ONLY drive down), there's a spectacular view of North Beach and Coit Tower. It's a great view that you can only enjoy for a minute or less. Gotta keep the traffic moving! But again, great neighborhood. You're walking distance to great food and great scenery from other heights. For that, it gets an extra star.
author: Helen L.

description:
I think all tourists (as well as locals who haven't been here yet) should visit this place. Why? Because it's a SF tourist spot, it's featured on postcards, it's pretty, the view is nice and because it's just a street so your visit will only take a few minutes (unless you're a photo whore). A few minutes of your life and you could mark San Francisco's Crooked Street off your checklist.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: So pretty!! A must see in sf. Well maintained, pretty and a true sf experience. Beautiful view. Just hop off the cable car and take a look.
author: Diane S.

description: Definitely a stop by for any one on their first visit to SF. If you love to test your driving skills, this is one heck of a road :)
author: Ahmed K.

description:
It's a fun street to bring out-of-towners to see. It's not so much the zigzag shape but the landscaping that makes it really fun, along with the red brick. 

Word to the wise: as long as you don't mind someone else driving your car, let your out-of-town guests drive down it themselves...that's half the fun!

Also, if you want a "more crooked" street, Vermont Street has a "crooked" portion that is apparently statistically worse (whatever THAT means) than Lombard.

description: It's a must-do if you've never done it, but I'm kinda disappointed at how backed up it gets now. I guess my memories of sailing down the street as a kid with my dad in the front are a dream that can only live in the past. But it was fun and on a Sunday morning didn't take that long.

I did learn this street isn't the only twisty street in SF. There's another one, but isn't famous because the trolleys don't pass by it. I also learned that there used to be more streets like this in the old days because it was easier for horses to trek down all of the steep hills. With the invention of cars streets like this were no longer necessary although a few still remain intact. This street also isn't the steepest street in SF. I passed by the steepest street and there's no way I'd like to climb that! By the way, this is all based off what some local told me. Who knows if it's true. hah

author: Cat T.

author: Carlene R.

description:

The first time I visited Lombard Street was in a car, and that was pretty crazy. I must say though, to be able to truly enjoy it and soak up the quirky view, it's much better to walk it if your calves can handle it!

author: Dawn R.

description:
So this is more of a PSA than a review. I live on Lombard, near Polk, so on the side leading up to it. I can understand others' excitement at seeing this street, when I'm in Pisa, I do those stupid pictures holding up the tower, etc. But please don't wait any longer than you need to for this. As others have suggested, take the Cable Car, it drops you off right there. 

If you must drive it on the weekend, do it BEFORE 1PM, otherwise you'll wait forever. I see it all the time, cars backing up to Van Ness, and there's no reason to. If you come in the morning, you won't wait. Come before 9AM and you can drive down it over and over. 

If you have no choice but to come in the afternoon/evening on the weekend, and you don't mind being a jerk, continue north on Van Ness to Francisco, take a right. Then follow the road as it curves up and to the right. This will put you on Larkin. Then take a left onto Lombard and your wait will be significantly less. 

Do enjoy, but if you get stuck in traffic, you've been warned, so please respect those living in the area and don't honk in frustration, I've heard enough vuvuzuela-type noises in the last month.

it is a must-see, of course, but be aware of all the other tourists who are seeing it! wear your comfortable shoes too. and bring a bottle of water, if you go to the filbert steps then hike to lombard street!

description: When in San Francisco there is no reason to spend a ton of money to see the sites.  Lombard Street is one of those great sites because it is FREE...  All you have to do is take the Powell-Hyde cable car and get off at the top of Lombard Street between Hyde and Leavenworth Streets.  Enjoy the site of several cars driving down the 27% grade, one way, worlds most crooked road as you walk down the side of the street safely on the steps.  On your way, you can take some amazing pictures of the houses, bushes, and flowers that line the sides of the street/stairs.  After reaching Leavenworth Street cross the street and get the beautiful view of the street with the cars taking the eight hairpin, tight turns.  If you want to drive it yourself, be aware that you have to start at the top of the hill on Hyde Street and the speed limit is 5 mph or 8 kpm.  Really and truly, this is a beautiful site to see.
author: Christian H.

description: I don't remember how much hill climbing my friends and I did to come to this street, well at least this time it's a downhill climb. The view from top of the street was amazing! Walking down this street I was afraid what happens if I trip, but luckily I didn't. I wondered how cool it would be to rollerblade down this street. When I reached the bottom it was a pretty cool view to see all the cars moving in zig-zag movements. Argh darn those tourists! author: Sandy C.

description:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/pacific-coast-highway-san-diego#hrid:VwhCzha1F6nIpKF3Ckk7tw 

Can you tell me how to get, how to get to...   Lombard Street?

This is a story about a Street. Stay with me peeps, this is not just any Street and we drove up and down it. Hubby drove, but I want to drive! It's my turn, it's my turn, watch out for that turn!. Ten hairpin turns in all makes for the world's crookedest Street. 

The red bricked street has high cement curbs and beautiful flower gardens along the one way street. If you choose to go sailing down, chances are these will stop you in your tracks. Some of San Francisco's wealthiest Real Estate is along Lombard, with colorful Victorian mansions. The street was designed to be able to switch back down the one way hill. 

Once on the top take a few minutes to view the magnificent city below, as well as the Coit Tower, the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz and Fisherman's Wharf. 

In 1922 a past resident thought up these switchbacks to ease traffic on this 27 degree slope.

Whether you take in it's magnificent views by day or night, this is a must visit.  At night when no one else is around, you could take your foot off the brake, leave go of the wheel and play bumper cars.  My bad? I suggest you do not drink and drive.

It's crowded at the top for the same reason, but getting there is no problem. There are also a lot of cars on the actual curvy street, but traffic moves fast. description:

This one block section of eight sharp turns constitutes the "crookedest street in the world" according to those who track these things.  It was concieved by Carl Henry in 1922 to overcome the hillsides 27% grade.  

The Crooked Street Task Force (probably a bi-product of His Williness) instituted a summer parking ban in 2001 in the area - so don't hope to park anywhere near.  Quick tip - The Powell Hyde Cable Car stops near the top of the block.

And be sure to check out Bill Cosby's parody of it off of his "Why is there Air?" CD.

description:
To all the people who live on the part which is the crookedest, I feel terribly sorry for you. I couldn't imagine not even being able to poop without tourists hanging out in front of your house.

That said, I don't live on that hill or even in San Francisco (nor would I be crazy enough to live on a curvy street on a hill in the first place), so I will stare in awe at this trippy oddity as much as I like.

The view at the top is beautiful. I almost did walk all the way down, but I really wasn't in the mood for walking way up ANOTHER hill so I just stopped in the middle and invaded the neighborhood for a little while. 

I'm dead serious with my first comment by the way. This neighborhood is a total zoo. Loads of people just standing around and hanging out and there's always a car zooming down (sometimes with people screaming like idiots because they're GHOST RIDIN' THE CROOKED ST. Maybe they're from somewhere else in the Bay Area?). Can these people even sleep? 

A definite must see on any trip to SF, even if you will annoy someone who unfortunately lives on this street.
author: Philippe C.

description: fun place to stop by. map it out so the GPS takes you to the top of it so you can go down. unique places! I didn't know there were homes along the way down. must suck when you have to get out of your driveway quickly
author: F P.

description:
Pssssssssssh.

Real World house? Whatever.
The most crooked street in SF? Not true.

Tourists? Hello. Again. And AGAIN. Oh, and AGAIN.

Lombard Street is best enjoyed with Critical Mass, music blasting & troubled that one person will fall & the rest of us will go like dominoes down that crazy ass street.

Good times.
author: matt m.

description: My dad was a traveler and took all of us places one as a kid can only imagine.. caught on video tape (33+) years later, i look back and say THANKS DAD!! I would not take these landmarks for granted, when i can i visit and bring new and old friends to the scene. ITS SF BABY!!
author: Becky U.

description:
P:    We should go to Lombard St. That's a good spot to see how steep these streets get.
EF:   Really!  (Trying to sound enthusiastic while thinking about my brake-to-gas-at-a-stop-light-with-other-cars-all-around mishap from years ago.)

My vaca host was driving while P and I were snapping pictures of every steep hill we were about to ride down. "Whooaaaaa" Yeah, we are dorks! Whatever. It was fun. 

We parked pretty close. I was puzzled by the crowd of people in the middle of the street. Like us, some had cameras with them. I thought it was the scene of an accident, but realized they were standing in front of the one-block marvel that is the famed crooked part of Lombard St.

My guess is that this block is so steep that they had to convert it to a one-way swerving lane. Garden beds of bella hortencia (sometimes called hydrangeas) graced the street. It was a one-block magical ride, like something out of a musical with pretty parasol ladies in pastels and gents in seersucker suits. There were sidewalks and smooth paved pathways on either sides of the block. *Cool* 

We got back in the car to drive through it. No one swerved through it very fast unless they were begging to have a date with cell mate #691212. 

There was no trouble finding another parking spot either. Yay! We made our way back over to the bottom of said block to gawk some more. It was hard to take pictures of the curvy lanes even with my arm stretched all the way up, so I had the bright idea of sitting totem-pole style on top of my 5'10"  vaca host's shoulders. P snapped a picture of my butt as I climbed up there. I dunno why she did that. At least my butt is nice. I have to admit I was very scared up there. My vaca host told me to stop molesting his head. What am I supposed to do to hold on tight? Well I survived and was satisfied with the photos I got out of it.
author: elsa f.

description:
What a novel idea for a tourist attraction. The world's most wiggly street. They've also decked it out nicely with flowers.

One star off for being relatively inaccesible
author: Yee Gan O.

description: Absolutely beautiful! What a wacky street! I loved all the different styles of houses on both sides of the street. They are pure architectural genius. I'm so glad I got to see this.
author: Eric W.

description:
People that live on this street must love tourists, or are masochists

I was so excited about driving down this path in the Scion tC Zipcar that I rented. But it was hardly exciting. Very slow turns, tons of tourists and their cars. I can't imagine anyone that wants to have live here. Unless they love the false sense of celebrity status that they get from all these wannabe papparazzis with their point and shoot cameras. The drive around this block is actually more exciting as the angle of elevation in the area is so steep. Anyway, the flowers in the path, and just the bricked layered path itself make this street one of the most memorable street in SF. I had to drive down 2x after seeing someone getting out of the passenger side of a car on the path and taking pics of the driver. Glad my gf is such a good sport about it. I'm sure she didn't mind with all the nice flowers there.
author: Jack N.

description: It's a novelty, not worth the 60+ minute wait on an insanely steep hill to get to the top, flowers weren't in bloom, it was like waiting a really long time for a really slow bendy slide...
author: Lasairiona M.

description:
I had heard about Lombard Street ever since I was a kid and I heard Bill Cosby talk about it during one of his stand-up routines.

He sort of explained it but you don't really know it until you've seen it in person, driven down it, walked up/down it, etc.

I used to live just up Hyde from there so I would pass by it fairly often and see the line of cars full of tourists waiting their turn to be next.
author: Mike J.

description:
Wow the wackiness! A curvy street. "Honey lets take some pictures!" Screech goes my scooter as I pull a quazi enzo infront of some asshole Russian couple who begin to scream at me. I told them politely to eat my ass and to get out of the middle of the road.

author: F B.

description: Good to see for a few minutes to check it off the list. It is unique and well maintained/landscaped. There were quite a few tourists hanging around taking pictures, as you would expect.
author: Curtis H.

description:
I am not typically a fan of anything crooked.  The word crooked conjures up images of crooked politicians, crooked noses, crooked Policeman, and crooked Teeth.  As a law-abiding citizen who suffered through two years of braces and two broken noses, I am not partial to any of them.

So needless to say, I was not very excited about having Lombard Street "the crookedest street in America" be Stop 4 on our Tourgasmic Trip of San Francisco.  But, as this is a "must-see" tourist destination, we made the trek up a few blocks from Fisherman's Wharf.

Though this street made me feel bad for anyone rich enough to live on it secondary to the constant flow of tourists, I am also easily amused and entertained, so I enjoyed it.  I laughed. I smiled. I posed for pictures like the best of 'em.  I ignored the "Do not Enter" sign and walked part way up the road.  All the honks made me feel like a movie star.  I thought, "Yup, I'm a hottie.  Honk your heart out."  Then as a man yelled, "Get out of the road a$$hole" it finally sunk in that the honking horns weren't simply because I am cute, but also related to the fact that I was blocking traffic.  I did my best Betty Boop "oops" and got out of the road.        

If you are as easily entertained as I am (Does America's Funniest Home Videos or the word "poop" make you laugh?), follow the pack mentality, and have a tour-guide book in hand, then you will enjoy this place.
author: Heather F.

description:
Yes, it may be a tourist trap *pointing at german tourist taking photos*, but hey it Lombard St. you gotta drive down it at least once while in San Francisco...and don't forget to take your picture at the bottom of the street with the tourist cars driving down the hill behind you.

A must do. Let your inner kid out!
author: Saul A.

description: Sure, it's just a really wind-y street, but it's so much fun! The views from the top really are incredible, some of my favorite in the entire city, and driving down is such a cool experience. Do it. It's classic San Francisco and a lot of fun if you go down it with the right people!
author: Hannah D.

description: Definitely the craziest street I've ever seen! However, I can see how visitors to this area could make living in the area a HUGE pain. My husband and I did NOT drive down Lombard, and I doubt we ever would (it looked pretty scary for the drivers!) Instead, we took a walk up the stairs beside the street & watched cars getting way too close to one another on the way down. Pretty sure a bumper-car would come in handy on Lombard. Anyway... Worth seeing, I'd say. The houses are really pretty, and the landscaping is gorgeous. Just be sure you always pick up after yourselves & try to remember that people LIVE on Lombard, so you're in their front yard (basically). :)
author: Carrie O.

description:
Lombard street doesn't even deserve one star. While the houses that sit on the street are absolutely beautiful, the fucking tourists that cement themselves to the street/sidewalks make this "San Francisco highlight" and absolute nightmare! 

Never try driving up Leavenworth St.  past Lombard. This is the bottom of the hill, which is permanently inundated with foreigners of all kinds. Honking, yelling, giving the finger- it will do you no good. And don't even try walking past here. If you get in the way of someone's camera for an oh-so-crucial shot of this windy road (like it's going somewhere any time soon...) you can bet your ass is going to get yelled at. Seriously. 

I know I sound utterly cynical, but living in the area makes you wish no one actually knew about it! Because really, it's a cool street with gorgeous home. Damn, fucking people.
author: Brock H.

description:

description:

San Francisco is known for its steep hills; Lombard street (the brick touristy part) was built because cars were not able to climb it easily. 

- 1 star 
Did ya know? Lombard street is not the crookedest street in San Francisco, let alone the world! The crookedest street is Vermont Street between 20th and 22nd!
author: Jessica W.

description: This is a must do if you are visiting San Francisco. The road is so curvy and yet entertaining. All you need to do is drive and work with breaks - no need to accelerate also. Very cute place to visit in SF and best - it's FREE!!! Some houses on this curvy road actually have garages. You can only go one way on Lombard street from up to down and a lot of streets around the actual entrance of the street are not a direct right or left. Plan your drive well or else you will end up driving a block or two round and round before you actually get to the main entrance. Overall really awesome!!

author: Amy C.

description:

i have to admit it was kinda SCARY driving down Lombard street. the turns are really NARROW!

hmm, i hope someday San Francisco will start snowing (i wish) and i'll take my snowboard and board down the street!

author: Carol Y.

description: This is a quick drive. Next time I would love to walk down and just stare for a while. This is a very quick visit about 10-30 minutes. Near pier 39 (sea lions), fisher mans wharf and ghiardelli square. All can be done in 1/2 day or full day.

description: A must see while in San Fran.  You have lots of cool views of the city from here.
author: Travis D.

description:
Lombard Street - its really crooked! It is nice to visit Lombard during Spring and Summer time here in Frisco because the flowers are in full bloom and you'll get the chance to take really good pics and probably use the stairs.

If you're a passerby - don't come because cars move about like 5mph or less and the hill is really tough! (the hill of Lombard street between franklin till larkin --its really high!
