description: Definitely worth the drive over. Follow down from Coit Tower. Take a lot of pictures, and watch out for tourists!
author: Jackie S.

description: Loses one star for being so damn steep.  I have to admit, as much as I think this is a cool tourist attraction and generally pretty neato street, I got winded walking up it.  Pretty much a must see/walk but wear your comfy shoes.  (-:   We have a love hate relationship.
author: Mina I.

description:
I'm sure most of us have seen the movie, "Herbie, the Love Bug" where they race Herbie down Lombard street. The movie probably made the street more famous than it was to begin with and it's definitely intriguing and exhilarating to drive your own vehicle down the street as well, possibly even pretending you're in the movie!

You have to be careful as to how you enter the street. On busy days, city police officers will be at the top of the hill, directing traffic and ticketing people who turn to enter the street from the wrong direction (believe it or not). I found this out the hard way one year, but the officer was kind enough to look the other way as I skipped a huge line of cars waiting to drive down the zig-zag street. On not-so-busy days, you should be fine entering the street from any direction (even though the signs are still posted about making illegal turns into the street) and you can park at the bottom of the hill and take a few pictures of the entire street like you see displayed here on Yelp.
author: Joshua W.

description:
Crooked street...

Great to see, but i'm guessing the owners there must hate all the spectators.
Hard to take pictures from the top, but fun to ride down a famous street like this.
author: Realtor Karl B.

description: Fun to visit but not much to see. There are however, great views of alcatraz from the top of the street.  Fun to walk around and take pictures and there are always people here.
author: Melissa W.

description: walk it or drive it. it's a crooked street with lovely flowers and green bushes year round, especially during spring and summer. worth a stop for pictures with those family and friends from out of town. great views of the City.  http://www.sftravel.com/lomabardcrookedstreet.html
author: Jeff W.

description: Lombard Street is actually a long major street in San Francisco running east to west, however when mentioning the street the image of the "most crooked street in America" title comes to mind (that or any number of tv or movie references to the street you've ever seen). This curvy (about 8 hairpin turns) 1/4 mile section of Lombard is between Leavenworth and Hyde streets. The curvy section of the street was designed in 1922 due to it's extremely steep 27 degree incline. The street is paved with red bricks and features gorgeous landscaping both between the turns as well as along the staired pedestrian walkways on either side. If you're visiting and want to check out the street for yourself the best place to photograph it (if you have a 200mm or longer zoom) is several blocks away on Lombard and Stockton otherwise going right to the base of it is good too. Once you walk to the top of the curvy section (which is at Hyde St) then it's a very quiet and picturesque walk down Hyde to Ghirardelli Square and Fisherman's Wharf (or you could wait for the Hyde Street Cable Car ($5) to bring you down). In case you're wondering this isn't the only windy street in San Francisco (it is the best looking though) there's actually another one on Vermont between 20th and 22nd. If you're amused by the interesting streets of SF then it's worth going a couple blocks away to Filbert (between Hyde and Leavenworth) as this is one of the cities steepest streets.
author: Matt E.

description: lombard street is pretty overwhelming when there are so many people standing at the top and bottom of the street. its an experience to drive down it, like a mini slow roller coaster on a random sf hill. picture worthy background, but that's about it. not much else to the street. finding parking could possibly be difficult, but i was able to find parking within 5 mins at the top (hyde st) and bottom (leavenworth st). also, beware of pedestrians randomly walking and taking pictures as you coast on down that crooked street. THEY"RE EVERYWHERE!
author: Jennifer H.

description: It's just whatevs, kind of cool I guess. It was fun to moped down it. I also feel bad for the people who live on this street who just need to get out of their drive way.
author: Hana G.

description:
I've gone down Lombard countless times, each time has been almost as magical as the first. Which is saying a lot because I'm scared of heights!

There's always a line, even in tourist off-seasons.

You have to jam out at high volume to whatever gets you pumped as you go down a crooked street meant for horses, not horsepower, so slowly you're almost going backwards.

Plan that it'll take you at least 30 minutes to get through the experience.

I recommend it to anyone who wants to enjoy San Francisco's historical sites.
author: Ashley B.

description:
It's a must-see for tourists and out-of-towners! It's funny that I actually drive my visitors down the ever wonderful "crookedest" street but I was told that there is an even more crooked street in SF, I wonder where though? 

Everyone seems to enjoy it, everyone takes picture of it....what more can I say, join in the fun and go with the flow. Ok, it might actually be a standstill on a public holiday or weekend!
author: Yan M.

description:
I just love Lombard Street, to me it is THE SAN FRANCISCO. Crooked!

It is so touristy and fun. Just find a spot to park (Good luck), get out and do what everybody else does, walk around. I'm sure the residents love all of the people walking on their property all day and night. ;(

Or if you are smart you can take the cable cars to the top, get out at the Lombard stop and walk down and then back up. Be careful though because the walk back UP is a bear so take it slow. Even if you are a SF native you have to do the walk at least once a year. It is as much of an institution as the Golden Gate Bridge or Alcatraz.

Only in SF can a street be an attraction.
author: Terry H.

description:
It's alriiiiiight! I prefer walking up and down the stairs rather than driving.... other drivers take forever-days driving down this road! its crazzyyyy! I would hate to live here... with everyone blocking my driveway...

Lots of tourist posing...laying down on the road... jumping on trees.. hugging them... posing next to flowers... piggy-backing each other...  taking picture at the top of road.. at the bottom of road... in the middle of road...hahaha.. love it! i love people!

walking up was fun...whewww! but we conquered it. three stars for downhill, uphill & toning my calves. :)
author: Shenni C.

description:
Just some points of advice:

1. If you're going to walk it, don't start at Powell and Lombard... because you'll walk down to the bottom of the hill and then up the ENTIRE hill; the wiggly bit is only at the top top stretch.

2. Be wary of cars as they have decided on occupying the same spot at the bottom of the hill where pictures are taken.

3. That burnt smell is the breaks....

4. ... or the clutch.

5. Take pictures of the people taking pictures... I've found them to be more interesting than the street itself sometimes...

6. There's a cable car stop at the top of the hill at Hyde and Lombard... seriously give it a go, I haven't been on one in 15 years, and it was heaps of fun, and a great/cheap way to get back downtown.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: A San Francisco tourist staple! You do not get the full experience of Lombard Street unless you drive down it. Like everywhere in San Francisco parking is difficult to get out and take pictures of the street but if you are sneaky you can park in a nondesignated area and get a quick pic, just as long as you do it fast. There are gorgeous homes on this block!
author: aldencondict

description:
I always drive down it when I can, but remember about half-way through that I'm going to be in about half the photos being taken by the nice Asian family at the bottom of the crooked street...they wave, I wave, I keep movin on.

It's one of those kooky San Francisco things.
author: Sophie D.

description:
Lombard Street is absolutely beautiful on a sunny day and I make sure to take friends/family when they visit from out of town.

That said, I truly feel rather sorry for the people who live on this street. As beautiful as it is, having tourists driving down it at virtually all hours of the day would drive me absolutely insane. I once had a tourist get upset with me when I exited my old building and (apparently) "ruined" his photo so I can only imagine how the people who live on Lombard must feel at times.
author: Anita B.

description:
The Perfect Date Stop #5:

The top of Lombard Street is a great place to sit and eat your Swenson's ice cream while watching the oversized SUV's from out of town try to negotiate the hairpin turns and the Bay Bridge sparkle in the distance. I would love to live here, but I am sure that the oversized crowds in the summer would get on my nerves. 

Each April there is a Big Wheel race down the street. Don't miss it.

This pretty much concludes the end of the perfect date, unless you need an after dinner/elevator/cable car/ice cream/lombard street cocktail. Then I would reccommend...
author: A W.

description:
I feel sorry for the residents here who must endure 
the cars that pass, all hours of the day and night.  I
must admit that, for the thirty years I've lived here, and,
fo the many years before that I was a visitor, I've been
guilty of traversing that crooked drive at all hours,
totally thrilled by its curves and the view of this 
fabulous city.  At 62 years old, it still delights me 
every time and I bring every guest, at least once to
share in my joy!
author: Carmen H.

description: This is one of the most randomest things that you will ever see.  It is a tourist must when in San Francisco.  To get the FULL San Francisco experience and save yourself some energy, take a cable car (one cable car ride is $5 and you have to be patient because all us tourists are filling up the cable cars during tourist season!) to the top of the hill, then walk down hill.  The views are great at the top of the road, and the flowers are pretty.
author: Rona H.

description:
The most ridiculous street in the world. We never drove the road but we did walk it from bottom to top and were knackered by the time we reached the summit. The view from the bottom and then from the top was fascinating, i just wish there was a way to skip the middle.
It's steeper than any staircase and you could climb your way up as easily as walk it. I pity any person that lives on that street (even though the Victorian mansions are amazing) and has to make that zig-zagging drive a daily routine.
author: Weaver

description: Its kind of hard to write a review on a street. Its fun to drive down here. Did it a few times for kicks but thats about it. Its pretty nice got lots of flowers on the side. I even got to walk up and down it before. Pretty cool street. Something you do only once and thats it.
author: Daniel S.

description: The debates will continue on whether or not this block of Lombard Street is the crookedest street in the world. But it doesn't matter. Lombard Street is pretty cool! I recommend taking the Powell-Hyde Cable Car to the top of Lombard and then walking DOWN the hill.

description: They always have some kind sport event here oh i mean they used to.  Now  its just driving a car.  I don't go there a lot.  I would like to own one of the houses here.

description: Pretty touristy but that's that. I kept thinking how annoyed I would be if I lived there but I guess they expect that when they move in. The street is curvy and interesting to see. There are some pretty houses along the sides and some nice flowers too.  It's worth the stop if you're in the area. I don't think tourists are supposed to actually drive down it.  You can get a good view of the bay from some spots here too.
author: reviewer m.

description: The Street was built as it is now in 1922 to avoid accidents due to a 32% grade. It is considered as the Crookedest Street in the world. Actually, I find Vermont Street even more tricky. Anyway, if you want to drive down Lombard, it's very early in the morning, after that the queues are too long. It's also the ideal time for pictures.
author: CasimirVessel

description:
beautiful!  flowers were in full bloom!  minus all the people that walk in the street, this place is cool to drive down.  

it's a curvey street, so i'm not gonna hype it up like you're about to have a miracle happen to you once you set eyes on it.  i would definately hate to live on this street because all of the tourist.  but there's little nooks and spaces that you can stop and take pictures at .  cool attraction to go to and just look at.
author: Marie T.

description: I drove down Lombard St. years ago. It is beautiful and fun, but so many tourists! Recently, we wanted to share the experience with our kids since the last time we went, my husband and I were still dating. We had just finished coming from Pier 39 along Hyde St and then saw the sign, No Left turn on Lombard St.! It was just not convenient to turn around and go the other direction from Hyde since the line to go down Lombard St. is insane. We'll have to come back another time.  The day we went was on a gray, overcast summer day in SF, so I do want to go back on a sunny day for better photos.

Even driving down Lombard wasn't as exciting as I thought.

description: i enjoyed walking down lombard street..the flowers are beautiful and the design is just perfect. a great tourist attraction..you can see Alcatraz, bay area and the rest of the city from this point.

The driver charged me for the time he spent apologizing to the tourist.
author: Alicia A.

author: J D.

description: I love the street, but damn dude, get out of the way.  Do the tourists think I won't run them over?  This is still a functioning street cars must drive down.  Seriously, I will break your camera.  I'm a crazy local.

description: Touristy, but it is really fun to drive/ride down this street.  My family had been pitching a fit that I had yet to see the world's crookedest street since I moved here.  So I had a friend drive down and I took a video.  Cheesy, but they loved it.  It really is impressive to see, and the houses and landscaping is quite nice.  If you are on the trolley, it's def worth hopping off and at least seeing on you way to/from the Wharf.
author: Jen K.

description: I've yet to drive down Lombard, but I'm really excited to! I've walked and driven past the windy street... I think it's neat!
author: Andrew C.

description: I would go back to walk but I wouldn't think of this if I had to make a list of what people should see in the city.  I love the brick but I would rather walk because it must be annoying for the residents because of the tourists.  The first time I visited San Francisco with my best friend and boyfriend he drove down here a couple of times.  This is his favorite part of the city, because he played some kind of racing game when he was younger so when he finally visited here, driving was familiar!  The landscaping is great.
author: Ai M.

description: I think Lombard street wins for drama, but there is another contender out there for crookedest street: http://www.snakealley.com/
author: Kelly S.

description: On my 2nd day of Driver's Training (total driving experience: 4 hours), my driving teacher took me here! It was kind of hard, but a fun and lovely street to drive. Nice views when it's nice weather (:
author: Pam S.

description: Wait a tick...I thought Castro was the "least straight street in the world."
author: Aaron A.

description: If it is your first time to San Francisco, you MUST see Lombard St!  I've seen it numerous times, and even drove down it once.  It can also provide a great photo op when it's not too crowded.
author: R R.

description: peering in these upscale houses along "the crookedest street in the world," you will see that lombard street residents are just your average san franciscans: Full House watching, rice-a-roni eating, cable-car riding, liberal voting, same-sex marriage approving, citizens. nothing too far off from the stereotype of smug san franciscans who choose to live on the not-so-straight-and-narrow-path....literally.
author: Rene T.

description: If you want a great place to test your brakes as well as your driving skills on a road outside the racetrack (legally), then Lombard Street is the place for you. And you have to drive through it without hitting the walls, tourists, or the flowers on your way down (think hand-eye-feet coordination). Once you're done, you can get out of the car and take a picture of the crooked street (and wonder if your car still works). Is it a worthy attraction in San Francisco? You bet!
author: Isaiah N.

description: I love this spot, for several reasons.  One being that my grandfather was an old school San Franciscan and he loved telling us how, before there were regulations and a speed limit enforced on the street, he would drive down Lombard as fast as humanly possible.  My grandmother would be sitting in the passenger seat screaming for him to slow down.  It is just a hilarious image and I wish I could speed down it sometimes!  Besides that random tidbit, I think the view and the location are beautiful.  It is a fun spot to stop by in San Francisco, and a nice area to explore after taking in Lombard Street.  Great area, especially on a clear day.
author: Lauren H.

description: Standard San Fran drive. Both fun for the 45 second ride downhill, and for the picture taking. This in actuality is not the most crooked, nor the steepest street in San Fransisco in fact but still a bucket list type of activity. Make sure to take the time to drive down the hill, then find parking at the bottom to enjoy that view as well. The view of the ride itself looking toward SF is gorgeous, and it is fun to watch other people make their venture too.
author: Rachel S.

description: I think i've come to lombard street every time i would visit family in SF as a child, and now that i moved back to the city and live within walking distance i've been back many times in the past couple weeks! the view is amazing on a clear day, although yeah, all the tourists are super annoying (and i want to take photos myself, but don't want to blend in with all the annoying tourists...but given its lombard street, tourists are a given)...i highly recommend either taking the cable car by, or walking around on hyde street in the area! also, in the warmer weather all the flowers make it that much prettier! its crazy that it can go from practically a 6 lane highway to this picturesque within a few blocks...
author: Danielle J.

description: It's just a darn crooked street, but heck, it's unique. Try not to get hit by the cable car at the top.
author: Dave L.

description: It's a beautiful street...but the parade of tourists make it annoying sometimes...still it's awesome...
author: Francis K.

description: Great place... Our out of town friend was salivating during the exciting 90 second drive.  Our friend had lots of questions about banana peels on the road, what happens when it rains, and many more thought-provoking questions which I promise I'll get to one of these years.
author: Mike M.

description: Best on a motorcycle, fast as you can do it.   Not officially the most winding street in SF, but a fun one all the same.  I doubt I will be walking and pointing at things on the street anytime soon, it just isn't the same.  Visits to Lombard Street usually last no more than 11 seconds for me (with traffic).
author: Eric T.

description: A must for tourists. This prettily kept brick road is a fun drive. The big surprise for your kid will be that there are tourists stupid enough to walk down the middle of this street while you are driving down it. One couple even left their baby in a carseat on one side of the street so that they could take a picture of each other on the other.  My daughter was excited that people actually LIVE on this street, and thought it was so nicely tended that the people must be magical, or oompa loompas, or munckins or something. Too cute.  Minus one star because it's a little over-rated, and the experience goes quickly.
author: Dayna S.

description: Touristy SF spot. But I gotta secret for ya! Go up Filbert street and then make a right onto Lombard to get to the twisty street. Dont have to wait in line with all the out of towners.
author: Roy L.

description: Had to see it and drive it! Very pretty street, lots of tourists, as you would expect, but you've got to really. I loved it, would hate to live on it, but it's lovely.
author: Kellemar

description: Check it out either early or late - we were there in the afternoon and the place was inundated with Italians and midwesterners yelling obscenities and nonsense.
author: Quartknee K.

description: a must see if you're in san fran.  yeah, there's a lot of tourists clicking away, but you'll be doing the same.  there's also a nice view from the top.
author: Immer E.

description: outstanding area, but the traffic situation will definitely test your patience.  visit this area during the day, since you can't take too many good pictures at night.  if you enter from the bottom, you may be able to quickly park on the side to take a pic and hurry off.  must visit at least once on your trip to sf, but after that, i'd try to avoid the area like the plague unless you like being caught in a traffic jam.
author: Bryce K.
